IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Quantitively decoding how cell fate changes can provide novel mechanistic insight into organogenesis and tissue regeneration, and help identify new strategies for the treatment of human diseases. This project aims to develop the first computational methods and toolkits for generating cell dynamics atlases and analyzing cell state transition and its regulation based on the appropriate reference atlases. The ability to build cell dynamics reference landscapes will open a new horizon to understand the diversity of cell fate through comparative analyses across tissues and diseases and enhance regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We seek to extend follow-up of our Atlanta ECHO Cohort participants under the ECHO Protocol and participate in solution-oriented ECHO team science. The unique contributions of our Cohort Study site include our demonstrated capacity to follow hard-to-reach racial and ethnic minority families (as our cohort is wholly composed of Black American families, 75% of whom are of lower socioeconomic status); our geographic location in a major metropolitan area in the US Southeast that experiences unique regional and area-level stressors (e.g., racialized segregation, structural racism); and our multi-disciplinary team of psychosocial, clinical, and omic investigators with expertise in (personalized) exposure assessment, maternal stress, perinatal and birth outcomes, and child neurodevelopment.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The term asthma is an umbrella diagnosis for several disease states with distinct variable clinical presentations (phenotypes) and mechanistic pathways (endotypes). In clinical care for childhood asthma, treatments are largely applied universally to all children with asthma, even though it has been shown that some treatments we use may not benefit certain asthma sub-types. The focus of this proposal is to define clinical asthma sub-types so that they may be easily identified in clinical practice, understand their distinct disease biology, and determine what risk factors promote asthma sub-type development with the goal to have targeted treatment and prevention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  We will investigate the network of paracrine signals communicating between cell types in pancreatic cancer by applying a powerful set of computational algorithms to a new and unique set of human patient samples. We will use a new model system culturing intact human pancreatic tumors in order to test the hypothesis that targeting key paracrine nodes that regulate multiple cell types simultaneously is more effective at counteracting the effects of the tumor microenvironment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narrative Kidney transplantation is the preferred kidney replacement therapy in patients with end-stage kidney disease but structural racism impacts access to kidney transplant referrals, evaluations, and waitlistings in Black and Hispanic patients. We propose to address these disparities using a multilevel approach by 1) Use a community health worker (CHW) to identify and manage SDOH-related and symptoms as barriers to kidney transplantation; 2) Have a CHW universally refer eligible patients for kidney transplantation and facilitate clearance appointments; and 3) Identify and educate transplant providers regarding stigmatizing language in transplant evaluation notes. Our project will be co-lead by a Community Stakeholder Board consisting of patients, caregivers, providers, advocates, and dialysis system leaders who will drive development, recruitment and retention, and dissemination of this project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The airways of patients with cystic fibrosis and other chronic lung diseases, as well as ventilator-associated pneumonia, are persistently colonized by respiratory bacterial pathogens, many of which are highly recalcitrant to antibiotics. Repeated episodes of microbial infections exaggerate proinflammatory response and cause excessive mucus that clog the airways, leading to reduced gas exchanges, detrimental physiological changes, reduced lung function and increased morbidity and mortality. Examination of the role volatile organic compounds produced by these pathogens that may directly contribute to excessive airway mucus production and deciphering the underlying molecular mechanisms, as proposed in this application, will help to improve the prognosis of patients with these chronic lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative To initiate collaborative genome-wide association studies (GWAS) on large genomic datasets, all researchers typically need to go through a long institutional review board (IRB) process to exchange raw datasets that include personal genomes of individuals. This complicates the predictability and timeliness of such studies, because researchers cannot identify valuable collaborators with high confidence without going through the entire IRB process at each institution. The goal of this research is to develop privacy-preserving algorithms within a sandbox environment, which (1) help researchers identify and eliminate low-quality, biased, or statistically dependent records from their federated datasets; (2) generate an accurate preview of researchers’ collaborative GWAS results to provide evidence for benefit versus risk tradeoff in IRB approval; (3) identify what part of the datasets should be shared among the collaborators (once they obtain the full IRB approval), and hence lead to data minimization; and eventually (4) democratize genomic data sharing across researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed K01 research will provide a framework for future Alzheimer’s disease (AD) prevention trials to intervene at an earlier point in the disease process than is currently possible with standard amyloid-beta (A)- PET approaches, increasing the feasibility of AD prevention rather than treatment to slow a neurodegenerative process that is already underway. A novel A-PET spatial extent approach will be developed that enables detection of the earliest focal A deposits below standard PET detection thresholds, allowing future trials to target individuals in the earliest stage of amyloidosis. This novel spatial extent approach will be used to examine the earliest changes in A spread, tau proliferation, and subtle cognitive decline, and establish optimized primary and secondary endpoints for clinical trials aiming to move closer to primary prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because delineation of the clinical benefits and mechanism of cardiovascular remodeling in patients with coarctation of aorta receiving angiotensin-II receptor blockers (ARB) will help develop novel management paradigms for prevention of left ventricular dysfunction and cardio- vascular death in this population, which will in turn save lives, reduce morbidity, and reduce healthcare costs. Successful completion of the proposed research in this application will provide strong justification for future multicenter clinical trials to determine the survival benefits of ARB and other classes of antihypertensive medi- cations in patients with repaired COA. The proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission per- taining to the pursuit of knowledge to extend healthy life and reduce the burdens of illness and disability.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of the Enriching ECHO with High-risk Pregnancies and Children with Disabilities (Enriching ECHO) cohort is to advance disabilities inclusivity in ECHO research by studying children with a spectrum of disability and by leveraging existing data from ECHO participants with disabilities. Our scientific premise is that psychosocial environmental exposures (e.g., social determinants of health, stress, social environment, discrimination) and modifiable personal factors (e.g., parenting style, social supports, mental health) impact the physical and emotional health of children with disabilities resulting in definable outcomes of function, well-being, and participation in community and family life. Our hypothesis is that we can identify specific modifiable environmental factors associated with better-than-expected positive health outcomes along the continuum of disability to typical development that allow children with disabilities (and, by extension, all children) to thrive.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Men are less likely to complete TB treatment, contributing to their reduced life expectancy in South Africa. To address the paucity of interventions to improve men's TB outcomes, the proposed project will determine the feasibility of Coach Mpilo for men and assess secondary outcomes on treatment completion and viral suppression among HIV co-infected. Findings will provide essential information to support a larger effectiveness study in this setting.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The NIH has established the Environmental influences on Child Health Outcomes (ECHO) Program, a collaborative multi-dimensional research initiative to characterize the impact of early-life environmental factors (e.g., social-environmental, parental risk factors, nicotine, diet, infection) on childhood health. Vanderbilt will support ECHO by establishing the ECHO Laboratory Core at Vanderbilt for Integrated Sample Tracking and Processing (ELVIS), to facilitate the collection and processing of biospecimens; manage the biorepository; performs a wide range of biospecimen assays (including novel development), and coordinate metadata and assay data transfer to the Coordinating Center. Successful completion will enable the success of ECHO’s mission to discover molecular underpinnings of early childhood determinants of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Poverty impacts over 37 million individuals in the U.S., putting them at risk for syndemics – clustered epidemics such as obesity, diabetes, and depression that arise from and perpetuate socioeconomic inequality. This application aims to mitigate syndemics by designing, delivering, and testing a fully automated online obesity treatment for those in poverty, working in partnership with primary care patients and providers. Given that 72.8% of adults in poverty have a primary care provider, and 82% have Internet access, this work has high potential for public health impact and findings will address a critical gap in scientific literature.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP) are at increased risk of mortality related to the development of malignant ventricular arrhythmias, also known as Arrhythmic MVP, yet there are no pathognomonic features for accurate patient characterization and we lack strategies to reduce this risk. PET/MRI imaging has emerged as a novel strategy for the detection, quantification and localization of myocardial changes related to increased risk of ventricular arrhythmias including left ventricular replacement fibrosis and the preceding stage of inflammation. The goal of this study is to demonstrate how PET/MRI adds complementary and valuable information to the current assessment of patients with MVP and ideally results in improved arrhythmic risk stratification.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will continue following children enrolled in the national ECHO study. We will investigate the impact of environmental chemicals and maternal overnutrition factors on child obesity and neurodevelopment and identify potential mechanisms and factors that may mitigate adverse effects. Results will provide a better understanding of the developmental origins of child obesity and neurodevelopment and inform future interventions, prevention strategies and policies to reduce the burden of these common and costly childhood disorders and their long-term impact on health across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Memory declines in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) develop before the onset of obvious clinical symptoms, but these changes are subtle and are often missed with conventional assessments that only measure memory over short periods of time. This project will develop and validate a smartphone-based memory assessment that extends memory testing to much longer and more realistic time periods. The ultimate goal is to incorporate this new assessment into ongoing clinical trials so that more sensitive tests are used to help determine the effectiveness of AD treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Recognizing and responding to social cues is fundamental for health and wellbeing, though the developmental processes by which neural circuits supporting recognition are shaped is poorly understood. The proposed research leverages an invertebrate model of individual facial recognition, a paper wasp that also requires social experience for normal development of recognition. The ability to easily manipulate social experience coupled with the smaller brain and rapid development time of paper wasps will aid in discovering basic principles by which social experience modulates neural circuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SUMOylation adds SUMO (a small polypeptide) to proteins, and polySUMOylation is a result of attachment of chains of SUMO. This project will investigate how polySUMOylation controls the relocation of key cell cycle regulators during the cell cycle and how this timely relocation contributes to genome stability. Because deregulation of SUMOylation leads to genome instability and cancer development, the results will likely provide new strategies for the treatment of cancer and other diseases.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will recruit 2,800 pregnant people, their partners, and their children into the EFFECT cohort to study how social and community influences before a child’s birth play a role in the development of child obesity. Our proposed cohort and study team are perfectly positioned to meet the current needs of the ECHO program: 1) to address solution-oriented scientific questions of high priority; 2) to increase the number of enrolled pregnant participants; 3) to facilitate the enrollment of the non-gestational parent; 4) to facilitate collection of preconception data; 5) to increase the racial, ethnic, and socioeconomic diversity of the ECHO cohort; and 6) to increase diversity in race, ethnicity, career stage, and professional background of the study team.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The Developmental Impact of NICU Exposures (DINE) brings a unique and sensitive population with a demonstrated large burden of adverse health outcomes to the ECHO Pediatric Cohorts program. In this second phase of the ECHO program, we will continue to focus on the scientific premise that early life physical and chemical exposures, notably phthalates and air pollution, have long-lasting harmful effects on child health and development, particularly on pulmonary outcomes. We will also explore one of the central tenets of our work, that preterm infants can be studied to identify exposure-outcome links that may be more subtle in the general population, through the large ECHO cohort that enroll participants born over the entire preterm-to-term continuum.

PHR: Narrative Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) causes significant morbidity and mortality in infants with a global disease burden of 64 million cases and 160,000 deaths with healthcare costs estimated at $365-$585 million per year. The objective of the current research proposal is to elucidate the role of human SP-A genetic variant and sex in RSV severity and to get insight into the mechanisms of host factors that govern the severity of RSV disease. This will lead to the development of novel approaches and individualized therapeutic options for severe RSV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic, daily, oral anticoagulation reduces the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation but increases the risk of hemorrhage, including fatal hemorrhage, even during long periods of sinus rhythm when the risk of cardioembolic stroke is low. This study will compare the current standard of care of continuous anticoagulation with a novel approach of targeted, time-delimited anticoagulation therapy guided by an AF-sensing smartwatch. If successful, this paradigm shift toward individualized or “precision” stroke prevention could reduce anticoagulant use, hemorrhage risk, healthcare utilization and cost for millions of AF patients worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Poverty and racism result in increased adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) and decreased positive childhood experiences (PCEs), which is associated with disparities in early child development (ECD) that begin early in life, widen as children age, and persist across the lifespan. Evidence-based preventive interventions (EBPIs) located in pediatric primary care and designed to reduce these disparities have shown some evidence of impact in addressing ACEs or supporting PCEs in insolation, but they have been limited because they fail to address both concurrently and directly, and because knowledge related to dissemination and implementation (D&I) is limited. This study proposes to identify best practices to implement integrated EBPIs, and to evaluate a novel integration of two exemplar, AAP-recommended EBPIs, HealthySteps and Video Interaction Project, in order to: 1) support wide D&I of co-located services; and 2) provide population-level impacts in reducing ECD disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Diabetes is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, and is on the rise. The role of different nutrients in diabetes is poorly understood. We have uncovered here a novel mechanism that links a specific class of nutrients, branched chain amino acids, to diabetes and to blood pressure, and we propose experiments to understand the process in molecular and physiological detail, in order to determine if and how targeting this pathway may have therapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/LAY STATEMENT Patients with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) require effective coordination to manage numerous longitudinal care needs including diagnosis, exacerbation of symptoms, and to treat existing comorbidities. Supporting primary care providers to manage and coordinate healthcare delivery among specialist teams is important to improve outcomes and better quality of life for patients with ADRD. The goal of this project is to develop approaches that monitor trends in care coordination among primary care providers and specialist teams and recommend actionable opportunities for improvement, which will ensure that patients receive high- quality multidisciplinary care necessary to maintain long-term wellbeing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Progress has been made in identifying genetic risk factors for PTSD. However, the under-representation of African populations in PTSD genetic research risks widening existing research and treatment disparities for such populations. The goal of this proposal is to accelerate genetic discovery for PTSD by addressing the under- representation of African populations in PTSD genetic research through a unique U.S. – African partnership which includes large-scale data collection, the long-term goal is to ensure the genomics revolution in psychiatry benefits future generations of Africans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE In this 5-year follow-up to the IGNITE exercise intervention study we will examine whether exercise has a delayed or protracted benefit to neurocognitive outcomes including Alzheimer’s disease neuropathology. We will also examine whether we can predict long-term exercise engagement by utilizing the rich biological and psychological data from IGNITE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Valvuloseptal defects account for the majority of congenital heart defects, which are the most common human birth defect. Down Syndrome, involving trisomy of chromosome 21 affects 1 in 700 live births and causes valvuloseptal heart defects. We will investigate the molecular mechanisms that cause valvuloseptal defects in mouse and human models, including models of Down Syndrome, to understand the sets of genes that when improperly regulated cause syndromic and non-syndromic heart defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementia are a leading cause of death and disability in the aging population, affecting approximately 6.2 million people aged 65 and older each year in the United States alone. The ability to non-invasively detect the earliest changes in AD progression is a critical and unmet need that will help advance the treatment time window for the most effective interventions. This project aims to develop a novel Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) approach to probe brain microstructural changes as an early marker of AD progression, which will further provide new insights into AD pathogenesis and lead to timely intervention strategies to prevent and/or slow down AD onset and/or progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to develop a new molecular strategy to create a favorable retinal environment for cell survival, vascular repair and revascularization of ischemic retina in retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). Sigma 1 receptor, a unique pluripotent cell survival protein, shows a novel promising vascular protection, providing a bi-functional (vascular and neuronal) therapeutic potential for ROP. The proposed studies are designed to use Sig1R deficient cells and mice to evaluate its retinal cell-type specific role, particularly vascular-immune interactive effects in rescuing neurovascular injury characteristic of ROP and to define the underlying mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Flask-shaped structures found on the surface of many types of cells known as caveolae are important regulators of human physiology. Despite this, we lack a clear understanding of how caveolae are assembled and function at a cellular level, or how defects in caveolae contribute to disease. Our proposed studies will exploit our recently determined three-dimensional structure of the major structural protein of caveolae to answer these questions using a combination of computational and experimental approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Studies on T cell development provide direct insights into the pathophysiology of a wide variety of diseases, such as malignancies, immunodeficiency disorders, and autoimmune diseases. However, our understanding of the epigenetic regulation of lymphoid development, especially the T cell fate commitment from hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSPCs), is incomplete. The goal of this project is to discover key epigenetic regulatory mechanisms underlying T cell development and explore new strategies to facilitate stem cell-based adoptive T cell therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in the Clarin-1 (CLRN1) gene cause Usher syndrome type 3 (USH3), a devastating orphan disease leading to combined blindness and deafness in humans. There is no treatment currently available to prevent vision loss and patients are legally blind by the fourth decade of life. This project uses newly developed pig and zebrafish models of USH3 to provide fundamental knowledge on USH3 disease pathology, and accelerate the development and validation of treatments to prevent blindness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This research will apply and compare machine-learning methods to derive plasma proteomic signatures of physical activity and examine them in relation to ADRD, yielding insight into the molecular mechanisms and biological processes through which physical activity may delay or prevent ADRD. This research may result in proteomic biomarkers of physical activity that measure the effect of physical activity to delay or prevent ADRD and suggest potential proteomic intervention targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Platelets are blood elements that are important in stopping bleeding, but they also contribute to the development of blood clots leading to heart attacks and strokes. Platelets stabilize clots by pulling them together by a mechanism termed clot retraction. The proposed studies will study how platelets produce clot retraction with the goal of obtaining information that may lead to the development of new drugs to treat or prevent heart attacks or strokes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Currently, Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is irreversible and becoming a large and growing public health crisis with over 6.5 million Americans affected, costing over $320 billion per year for AD and related dementias (AD/ADRD). New intervention strategies targeting brain metabolism are emerging to treat and/or prevent AD, thus, it is critical to develop a robust precision mapping of cortical and subcortical brain metabolic signatures to identify altered metabolic processes and brain dysfunction associated with AD pathology, with the use of state- of-the-art high-resolution whole-brain metabolic imaging techniques with enhanced sensitivity that can detect aberrant brain metabolism and evaluate the efficacy of new interventions. This project will also generate population-based metabolic atlases of the aging population, which will enable us to identify patterns of regional metabolic abnormalities and the effect of treatment strategies targeting metabolic processes to prevent or treat AD/ADRD as well as a variety of neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our long-term goal is to eliminate racial disparities in chronic kidney disease progression, treatment, and care among patients within Emory Healthcare, the state’s largest healthcare system, by developing a model of care that can be replicated and sustained within health systems across the country. In the development, implementation, evaluation, and dissemination of multi-component, multi-level interventions that mitigate the impact of structural racism on healthcare delivery we will rely heavily on a community-engaged approach at all stages of implementation to maximize the impact of these interventions on patients, providers, and treatment settings. Doing so is expected to have an important positive impact on the field of public health and the mission of NIDDK through the generation of health, organizational, and implementation outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Recent major breakthroughs have allowed researchers to use a simple blood test to accurately determine whether a person has Alzheimer's disease, but this method needs to be tested in real-life clinical settings before it can be widely adopted. We will administer these blood tests in two real-life clinical settings (a memory clinic and a general primary care sample, 800 people each) and test i) how well the blood tests diagnose Alzheimer's compared to existing expensive and invasive tools; ii) whether patient management changes based on the blood test results; and iii) whether we can use blood tests and brief cognitive digital tests to predict who will show future cognitive decline. At the end of this project, we expect that our results will allow us and – importantly – others to implement these Alzheimer's disease blood tests in real-life clinical settings worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with HIV have a heightened coronary artery disease (CAD) risk even after controlling for traditional cardiovascular (CV) risk factors. The proposed study will assess the unique relation of coronary inflammation, measured as pericoronary adipose tissue density on cardiac computed tomography (CT), to coronary plaque development in relationship to other CAD risk factors, the effects of statins on coronary inflammation in relation to changes in plaque volume, and the relationship to major adverse CV events. We will accomplish our objectives by leveraging data from the Randomized Trial to Prevent Vascular Events in HIV (REPRIEVE) CT mechanistic substudy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolic reprogramming is required in colorectal cancer to maintain cellular plasticity and to thrive in the anoxic lumen. There is a strong body of research that coordinated inter-organellar interactions of endoplasmic reticulum-mitochondria are essential for compartmentalized metabolism. The proposed research will fill a major gap in the fundamental understanding of the mechanisms in which endoplasmic reticulum-mitochondria drive colon cancer metabolism and cell fate dynamics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite >25% of Americans with inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) being ≥65 years, <1% are included in clinical trials of IBD medications, resulting in a lack of robust data on safety and efficacy of these medications in older adults. Immunosuppression, associated with substantial risks and benefits that may be amplified at older ages, is the mainstay of modern IBD treatment; however, we have no tools to tailor treatments for older adults. This proposal seeks to study the impact of geriatric constructs of frailty and function as adverse event risk mediators after immunosuppressive treatments for IBD and generate a risk prediction model that can expand treatment options for the heterogeneous population of older adults with IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Pulmonary hypertension, the state of having high blood pressure in the lungs, affects more than 1.5 million U.S. adults, is more common with age, and causes significant respiratory symptoms and a higher risk of death. In a large portion of patients, pulmonary hypertension is the result of underlying chronic lung disease, and unfortunately, no direct treatment is available. This research project will evaluate metabolic abnormalities as an underlying and treatable cause of pulmonary hypertension in patients with chronic lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study is relevant to public health because it focuses on testing a novel adapted evidence-based multilevel intervention, D-THIO: Deprescribing Thyroid Hormone In Older Adults, to support thyroid hormone deprescribing (dose de-escalation and/or discontinuation) in older adults with thyroid hormone overtreatment and/or misuse and reduce patient harm. Findings from this study will lay the groundwork for broad implementation of D-THIO and serve as a model for deprescribing inappropriate medications for other endocrine conditions and conditions with biochemical monitoring. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to de-implementing low-value care in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this proposal is to establish and translate novel noninvasive imaging methods and blood markers prognostic of impaired wound healing in the setting of diabetic foot ulcers (DFU). We will benchmark the sensitivity, specificity, and repeatability of MRI-derived foot perfusion markers and systemic and local metabolic markers of poor wound healing in DFU and examine multiparametric classification models to predict wound healing outcomes in DFU patients receiving standard of care. We expect this work to provide novel information for more effective treatment strategies and lead to improved clinical management of DFU.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  The rapid increase in the number of older adult drivers (OAD’s), and the overrepresentation of OAD’s in motor vehicle crashes and injuries, has heightened the need for products which improve roadway safety in this population. This phase 1 SBIR proposal focuses on the feasibility and usability of a novel driving coach app (StreetCoach) to improve driving performance in OAD’s with and without Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementia (ADRD), and/or cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chromatin, a nuclear entity in a cell, can be abnormally shuttled to the cytoplasm during aging, leading to inflammation. This proposal studies how fragments of chromatin are shuttled from the nucleus to the cytoplasm, and how to block this pro-inflammatory process via metabolic changes. This study will offer novel insights into age-associated inflammation, with potential to develop new strategies to suppress chronic inflammation and to promote healthy aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it provides evidence on the extent to which the transportation benefit in the Medicaid program — which currently insures over 84 million low-income individuals in the United States — is associate with racial/ethnic disparities in health care access and outcomes. It will generate important information on steps state and federal policymakers can take to use the transportation benefit to improve health equity. The proposed research is relevant to NIMHD’s mission as it pertains to generating knowledge that contributes to improving minority health and reducing health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative End-stage renal disease afflicts Black persons disproportionately more than other races/ethnicity and although kidney transplantation provides the best outcomes for patients, Black patients with end-stage renal disease are less likely referred for kidney transplant evaluation, less likely listed for kidney transplantation, and less likely to receive a kidney transplantation. Structural racism is a fundamental cause of racial disparity in health outcomes for Black patients with end-stage renal disease and to this end - rooted in the Black experience - Dr. Simpson together with the Black community created the first African American Transplant Access Program {AATAP) in the country at a large transplant center in the heart of diverse Chicago. This grant proposes (i) to study the impact of AATAP on patients and transplant metrics (e.g., listing rates), (ii) to increase awareness and structural competency among transplant gatekeepers {clinicians, staff) and {iii) to demonstrate generalizability by adapting the AATAP program to another large kidney transplant program in Florida.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The essential human enzyme O-GlcNAc transferase (OGT) dynamically regulates a variety of physiological and pathological processes including the “Warburg effect” in cancer cells and insulin resistance in diabetes. This proposed research will elucidate how OGT interacts with other proteins, which will be essential for understanding OGT’s functional regulation in nutrient sensing and other important roles and will support the need to specifically modulate OGT functions for biomedical applications.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - STARTUP CENTRAL Continuum Educational Technologies will collaborate with the University of Kansas and other Central Region IDeA State universities to develop an integrated suite of entrepreneurial education products to help university bioscience researchers commercialize their discoveries and bring critical biomedical innovations to market. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative  Early detection of pancreatic cancer is one of the foremost priorities of the NCI. The overarching goal of this F99/K00 proposal is to develop the capability of non-invasively detecting advanced pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN) precursor lesions in pancreas prior to invasive disease using two magnetic resonance imaging based tools: a) hyperpolarized metabolic imaging (HP MRI) and b) acidoCEST MRI and test the efficacy of immunoprevention in animal models employing these techniqies. The success of this proposal has the potential for leading to practice changing recommendations for non-invasively detecting and monitoring advanced PanIN lesions and incipient pancreatic cancer, as well as to prevent over-diagnosis and over-treatment in cysts that harbor indolent biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Spinocerebellar ataxia type 1 (SCA1) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease, whereby individuals gradually develop incoordination, which progresses to being weak, short of breath, and culminating in premature death. This proposal aims to understand which brain cells are responsible for the premature death and what molecular changes within them lead up to their degeneration. Understanding these details are important for developing effective treatments for patients with SCA1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The lack of definitive evidence (prospective randomized or retrospective observational) to support (or refute) the use of intraoperative transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) during isolated coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery has led to widespread practice pattern variability and a near 50/50 split in TEE (vs no TEE) intraoperatively – an evidence gap with clinical equipoise. This study aims to leverage this existing practice pattern variability and clinical equipoise to generate the required foundational data necessary to inform a future, multicenter randomized controlled trial (RCT) that could resolve questions surrounding the efficacy, effectiveness, and risk-benefit ratio of intraoperative TEE during isolated CABG surgery. These findings will be critically important for health policy efforts to reduce variability, standardize intraoperative care, and improve perioperative outcomes among cardiac surgery patients undergoing isolated CABG surgery.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The causes of approximately half of stillbirth cases are unknown. Novel genetic analysis techniques applied in a unique data source with families and large pedigrees allow identification of previously unrecognized causes of stillbirth. The results will improve risk stratification for stillbirth, identify novel therapeutic targets, facilitate closure and bereavement for grieving families, and improve subsequent perinatal outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Leptin-sensitive neurons within the hypothalamus, including AgRP neurons, play a dominant role in regulating appetite, and until recently we did not have the tools needed to study the transcriptional regulatory processes that govern their activity during the development of obesity. This project will utilize cutting-edge cell-type specific genomic profiling techniques to study a newly identified transcription factor, Interferon Regulatory Factor 3 (IRF3) in leptin-sensitive neurons, including, AgRP neurons (IRF3AgRP) that is both regulated for acute leptin sensitivity and is potentially disrupted during states of hyperleptinemic diet-induced obesity. The transcriptional pathway investigated in this project will aid the discovery of novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the second leading cause of cancer-related deaths in the United States; altered cellular metabolism drives tumorigenesis and progression and promotes resistance to immune checkpoint blockade. Our proposed study will define the metabolic adaptations associated with decreased ketogenesis and will significantly improve the efficacy of immunotherapy for advanced CRC by targeting the dysregulated ketogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) is a type of heart failure with increasing prevalence in older adults in the US. Diagnosis of this type of heart failure is complex and it often remains unrecognized in primary care. In this proposal we aim to develop and pilot test a clinical diagnostic decision support aide, specifically designed for primary care providers to diagnose HFpEF. The ultimate long-term goal is to develop aides for clinicians to use that can improve the diagnosis, and therefore, health outcomes of patients with HFpEF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Herbal medicines and dietary supplements are severely under characterized compared to over-the-counter medicines. This creates a critical need for natural product scientists trained in pharmacognosy and drug pharmacokinetics. This project addresses this need through research training focused on metabolic products of antiviral compounds of Elderberry (Sambucus nigra L.) to better understand their anti-influenza activities.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research aims of the K99/R00 proposal will provide support for a novel pathway of intergenerational trauma through newborn amygdala network connectivity programmed in utero influencing infant emotion regulation problems that may in turn lead to less optimal mother-infant interactions (e.g., disorganized attachment), and result in increased risk for psychopathology across generations. The Award will add to the applicants’ background in perinatal psychology and developmental psychopathology to include needed training in newborn brain imaging, which will enable them to carry out their proposed research and help launch their independent career studying novel pathways of intergenerational trauma through in utero programming – leading to altered early brain-behavior and increased risk for psychopathology – informing critical malleable windows for early intervention. The applicant will obtain training in newborn functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), laboratory observational assessment of infant emotion regulation problems and parenting sensitivity, theory and science of intergenerational trauma, and biostatistics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure, imposing a major healthcare and economic strain worldwide. Standardization for an easy-to-use and reliable biomarker-based diagnosis of AD is lacking, resulting in invasive, high-cost tests of variable accuracy that may put the patient at risk. Thus, there is a significant need to develop highly accurate, sensitive, and minimally invasive diagnostic methods to promote improved treatment strategies and standardize AD diagnosis. The proposed project aims to create a liquid biopsy platform for AD that is capable of fully automated, rapid, precise exosome isolation and ultrasensitive, accurate exosome analysis from blood/plasma, realizing a point-of-care platform for early-stage AD diagnostics and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Retroviruses must integrate into their host’s genome to cause a variety of devastating diseases including AIDS (HIV-1) and leukemia (HTLV-1). Integration is catalyzed by a complex between the viral integrase (IN) protein and the viral cDNA (termed an intasome), that for HIV-1 assembles with 12-16 IN subunits. The goal of this proposal is to quantitatively determine the biophysical rules that guide HIV-1 intasome assembly progressions as well as the effect of HIV-1 IN-multimer architecture on host genome integration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: People with serious mental illness SMI comprise five percent of the US population and experience one of the largest cardiovascular disease-related mortality disparities of any group with rates two times higher, and dying 10-20 years earlier, than the general population. Widespread scale-up of evidence-based interventions to reduce cardiovascular disease risk in the population with serious mental illness is needed to address the significant disparities in lifespan experienced by this group. This proposed study leverages national expertise in cardiovascular risk reduction interventions, implementation science, and community and State policymaking to enhance uptake of evidence-based interventions to prevent cardiovascular disease among persons with serious mental illness, through strong community partnerships that are enhanced using novel implementation science strategies.

Findings will help identify potential risk factors and mechanisms that may serve as targets for preventing STBs earlier in development before the adolescent period. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Though cardiac arrest is common, with an estimated 250-350,000 out-of-hospital and 250-750,000 in-hospital events occurring in the U.S. each year, survival rates remain at only 5-20% and many survivors suffer severe brain injury. Developing interventions to reduce brain injuries among survivors of cardiac arrest is essential in order to improve neurological outcomes and patient survival. This planning grant aims to collect information that will help to design a multi-site clinical trial to determine whether the administration of magnesium following an in- hospital cardiac arrest event is feasible and safe and if it improves survival and neurological outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: This project aims to determine the principles by which neuronal populations communicate with each other across multiple brain areas. The misregulation of inter-areal signaling is thought to be central in psychiatric  disorders like schizophrenia and autism. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Studies have shown that early life exposures can influence neurodevelopment, and gut microbiome composition and function, however, studies linking early life environmental metal exposure to the gut microbiome in childhood, and their combined associations with neurodevelopment are lacking. The proposed research will investigate these associations and their timing by integrating early life measures of metal exposure, detailed analysis of the gut microbiome and metabolome, and behavioral and biological measurements of neurodevelopment. Filling these knowledge gaps will provide information to better inform future interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Dysphagia (swallowing impairment) is a serious health condition seen in many age-related disease and injury processes. Although videofluoroscopy (VF) is an international “gold standard” dysphagia diagnostic exam, there is a paucity of available normative physiologic VF reference values in healthy adults across the age span to guide interpretation of these examinations. We propose to extend our prior work on the quantitative measurement of swallowing physiology from VF examinations to establish reference values for swallowing in healthy adults, and to identify clinical decision point values for differentiating healthy swallowing across the age span from disordered swallowing in several high-risk clinical populations to study dysphagia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the context of shrinking family size and growing complexity and diversity of family and household structures, characterizing the full scope of informal caregiving, such as who provides caregiving to the person with dementia, what caregiving roles are played by the multiple members of these networks, and how the various members are socially connected, will be required to inform responsive public health approaches and policies to support the growing community of caregivers, and to improve healthcare and social services for persons with dementia. The proposed work is to develop CareNet, a digital caregiving network assessment tool, that will be easily deployed by providers and researchers to fully characterize the caregiving network of a person with dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE  Trauma and shock activate pathways of inflammation that can lead to organ failure and death. The mechanisms of activation of inflammation in different organs and cell-types is not well understood, but knowing how cell, tissues and organs respond to shock may improve our future ability to prevent and treat organ failure in trauma patients. Our research investigates effects of activation of an inflammatory protein, caspase-11, on organ damage and inflammation during shock, and investigates inhibition of caspase-4/11 as a treatment approach to prevent organ failure in severely injured patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative While RNA splicing is a necessary part of proper cellular function in humans, errors in RNA splicing can lead to a large number of human diseases. It is estimated that nearly 50% of genetic mutations associated with human diseases including cardiomyopathies, early onset Parkinson's Disease, and various cancers involve splicing errors. In this project, I propose to determine molecular-level events that guide the selection of splice sites, thereby facilitating the development of treatments for splicing-related diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: This K99/R00 proposal will investigate early developmental determinants and pathways in Down syndrome. We will characterize the developmental dynamics between early phenotypic impairments in motor and attention during infancy and examine their mutual or distinct role in communication and cognitive outcomes using a multimethod biobehavioral approach. Results from these studies will constitute advanced phenotyping approaches to better understand the developmental complexity in Down syndrome.

PHR: AIHEC BIRCH Overall Core Project Narrative Each component of the AIHEC BIRCH project is designed to significantly advance Tribal College and University (TCU) efforts to strengthen education and research partnerships that will enable American Indian and Alaska Native (AIAN) students, Tribes, and tribal communities to address Native health disparities, thereby furthering NIH’s mission to address health disparities. The project expands health sciences career pathways for AIAN students, providing professional development opportunities for TCU faculty to engage in Indigenous health research, and conducting vital AIAN health research. Through our intentional partnerships, effective AIAN community-based research and intervention methodologies will be developed, tested, adapted to the unique cultural and place-based context of tribes and communities, and disseminated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The vision of the American Indian Higher Education Consortium’s (AIHEC) “Building Indigenous Research Capacity in Health” (BIRCH) project is sovereign Tribal Nations asserting full ownership, direction, and control of the health research needed to help their people grow healthy and strong. Implementing new programs in the 37 TCUs across the country, AIHEC will provide additional resources for American Indian and Alaska Native (AIAN) students to pursue coursework and careers that will enable them to act as healthcare providers and researchers. This project provides a comprehensive approach to growing a networked community of AIAN and non-Native researchers, educators, and community practitioners to implement traditional knowledge practices in addressing AIAN health issues and continuously improve Native health and health research practices and outcomes. The lack of tribal healthcare researchers and providers perpetuates health disparities and a lack of equity in tribal communities. Furthermore, studies show that communities with tribal healthcare providers and researchers have a higher treatment adherence and fewer mortalities or serious illnesses. Promoting the advancement of AIAN students will not only benefit the students. Still, it will also lead to healthier tribal communities, increased compliance with healthcare visits and interventions, participation in clinical trials, and a reduction in the primary causes of illness and mortality such as diabetes, substance use disorders, injuries, homicide, and suicide. The long-term goals of the project are: To expand a community of Indigenous research practice in health/health sciences at the nation’s TCUs; to establish TCUs as essential tribally-centered components of the national health sciences research and education infrastructure; to improve the quality of health services provided to AIANs using a science-based empirical approach to intervention development and evaluation that is relevant to Native peoples and communities and based on core tribal values, cultures, and traditions; to expand the TCU component of the health research and education career pipeline to recruit, support, and provide critical linkages for AIAN students to pursue health careers; to empower tribes and tribal communities to develop and control their research agenda and connect that research to tribal values and needs, and to promote the integration of Indigenous knowledge and Western knowledge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diseases result when the internal stability and normal communications within and among biological pathways are disrupted by genetic defects, environmental disturbances, or pathogens. The Nebraska Center for Integrated Biomolecular Communication (CIBC) integrates the research activities of chemists, biochemists, engineers, and bioinformaticians to address critical knowledge gaps in our understanding of how cells communicate and integrate metabolic and regulatory pathways relevant to complex disease development and progression. CIBC investigators will continue to bring together unique expertise in the understanding of complex diseases and in the development of novel methodologies and technologies to probe communication pathways. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders (FASD) and is estimated to occur in up to 5% of live births per year in the US and is characterized by physical, cognitive and behavioral impairments. The proposed study seeks to examine novel molecular mechanisms through which prenatal alcohol exposure might cause craniofacial and brain abnormalities. These experiments are important for our understanding of how prenatal alcohol exposure causes birth defects in the human population and will aid in the identification of potential therapeutic targets for the treatment of FASD.

PHR: Project Narrative  Mapping the complex wiring between neurons can help us understand how brain circuits work a fundamental level, but is not possible with current imaging technologies. In this project, we will develop a synchrotron-based X-ray imaging approach that has the potential to enable rapid brain-wide circuit mapping. This new imaging technology will contribute to a mechanistic understanding of human cognition and the development of cures for psychiatric diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Calcium signaling helps maintain normal cellular functions, but pathogens, including intestinal viruses like rotavirus, reprogram normal cellular calcium pathways to commandeer cellular machinery for their replication, which results in potentially life-threatening diseases like diarrhea. We recently discovered that rotavirus infection triggers long-distance signaling that also increases calcium in surrounding uninfected cells in the gut. This proposal investigates how this long-distance calcium signal is involved in host responses to rotavirus- induced damage but also exploited by rotavirus to increase its replication and spread.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE In low-resource settings, high rates of perinatal mortality are due in part to challenges accessing affordable technologies to screen and monitor high-risk maternal-fetal conditions, such as intrauterine growth restriction and preeclampsia. To address these issues, we will use artificial intelligence to develop techniques for predicting intrauterine growth restriction and preeclampsia from low-cost hand-held maternal and fetal Doppler recordings. This will represent a major step forward in affordable and scalable technology for pregnancy monitoring in low-resource settings around the globe.

PHR: Narrative Racial and ethnic health disparities in the US have been made worse by COVID19, thus, increasing its awareness and its need to be addressed. The role of HBCUs in addressing and being represented in the community has proven to be essential to the resolution of these disparities. PHR: Project Narrative – Project 1 Black women suffer disproportionately from breast cancer mortality, with social, environmental and biological causes. We propose to identify mechanisms by which metastatic breast carcinomas tend to be more common in Black women, focusing on cell-cell interactions between the cells that surround the tumor and the tumor itself. This research will provide a basis for developing new methods for targeting these aggressive breast cancers.

PHR: Narrative Racial and ethnic health disparities in the US have been made worse by COVID19, thus, increasing its awareness and its need to be addressed. The role of HBCUs in addressing and being represented in the community has proven to be essential to the resolution of these disparities. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection is a global public health burden that affects approximately 300 million individuals worldwide, and there is consensus in the field that having better small animal models to study HBV immunopathogenesis would speed the development of curative therapies. The goal of this proposed research is to leverage host and viral diversity to breach the species barrier for HBV infection in murine hepatocytes. These efforts will yield new insights into HBV tropism and facilitate the development of immunocompetent, HBV- susceptible animal models for chronic hepatitis B.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE COPD is a common and preventable chronic lung disease, and real-time remote monitoring is necessary to provide individualized care to patients with COPD for seamless long-term care and more cost-effective efforts. Our company is developing a novel product that can revolutionize healthcare for COPD patients by presenting new opportunities for clinicians to care for their patients and reduce hospital readmission while permitting users to monitor respiratory well-being and change behaviors to have immediate health benefits. The proposed technology creates a fully wireless and intelligent wearable sensor for passive monitoring, prompt data access, and alert for daily emergency assessments and medication adjustment, as a result helping maximize patient outcomes while reducing healthcare costs for COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Women are disproportionally affected by Alzheimer's disease and Alzheimer's disease-related dementias (AD/ADRD) with approximately two-thirds of individuals diagnosed with this condition being women, women being less likely to receive annual blood pressure and weight monitoring, and women more likely to experience delayed initiation of anti-dementia medication than men. The way in which physicians treat female persons with AD/ADRD has important implications on sex and gender disparities in AD/ADRD care quality and outcomes, but the effects of patient-physician gender concordance, physician training diversity, and health system board diversity on sex and gender disparities in AD/ADRD care have not yet been investigated. Using the nationally-representative data with detailed information on patients, physicians, medical schools, residency programs, and health systems, the proposed study will clarify how these physician-level and health system-level factors affect sex and gender disparities in AD/ADRD care, and provide new evidence to develop interventions aimed at eliminating those disparities, such as increasing female representation in physician workforce, introducing sex and gender sensitivity in medical education, and promoting sex and gender diversity in health system boards.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Contemporary treatments for hyperfunctional voice disorders such as muscle tension dysphonia (MTD) are effective but typically do not restore voice handicap or voice function to normal thresholds. Recent reports of vibration as a voice therapy modality have been published, but many questions remain about the efficacy of this tool. The current project addresses these problems through a blinded and randomized controlled trial to investigate the efficacy of local translaryngeal vibration for MTD and the dose-response relationship of this modality when compared to treatment without vibration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection affects more than 296 million people globally and approximately 820,000 people die each year from HBV infection and related complications such as cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). One of the major impediments in developing a cure for HBV is the lack of immunocompetent animal models permissive to HBV infection. The goal of this project is to develop a novel hamster model to support the development of new therapies to cure HBV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative A NIOSH grant renewal will enable Fishing Partnership Support Services (FPSS) to enhance and expand safety training for Mid-Atlantic commercial fishermen, including immigrant workers and those new to fishing, with the goal of reducing the rates of injuries and death resulting from fishing vessel disasters and other dangers. FPSS will offer 18 training sessions in the hands-on courses of Safety & Survival Training and Drill Conductor Certification. FPSS will also promote a culture of safety across the commercial fishing industry by training new safety instructors; by reaching out to fishermen in remote locations and offering safety training within their communities; and by promoting outreach and communication between fishermen themselves about the potentially life-saving impact of safety training.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Community-Based Safety Training for the Mid-Atlantic Fishing Industry

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative A NIOSH grant will enable Fishing Partnership Support Services (FPSS) to continue to enhance and expand safety training for New England commercial fishermen, including immigrant workers and those new to fishing, with the goal of reducing the rates of injuries and death resulting from fishing vessel disasters and other dangers. FPSS will offer 30 training sessions where fishermen will complete hands-on courses including Safety & Survival Training, and Drill Conductor Training and Certification. FPSS will also promote a culture of safety across the commercial fishing industry by training new safety instructors; by reaching out to fishermen in remote locations and offering safety training within their communities; and by promoting outreach and communication between fishermen themselves about the potentially life-saving impact of safety training.

PROJECT_TITLE: Community-Based Safety Training for the New England Fishing Industry

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Few treatments target core features of suicidal thoughts and behaviors in Veterans. In the proposed SPiRE study we will determine the acceptability and feasibility of using real-time functional magnetic resonance imaging neurofeedback for reducing suicide-specific rumination, defined as a “repetitive mental fixation on one's suicidal thoughts and intentions” in a transdiagnostic sample of Veterans at elevated risk of suicide. Veterans will learn strategies for modulating activity within brain regions comprising the default mode network, which has been demonstrated to contribute to the maintenance of rumination, as they receive feedback signals from the brain. These data will be used to guide a future randomized double-blind, placebo-controlled study to test the efficacy of real-time functional magnetic resonance imaging neurofeedback as a first-line treatment intervention for reducing suicide-specific rumination in Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE FROM PARENT GRANT This research will provide definitive evidence about whether treating prenatal insomnia with digital cognitive behavior therapy for insomnia prevents depression during the perinatal period (i.e., pregnancy and the postpartum period). Currently, there are few intervention options for preventing perinatal depression, none focus on women with prenatal insomnia, and the accessibility of existing interventions is limited. Several attributes of our approach will facilitate its broad dissemination, including focusing on the low stigma target of insomnia and using a scalable intervention, with significant public health impact for reducing the burden of perinatal depression for mothers, children, families, and society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to develop a common data analysis medium—BRC.analytics—that would connect infectious disease researchers to data, tools, and workflows. The transformative tenets of the proposed system are: (1) giving access to an ensemble of data resources via a single workspace where data can be stored, combined, and analyzed; (2) enabling access to the majority of high quality open source tools and allow creation of complex workflows in the workspace; (3) ensuring that workspace in powered by powerful hardware capable of sustaining thousands of users analyzing large datasets; (4) providing several modes of access including a graphical user interface (GUI) as well as an Application Programming Interface (API). BRC.analytics will be a new type of knowledgebase that provides data, tools, and infrastructure as well as the “know-how” on applying this power effectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We recently discovered that a key blood clot lysis protein, tissue-type plasminogen activator (tPA), in hepatocytes limits the production of apoB-lipoproteins in mice and cultured primary hepatocytes. The overarching goal of the Parent R01 proposal is to explore the underlying mechanisms by which hepatocyte tPA lowers plasma apoB- containing lipoprotein-cholesterol levels. In this supplement award, Ms. Maya Rodriguez proposes to investigate the potential mechanism by which tPA and PAI1 regulate lipid metabolism with the impact from immunological stimuli as a logical extension to the Aim 3 of the parent R01.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The aim of this project is to advance HPX-612, the first orally available immunotherapy that activates the innate immune system, for the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis. Visceral leishmaniasis, caused by the parasite  Leishmania, is prevalent in low- and middle-income countries, and current treatment options such as liposomal  amphotericin, pentavalent antimonials, and miltefosine are associated with significant toxicity and long treatment  duration, often requiring hospitalization. As a result, up to 400,000 individuals annually experience significant  morbidity and mortality. Herein this proposal, HPX-612 will be evaluated for efficacy in leishmaniasis, including  its pharmacokinetics and optimal dosing, before launching into rigorous pre-clinical development program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Currently, pure pharmaceutical grade cannabinoids are purified from plant-derived extracts through complex, unstandardized, and high-cost purification techniques. As interest in utilizing cannabinoids as active pharmaceutical ingredients grows, and subsequently the number of trials using cannabinoids increases, heavy strain is put on cannabinoid supply chains. Cellibre is developing a microbial engineering and biofactory platform for sustainable, scalable, and cost-effective production of pharmaceutical grade cannabinoids and related compounds to eliminate the primary pain points currently associated with plant-based cannabinoid production, reducing the costs of manufacturing and purification by 5–10X, increasing access to minor cannabinoids and analogs for pharmaceutical studies, reducing competition with food crops and environmental impacts, and resulting in a smaller manufacturing footprint.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Central venous catheters provide lifesaving therapy to millions of patients every year; however, thrombosis and infection complications are high and associated with device failure, increased healthcare costs, patient morbidity, and mortality. Our novel approach is to combine antifouling and antimicrobial killing functionalities into a new polymer additive product (HaloAddTM) that catheter manufacturers can blend with thermoplastic polyurethane to prevent catheter-associated infections and thrombosis. This cost-effective and simple approach will have a meaningful impact on the safety and quality of life of patients who require a catheter by minimizing complications without using systemic anticoagulation and antibiotic treatments that will greatly decrease healthcare costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Ciguatera poisoning (CP) is a form of seafood poisoning that affects tens of thousands of people on an annual basis and is expected to increase with climate change impacts. The Greater Caribbean Center for Ciguatera Research (GCCCR) was established to study the anticipated intensification of CP in the Greater Caribbean Region due to warming sea surface temperatures and reef degradation associated with climate change. Hurricane Ian caused severe damage to the Florida Gulf Coast University Vester Field Station, hindering progress and forming the basis for our request for an Administrative Supplement for the GCCCR project through this funding mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The use of in vivo imaging approaches paired with genetically encoded sensors and actuators (e.g., calcium imaging, optogenetics, and others) to study visual function has led to fundamental discoveries in visual neuroscience, but also has tremendous potential to transform pre-clinical development of therapies and treatment of blinding diseases. The 33rd Symposium of the Center for Visual Science brings together a diverse array of scholars who are leaders in these state-of-the-art methods to study and manipulate visual function in the eye and brain at unprecedented resolution and scale. The meeting will provide a forum to discuss recent discoveries, and foster new collaborations between technology developers, neuroscientists and clinicians at all career stages with an emphasis on large animal models and translation.

PHR: Project narrative:  We propose to develop molecular diagnostic tools (TaqMan Array Card platform and POCT CRISPR) for centralized and decentralized laboratories and establish a genetic analysis platform (Short-read and Long-read sequencing), bioinformatic pipelines, and microbial genomic database to facilitate genomic surveillance of respiratory viruses, arboviruses, bacterial STIs, and nosocomial bacterial pathogens, including antimicrobial resistance. These multi-level tools and systems will facilitate early detection and rapid response to EIDs and AMR across different levels of government and local communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: This high risk / high reward exploratory R21 project will make breakthroughs in understanding chemical- induced occupational allergy (asthma, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, skin disease). We will identify small molecules (peptides) that mimic the structure of chemical allergens by combining cutting edge technology with unique reagents generated in our laboratory. The results and newly identified chemical allergen mimics (mimotopes) will lead to new diagnostics, surveillance approaches, and potential therapies.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Discovering epitope mimics (mimitopes) of chemical allergens that cause occupational asthma

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Occupational hearing loss (HL) is a burden in regards to health care cost, worker performance, and quality of life. Hearing protection can prevent hearing loss, but workers often choose not to wear it because of listening difficulties that arise while wearing. This project will measure these difficulties, their impact on choice to wear HPDs, and test an auditory training approach to alleviating them.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Listening while wearing hearing protection: performance dynamics, choice to wear, and impacts of training

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: A novel passive sampler to assess personal exposures to airborne biological agents A novel Personal Rutgers Electrostatic Passive Sampler (P-REPS) will be developed and tested to assess personal exposures to bioaerosols in occupational environments. P-REPS will consist of a permanently polarized polymer film wound into a spiral and a 3D-printed film holder. The new sampler will advance our capabilities to determine exposures to biological aerosols, especially due to its pump-less operation and long sampling time frames.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: A novel passive sampler to assess personal exposures to airborne biological agents
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women have been deterred from working in the skilled trades, partially due to the challenging physical, social and organizational work environment, which highlights the need to study this vulnerable, disproportionately at- risk population and better understand the challenges that jeopardize skilled tradeswomen’s safety, health, and well-being. Although fostering equitable gender representation, diversity, fairness, and inclusion is essential for the skilled trades, few studies or publications have addressed the issue or explored strategies for improving working conditions for the purpose of enhancing opportunities for skilled tradeswomen. We will utilize the Sociotechnical Systems and Total Worker Health® approaches to assess the joint impact of factors impeding or enhancing tradeswomen’s safety, health, and well-being, identify needs and improvement strategies, and then disseminate the generated knowledge to key stakeholders and the public in support of a more equitable and diverse workforce in industries that rely on the skilled trades.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Building a Safe, Healthy, and Respectful Workplace for Tradeswomen: A Total Worker Health Approach.
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will provide the first evidence on racial and ethnic disparities in the economic consequences of injury by imputing race and ethnicity data to administrative data on injured workers from the California workers’ compensation system. By quantifying how a wide range of observed factors contribute to disparities in earnings and employment losses, our study will provide policymakers and researchers valuable information about how safety and disability prevention interventions could be targeted to have the greatest impact on inequity in the financial burden of occupational injury and illness. This research supports NIOSH’s objective of reducing disparities related to occupational injuries and illnesses.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Racial and Ethnic Disparities in the Economic Consequences of Occupational Injuries
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative: Veteran suicide death is a national crisis. Risk factors include emotion dysregulation, which occurs across mental health disorders. Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT) is an evidence-based suicide intervention that targets emotion dysregulation but is resource-intensive and not widely available at VHA. A more efficient evidence-based DBT Skills Group (DBT-SG) is associated with reduced suicidal ideation and emotion dysregulation and likely more feasible to implement at VHA. We propose a randomized controlled trial to test whether DBT-SG, compared to VHA treatment-as-usual, reduces Veteran suicide attempt, the first study of its kind at VHA. Before, during, and after the trial, we will assess stakeholder viewpoints about DBT-SG, including barriers to implementing DBT-SG and factors that might make it more feasible to use for Veterans, clinicians, and leadership. Study results will tell us (1) whether DBT-SG is more effective than usual VHA treatment for high-risk Veterans, and (2) how VHA can best implement DBT-SG to reduce suicide risk.
