PHR: NARRATIVE. The openly-shared NKI-Rockland Sample has provided a model for lifespan imaging studies and has led to more than two hundred publications to date. This competing renewal application will provide a comprehensive data resource to enrich and expand resources available for brain research and biomarker discovery across the lifespan. Construction of the proposed sample was organized around three main themes: 1) integration of advanced measures for brain and body, 2) real-world strategies for characterizing individuals, and 3) enhanced focus on the relationships between obesity and cardiovascular fitness on brain function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Protein Arginine Methyltransferase 5 (PRMT5) regulates gene transcription by methylating three of the four core histones. I will reveal how PRMT5 recognizes and modifies histones H2A and H4 using a combination of biochemical and structural techniques. Understanding the mechanism of PRMT5’s histone specificity will further insights into PRMT5’s role in gene expression and support ongoing efforts in structure-based drug design of PRMT5 inhibitors.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The time following discharge from psychiatric hospitalization is a high-risk period and has been associated with a range of negative outcomes including high rates of hospital readmission and suicide. The purpose of this proposal is to: 1) create a Peer Specialist facilitated intervention, called Recovery Bridge, designed to facilitate the transition from inpatient psychiatric hospitalization to community living; 2) examine feasibility, fidelity, and acceptability; and preliminarily explore the impact of the intervention on: a) readmission rates and connection to outpatient care compared to a control group identified from administrative data; and b) change in recovery and quality of life measures over time in the intervention participants. Results from the proposed open pilot trial will set the stage for next steps including a larger effectiveness trial followed by a possible hybrid-I effectiveness/implementation trial to inform future dissemination and implementation of the intervention more broadly across the VA.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: As part of comprehensive suicide prevention, VA integrated mental and physical health services to better detect and treat depression. Depression detection and management processes are complex, involve multilevel stakeholders, and subject to significant disruption from COVID-19 and from resulting expansion of telehealth aiming to preserve care access. To improve virtual and in-person services for the VA primary care population during recovery, this proposal will examine how the pandemic disrupted depression care delivery mechanisms and patient outcomes (e.g., psych hospitalizations, suicides). The pandemic provides an opportunity to engage multilevel stakeholders to improve upon VA’s management of depression and suicide prevention for the entire Veteran population. This proposed research will provide the basis for testable hypotheses (e.g., acceptable virtual depression treatments in primary care), and clinical recommendations (e.g., satisfactory virtual provider- to-provider handoffs for new patient referrals), to improve hybrid (virtual/in-person) VA depression services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The Endosomal Sorting Complex Required for Transport (ESCRT) machinery is known for its fundamental roles in remodeling cellular membranes to enable membrane protein degradation, HIV budding, and cell division. The work in this proposal builds on and extends our discovery that ESCRTs also stabilize and repair membranes throughout the endolysosomal network. Insight into how this machinery maintains compartmental membrane integrity has important implications for understanding inflammatory responses, pathogen invasion, and mechanisms underlying necrotic cell death.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (mTBI) is a major cause of morbidity in the Veteran population. Synapse alterations represent an underappreciated area in chronic TBI pathobiology. Based on our preliminary data, we hypothesize that (i) TBI can cause sustained down-regulation of protein complexes at the pre-synaptic terminal associated with diminished vesicular neurotransmitter release function, and that (ii) TBI can also destabilize post-synaptic density proteins leading to reduced functions of glutamate receptors. (iii) We propose to study both cortical impact and repeated closed-head injury–induced chronic synaptic damage and dysfunctions as facilitated using synaptosome preparations isolated from affected brain regions. (iv) We will also examine if oral treatment of a BBB-crossing antioxidant Mitoquinone (MitoQ) can mitigate post-TBI synaptic structural/functional deficits, restore synaptic mitochondrial function and improve chronic neurobehavioral outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Cystic fibrosis is a devastating genetic disease that involves multiple organ systems and leads to premature death; therapeutic advances have extended lifespans and improved quality of life, but patients still suffer from airway infections, in addition to CF-related diabetes, digestive complications, and inflammatory responses. Our Center catalyzes new research in preclinical drug development, gut disease and diabetes and changes in patient microbiomes. We believe that these phenomena are interconnected, and that parallel investigations, coupled by powerful new data-science strategies can find new therapeutic approaches for CF patients by understanding the complex underlying biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Damage to the mammalian retina through injury or disease causes irreversible vision loss, unlike in other vertebrates, which restore tissue function through Müller glia-based regeneration. I propose to overexpress a robust cell reprogramming factor, L-Myc, in murine Müller glia in retinal tissue to understand the capacity of these cells to change cell state in an injury model. The results of this study will provide insight on what genetic signals are sufficient to induce cell state changes in mammalian Müller glia, what signals are inhibitory to this process, and ultimately identify targets for future genetic therapies to restore vision after injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative With a focus on post-doctoral training, this proposal aims to advance a novel approach for the treatment of a highly aggressive form of lung cancer. In addition to enhancing the pool of highly trained physician-scientists, the results of this study will validate a novel approach to enhance cancer immunogenicity. This may be useful in treating many forms of cancer, thus improving public health and quality of life for patients.

PHR: Project Narrative:  Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) affect 1 in 60 children in the United States. Despite its prevalence, the aberrations in neuronal development that lead ASDs are not well understood. This study focuses on understanding how patient mutations in genes involved in translation result in ASDs and what cellular pathways are dysregulated as result of these mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the emerging link between air pollution exposure – specifically PM2.5 – and heighted risk of adolescent anxiety, the neurobehavioral mechanisms underlying this association are unknown. The proposed F32 project will be the first to evaluate whether exposure to recent PM2.5 concentrations is associated with poorer extinction recall, lower frontolimbic activation, and higher anxiety symptoms during adolescence, a period of frontolimbic development and psychiatric vulnerability. This project will be an important first step towards identifying mechanisms underlying environmental risk of psychopathology and will lay a critical foundation for early interventions to stem the etiology of anxiety in at-risk pollution-exposed youth.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: REHABILITATION INSTITUTE OF CHICAGO D/B/A SHIRLEY RYAN ABILITYLAB
PHR: Project Narrative Restoration of community mobility is a goal for most of the 7.2 million stroke survivors in the US, who experience chronic gait impairments due to spasticity, contractures, and muscle weakness. Available therapies that focus on stimulation of affected ipsilateral and contralateral areas of the brain are not effective in the long term. Noninvasive electrical stimulation of the spinal cord, in combination with symmetry-focused gait training, may facilitate short-term or long-term modulation of spinal circuitry to improve walking function, and thus health and quality of life, in persons with chronic stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative 90% of individuals with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) are women, but the mechanisms that underly this sex bias are poorly understood. Mounting evidence suggests that perturbed X chromosome inactivation (XCI) maintenance in lymphocytes may contribute to the development of female-biased autoimmune disease. This project aims to investigate genetic and epigenetic features of XCI in age-associated B cells, an important cell type in SLE pathogenesis, and to leverage a novel mouse model of B-cell specific disrupted XCI maintenance to determine how contributions from the X chromosome in B cells underly sex biased autoimmune disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The sex difference in the profile of extracellular bioactive lipids, which mediate the progression and resolution of inflammation, is linked to the sex-dependent differential cellular response, and incidence and severity of various diseases. Our proposal will investigate the sex differences during histamine-mediated ocular allergic inflammation in cellular response of conjunctival goblet cells and the differential profile of extracellular proinflammatory and specialized pro-resolving lipid mediators that are secreted via extracellular vesicles . Our study will provide new insights into the lipid-mediated ocular surface protection mechanism regulated by the conjunctiva, which has been consistently under-studied.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite widespread use of antiretroviral (ARV) therapy, approximately half of people living with HIV exhibit symptoms of HIV-Associated Neurocognitive disorder, a hallmark of which is the atrophy of white matter and the loss of myelin. We have previously demonstrated that select ARV drugs inhibit maturation and differentiation of oligodendrocytes, the cells responsible for myelination in the CNS. The proposed experiments aim to elucidate the role that stress granules play in the inhibition of maturation in ARV treated oligodendrocytes, so as to better understand the mechanisms of oligodendrocyte dysfunction as a prelude to designing therapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Autism spectrum disorders (ASDs) are associated with cognitive deficits in perception, social interaction, and communication, and recent evidence suggests that the disruption of GABAergic inhibitory function is a likely mechanism underlying ASDs. One major challenge in exploring GABAergic dysfunction is the diversity of inhibitory interneurons, which can be subdivided into distinct classes with different physiology, synaptic targets, and molecular markers, and thus, will each have a unique contribution to ASD symptoms. This proposal will disrupt the expression of an ASD-linked gene in parvalbumin-expressing inhibitory interneurons to gain mechanistic insights into how impaired parvalbumin interneuron dysfunction can contribute toward ASD symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unhealthy alcohol use negatively impacts the entire continuum of HIV prevention and treatment but is challenging to diagnose since self-report consistently under-represents actual alcohol consumption. This project will leverage existing samples and data from two seminal trials of injectable long-acting vs. oral antiretroviral therapy to evaluate the predictive power of an objective alcohol biomarker (PEth) for clinical outcomes in persons at risk for HIV, and persons with HIV with the highest potential to transmit to others. In parallel to establishing these relationships, a point-of-care test will be developed to measure PEth in the clinic, enabling real time interventions to reduce alcohol consumption and prevent acquiring or transmitting HIV.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Skin disease affects 1 in 4 Americans, and doctors base diagnosis and management decisions on changes in skin appearance. But visual markers of disease can be indirect and subjective, especially in skin of color patients where skin changes like redness are harder to see. We propose new infrared imaging technology that allows skin disease to be more objectively measured at both large and microscopic scales.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will determine whether there is a significant association between neighborhood characteristics, substance abuse, and mental health symptoms among urban youth. Using innovative methods in recruitment such as venue-based sampling, this study will obtain a representative sample of youth to include those who are most at-risk such as street- involved and truant youth. Results from this study will advance the field of substance abuse prevention by including hidden populations of youth to inform the adaptation of a substance abuse prevention intervention.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Mechanical forces generated by cells in epithelial tissue sheets play key roles in the development of functional tissues and organs. This project will integrate nanoengineering and optogenetic techniques to measure and manipulate these forces in order to better understand how tissues are shaped during development. Dysregulated forces in tissues can lead to disease states including birth defects, metastatic cancer, and improper wound healing and this project will shed new light on how mechanical forces contribute to human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary hypertension (PH) induced by hypoxia is a debilitating disease that affects premature infants with bronchopulmonary dysplasia and adults with chronic obstructive lung disease. We showed that genetic activation of Fibroblast Growth Factor (FGF) signaling in lung endothelial cells is protective against hypoxia-induced PH. This proposed studies will increase our understanding of the role of FGF in vascular remodeling, as well as advance gene therapy approaches to activate FGF signaling efficiently and selectively in the pulmonary vascular endothelium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Severe infections and inflammation of the lung leads to build-up of fluid in the lung, resulting the devastating Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), in which patients have to be placed on ventilators and for which there are no effective treatments. We have found that lung blood vessel endothelial cells can function as immune cells and are essential to the development of the disease. By understanding this newly recognized function of lung endothelial cells, this Program Project will identify molecules that can be targeted for the development of new ARDS treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Racial disparities in the use of OAC in patients with NVAF are notable given the increased risk of stroke and death in Blacks with NVAF. Shared decision making is guideline indicated by cardiovascular professional organizations for discussions about the risk and benefits of OAC, but it is less likely to occur in Blacks with NVAF. This research will identify barriers and facilitators to shared decision making, develop a patient decision support tool to assist in facilitating shared decision making with the goal of improving decision quality, increasing OAC use among Blacks and decreasing disparities in OAC use between Blacks and Whites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Immune thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (iTTP) is a potentially devastating hematologic disorder associated with significant morbidity and mortality. There is a need for improved treatments and for better diagnostic testing to identify patients at increased risk of disease relapse. This proposal will address the autoantibody-mediated pathophysiology of iTTP towards identifying novel strategies for the clinical management of the disease.

PHR: Project Narrative We will develop and efficiently complete novel early phase cancer prevention clinical trials of vaccines, signaling inhibitors, and immune-modulating drugs by enhancing patient accrual through effective use of social media and mobile messaging. The results of these trials will contribute to our basic understanding of the critical role of the immune system and molecular signaling pathways in tumorigenesis, thus helping to reduce cancer incidence and mortality and promote public health by advancing cancer prevention drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Summer Program to Increase Diversity in Biomedical Research and the Physician Workforce encompasses two training initiatives designed to enhance the training experience of underrepresented minority and disadvantaged students who are interested in pursuing careers in medicine and research. The program for undergraduates is entitled “The Pritzker School of Medicine Experience in Research (PSOMER),” while the medical school program supports the participation of rising second year medical students in the Pritzker Summer Research Program (SRP). The goal is to provide strongly mentored summer experiences in research, as well as structured programming and mentoring that will encourage students to progress into medicine and biomedical research careers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A unique epigenetic state called bivalency exists in germ cells and embryonic stem cells at promoters of developmental genes, but little is known about the mechanisms that establish bivalency and the functional contributions of the bivalent state to germ cell function, fertilization, and embryonic development. This project will address this gap in understanding by investigating the specific sequence elements that drive establishment of bivalency and identifying novel candidates responsible for regulating this unique histone modification state. This research will advance our basic understanding of how chromatin state is regulated and provide insight into new factors that may affect fertility and congenital disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative This R50 application seeks fund to support Dr. Zhao Lai, Director of the Next-Generation Sequencing Shared Resource (NGSSR) of the NCI-designated Mays Cancer Center at the University of Texas Health San Antonio. The NGSSR, heavily used by Cancer Center members and investigators in the San Antonio area, has a strong focus on its unique Hispanic population, and provides cutting-edge high throughput sequencing expertise and analytical capacities to support diverse genomic applications. Dr. Lai, a highly skilled and well-trained genomics scientist, is a critical member who leads a cutting-edge scientific team in the NGSSR that supports and contributes intellectually to many NCI-funded projects through its expert genomic analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to investigate the cellular morphologies, behaviors, and signaling events that drive the asymmetric development of the murine incisor. The knowledge of these mechanisms at this unprecedented resolution will enable us to define the processes that drive the morphogenesis of teeth, and on a broader scale, various organs that use similar dynamic and tightly regulated epithelial-mesenchymal interactions. Furthermore, the knowledge of how tooth development is regulated will build a foundation to drive future regenerative dental therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Bone healing is impaired in type 2 diabetes (T2DM). This project will study the role of diabetic macrophage derived-extracellular vesicles and their unique/novel miRNA act in concert with mesenchymal stem cells to control bone repair and regeneration. Successful completion of this work will refine knowledge of diabetic pathology and provide potential targets for therapeutic intervention as well as further innovative ways to control inflammation and regeneration that influences bone repair in T2DM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal develops an acellular therapy for the in vivo regeneration of the mandibular condyle cartilage of the temporomandibular joint using a novel multi-layer scaffold design and biomaterials. The novel scaffold design will be used to recapitulate the native tissue architecture. Furthermore, we have developed a novel clinically relevant injury model for the TMJ in goats used in the proposed studies.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative The proposed Johns Hopkins University-Hanoi University of Public Health Research Program on Health, Economic and Societal consequences of trauma and injuries in Vietnam (JHU-Hanoi HEalS) will build capacity for research on the consequences of injury, and post injury rehabilitation within health systems in Vietnam. We will develop a core group of researchers through a long-term training sequence for students in the Hanoi University of Public Health’s MPH, Master of Hospital Management degree program and program on rehabilitation to ensure sustainable research capacity development in the region. We will create a center of excellence for research on the consequences of injury and post injury rehabilitation at HUPH, where we will also offer non-degree short-term trainings such as workshops, online courses, and webinars on key priority topics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The etiology of the megakaryocyte defect in thrombocytopenia absent radius (TAR) syndrome is still not understood, and the postnatal emergence of the thrombocytopenia suggests that definitive hematopoiesis may be more insightful than primitive hematopoiesis to model its pathogenesis. Though functional and qualitative differences between megakaryocytes derived from primitive and definitive hematopoiesis has been well described, the mechanisms responsible for these differences or if they can lead to inequal disease phenotype penetrance has not been determined. The proposed study will expand our understanding of the pathogenesis of TAR syndrome, megakaryocyte biology at different stages of development, and how mutations affecting ubiquitous cellular processes may exhibit lineage-specificity in order to improve the relevancy of in vitro disease models and tailor therapeutic strategies to distinct tissue systems.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Preterm birth is the leading cause of neonatal morbidity and mortality, is frequently associated with maternal morbidity, and is significantly more common among Black women. The interactions of race with mechanisms that cause preterm birth and on potential preterm birth biomarkers are not fully understood. I will conduct a paired analysis of vaginal metabolites and metagenomics in a racially diverse cohort of pregnant women to quantify the interactions among race, vaginal metabolites, vaginal microbes, and preterm birth, in order to address a significant reproductive health challenge and driver of racial inequity.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative While the demand for fertility treatments is on the rise because of the increasing age that women seek to become pregnant, the high cost and accessibility of IVF is the leading reason why couples choose not to undergo and/or delay the treatment. The ability to automate various functions of an embryology lab will enable decentralization of IVF and pave the way to reduced treatment costs and improved accessibility. We will develop and commercialize a novel microfluidic system, OvaSafe, for standardized and automated vitrification of oocytes, in order to support an approach of providing IVF services in remote and small clinics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The objectives of this project are to develop and determine the effectiveness of an mHealth smartphone technology which can be used to engage primary caregivers directly in the active monitoring of their infants’ development, and to provide tailored feedback and support for the provision of nurturing care and positive infant developmental outcomes. In addition, we will also prospectively assess the implementation characteristics of the technology—usability, acceptability, and sustainability—for caregivers and health workers in a rural Guatemalan population which is at high risk for impaired infant growth and development. Following successful implementation in Guatemala, this mHealth method could then be expanded to families with at-risk infants worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oral clefts are among the most common birth defects, affecting 1 in 700 live births. Although problems with language and literacy have been well-documented in children with clefts, there are currently no studies of interventions to address these problems. This randomized controlled trial study will be the first to test the efficacy of a shared reading intervention, developed to meet the needs of children with oral clefts and their caregivers, in improving language and literacy outcomes.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 8.5 million Americans participate annually in competitive high school or collegiate sport, greatly elevating their risk for musculoskeletal injury and perhaps positioning them for poor long-term health and function. The proposed DP5 research will evaluate the impact of prior knee injury and sedentary behavior as two potential mechanisms of later poor health and reduced function. The findings will inform the way we rehabilitate, counsel, and educate athletes for long-term health and lead to future longitudinal and intervention studies that will ultimately decrease chronic disease in mid-life, enhancing healthspans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Spinal cord injury (SCI) is a major medical illness, as it affects many Veterans, and it affects their quality of life. Several important organ functions are affected such as bladder, bowel, and sexual function due to the limited intrinsic healing capacity of the spinal cord and the absence of effective therapeutic interventions. The major focus of this proposal is to evaluate the feasibility of the application of a novel combination therapy to improve urinary bladder functional recovery after SCI in an animal model. We believe the proposed studies will have important therapeutic implications for future treatment strategies for SCI-related autonomic organ function recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Oxfendazole in Neurocysticercosis Principal Investigator/Program Director: GARCIA, Hector H. A multicenter, randomized controlled trial of single and three-dose  regimens of oxfendazole for mild (one or two lesions)  parenchymal brain cysticercosis NARRATIVE  The cystic larvae of the pork tapeworm Taenia solium can infect the human brain and cause epilepsy. This condition, named neurocysticercosis (NCC), still accounts for approximately one third of epilepsy cases in most of the world. Anti-parasitic drugs destroy the cysts and also result in clinical benefits. Still, the efficacy of the best available regimens offer less than 70% efficacy in parenchymal brain NCC with one to two lesions, which is the most form of presentation in the Indian subcontinent, in pediatric populations worldwide, in travelers to endemic regions, and in non-endemic regions such as the US. The recent development of oxfendazole (OXF) as a potential anti-parasitic agent for human use may provide increased efficacy and easier administration. We will perform a controlled trial in Peru and India comparing a single dose and a three-dose regimes of OXF with the currently used 10 day regime of ABZ plus PZQ.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In 10% of elderly patients, pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) originates from mucin-producing cystic precancerous lesions called intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms (IPMNs). Activating mutations in GNAS(R201C) are thought to drive IPMN-derived PDAC, but the cell of origin for IPMN initiation is not known. This proposal aims to take advantage of human stem cell-derived pancreatic ductal and acini organoids to understand how oncogenic GNAS supports initiation and progression of IPMNs in pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative    . Cardiac arrest is a common and devastating cardiac and neurological emergency affecting almost 400,000 victims in the US every year, many of whom are successfully resuscitated but then die in the hospital or are left with severe disability from injury to the brain during the cardiac arrest. Immediate temperature control and cooling of comatose survivors of cardiac arrest is now commonly used to try to reduce the brain injury, but it remains uncertain whether it is truly effective, how long a survivor of cardiac arrest should be cooled, and which patients are more likely to benefit. This clinical trial proposes to first determine whether longer durations of cooling improve recovery better than shorter durations, and secondly to determine the best duration of cooling, in comatose patients resuscitated from either of two different types of cardiac arrest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Advancements in computational psychiatry allow us to isolate the contributions of multiple, specific, cognitive mechanisms that contribute to the behavior that we see in everyday life. This approach fills a critical unmet need in psychiatry by generating mathematically precise variables that can bridge the gap between pathophysiology and psychopathology. The main goals of the current project are to: 1) test the idea that computational metrics have enhanced validity and sensitivity relative to standard behavioral performance metrics in key psychiatric and nonpsychiatric populations and to relate these metrics to EEG markers of brain function; and 2) establish and optimize the psychometrics of these computational metrics so that they can be used as tools in treatment development, longitudinal studies, and genetic studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative DNA replication, the duplication of the cell’s genetic material, requires over 3 dozen proteins to orchestrate this complex process and any of these processes gone awry can lead to human disease, including metastatic cancer. The studies proposed here are basic studies using pure proteins to understand very specifically on how these many proteins function together to duplicate DNA, but with an eye toward processes that may lead to human abnormal function, especially for epigenetic inheritance that is known to cause human disease. However, there are certainly other disease related processes that will come to light as the basic mechanism of how the replication machinery functions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The current Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic is threatening the health of Americans - including our Veterans. Currently, there are no proven methods for treatment or prevention of COVID-19. The ultimate goal of this project is to understand the antibody responses to the outer part of the virus that causes COVID-19 and to isolate monoclonal antibodies against it. With this information, we are hoping we can come up with new therapeutics for treatment and prevention of COVID-19 in our Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to continue the follow-up of the Nurses' Health Study II (NHSII), a Cancer Epidemiology Cohort of 116,430 women enrolled in 1989 at ages 25 to 42 years. Data include repeated measures of diet, physical activity, and other exposures over 33 years of follow-up, as well as blood, urine, buccal cells, stool and tumor tissue biospecimens. Cohort follow-up is reaching the most informative phase and is a unique resource for scientific aims that integrate exposures over the life course, including diet, other lifestyle variables, biomarkers, genetic predisposition and mediating variables, in relation to cancer risk and survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite effective treatments for choroidal neovascularization, age-related macular degeneration (AMD) remains the leading cause of blindness in the US due to the eventual development of atrophy in the long-term. As current attempts to develop therapies to slow the progression of atrophy have met with limited success, earlier intervention would be desirable, and could be possible if endpoints and biomarkers to assess progression early in the disease were available. By studying the epidemiology of AMD progression over 7 years, the proposed research will identify these critical biomarkers and develop a staging system for AMD which is essential to enable early intervention clinical trials for AMD.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gender-affirming medical therapy for transgender and gender diverse youth can be initiated in early puberty with gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists for puberty suppression, but there are sparse data on skeletal outcomes of early pubertal suppression and subsequent peer-concordant puberty-timing of gender-affirming sex hormones. Because puberty is a critical time period for skeletal growth and mineralization, gender- affirming medical therapy is introduced during a particularly vulnerable window. Understanding how bone mass develops as gender-affirming sex steroids are introduced following puberty suppression, in the context of important determinants of bone development such as physical activity, body composition, and muscle strength, will fill a critical knowledge gap and potentially improve current treatment protocols, as future studies further characterize these skeletal trajectories into young adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Men living with HIV are significantly less likely than women to know their HIV status, initiate anti-retroviral therapy, and achieve viral suppression, particularly in South Africa. Furthermore, while there is growing knowledge of the Undetectable Equals Untransmittable (U=U) concepts in Western and high-income countries, the reach and penetration of the U=U message in sub-Saharan Africa has been limited. Our rigorous evaluation of interventions that incorporate U=U messages for cis-gender men in a high HIV prevalence setting will provide critical information to inform the implementation of HIV testing and ART adherence counseling guidelines in South Africa and globally, ultimately accelerating the decline in HIV incidence among women, improving men's HIV-related health outcomes, and improving the likelihood of achieving UNAIDS 95-95-95 goals by 2030.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Machine learning-based computer vision technology can supplement or even supplant some of the traditional benchtop methods that malariologists currently rely on for interrogating the biology of Plasmodium, a persistant cause of death and disease in much of the tropical and sub-tropical world where one-third of the world population resides. Microscopy-based methods may seem on the surface mundane or archaic, but they remain a crucial clinical and investigative tool for malaria where a tissue “biopsy” is as simple as a prick of the finger. We aim to modernize microscopy applications in basic science and pre-clinical malaria research by leveraging recent advances in computer vision and artificial intelligence to accelerate and innovate the means by which information is derived from malaria blood smears and, in the process, establish novel methods in weakly- and semi-supervised learning and domain adaptation to overcome key challenges in biomedical image analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: Project Narrative Suboptimal racial/ethnic minority accrual to clinical trials perpetuates significant disparities in cancer care. The overall goal of the proposed research is to refine, implement, and evaluate a multilevel intervention to improve minority referral and enrollment to NCI-sponsored cancer therapeutic clinical trials leveraging digital solutions coupled with navigation by community health educators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite recent progresses in mechanobiology research, there is still a fundamental knowledge gap in critical cellular functions and molecular mechanisms, which take place between the molecular and cellular scale. Combining the state-of-the-art top-down nanotechnology and the bottom-up synthetic biology, we will create artificial cell interfaces with multiplexed physicochemical features to elucidate and direct cellular functions. Considering the interplay and crosstalk between multiple receptors and physicochemical cues, we will reveal the underlying synergistic mechanisms of heteromolecular mechanobiology for cell-extracellular matrix signaling (fibroblast as a model) and cell-cell signaling (T cell as a model).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer has a mortality rate approximately equal to its incidence and will soon become the second- leading cause of all cancer-related deaths. High mortality is primarily the result of treatment resistance and, therefore, the current proposal seeks to develop microbial-based, tumor-targeted approaches to diminish the abundance of extracellular matrix components that significantly reduce delivery and efficacy of therapy in pancreatic cancer. Our research is relevant to public health because it is expected to generate approaches that will safely promote tumor permeability and drug perfusion, ultimately enabling anticancer agents to achieve their greatest therapeutic effects in cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE: The goal of this project is to develop and validate an “integrated risk score” (IRiS) predictor using histomorphometric features derived from digital images of surgically excised tissue specimens and biopsied tissue, that is both prognostic of prostate cancer (PCa) outcome and predictive of added benefit of adjuvant therapy following definitive therapy (surgery OR radiation therapy). IRiS will help to identify which of the over 160,000 men with high-risk prostate cancer in the US and who annually undergo definitive therapy have higher risk disease and hence may receive added benefit from additional chemotherapy following definitive therapy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the discovery of effective approaches for the design and implementation of computerized clinical decision support (CDS) tools can improve the expeditious translation of evidence into practice; thereby, improve the management of populations of patients and lead to improved patient care and outcomes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Health care workers’ negative behavior towards patients (likely a reflection of low job satisfaction, frustration with delivering HIV care and treatment in extremely resource-limited settings, and burnout) is one of the primary reasons people living with HIV abandon treatment in Mozambique. The purpose of this proposal is to test the impact and implementation of a provider resilience intervention and an anti-stigma intervention, individually and in combination, using a randomized controlled trial design at four health facilities. This potentially high-impact intervention offers the opportunity to test a low-cost, provider-focused approach to improving HIV treatment that, if proven effective at increasing adherence and retention in care, could be tested in a fully powered R01 trial in Mozambique.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Osteoarthritis (OA) is a highly prevalent musculoskeletal disorder affecting 303 million people globally in 2017. Since OA is associated with aging and obesity which are on the rise in global population, its prevalence is also dramatically increasing. Currently there is no treatment that can prevent, stop, or even restrain progression of OA; the current OA pain medications have several side effects that increase the disease burden. We have identified a novel target whose inhibition promotes cellular regeneration while blocking senescence and will develop a small molecule inhibitor to be tested as a disease-modifying treatment in OA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Normal strength and structure of elastic fibers surrounding the optic nerve head has been linked to glaucoma which is the leading cause of irreversible vision loss. We propose to use our unique animal models to test mechanistic association of abnormal elastic fibers with optic nerve damage. We will also test the novel therapeutic strategy for glaucoma treatment by targeting tissue biomechanics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Progressive trabecular meshwork stiffening contributes to persistent intraocular pressure elevation in primary open-angle glaucoma. This work seeks to understand how trabecular meshwork cells retain a memory of their past environments, and how this impacts their future behavior. Understanding the mechanisms that control the persistence of trabecular meshwork dysfunction will help find new therapies to treat this blinding disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Though children with Down syndrome (DS) are at increased risk for having a comorbid diagnosis of Attention- Deficit / Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), ADHD is often under-recognized in children with DS due to “diagnostic overshadowing” by the primary intellectual disability. Even when ADHD is diagnosed in children with DS, ADHD is often under-treated due to a lack of data to support the efficacy and safety of stimulant medication in children with DS+ADHD, especially among the 50% of children with DS who have congenital heart defects for whom there could be increased cardiac risk. This study is the first clinical trial of stimulant medication in children with DS+ADHD and will determine the short- and long-term efficacy and safety of these medications in children with DS+ADHD and has the potential to significantly improve the functional status, behavior, and quality of life of children with DS+ADHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The links between ocular surface innervation and disease are apparent; however, there is a wide gap in the understanding how ocular surface nerves may affect and may be affected by disease. This proposal is designed to create large “-omic” data sets that morphologically, anatomically, molecularly, and functionally characterize interactions between ocular surface nerves, epithelial cells, and immune cells during ocular surface health and disease

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The Fort Belknap Community (FBC)-Johns Hopkins School of Nursing (JHU) NARCH XI programs will build individual and tribal capacity to address health disparities and promote wellness on the Fort Belknap Reservation through research and training. Aaniiih and Nakoda students, faculty members, tribal health leaders, and nurses will complete training in STEM, public health, and nursing, and engage in the adaptation and evaluation of the JHSON Mental Health Training program. Additionally, they will participate in hands-on community-based research training through the two research studies to: (1) reduce risk and promote healing after a suicide death and to develop a suicide cluster response plan, and (2) adapt the myPlan app to improve safety and health of adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is a life-threatening and fatal lung disease, and novel therapeutic approaches directly targeting the vascular remodeling process are critical. Our goal is to define the epigenetic mechanisms underlying the regulation of BMPR2 expression in PAH and characterize the physiological consequences of epigenetic modifications in pulmonary vascular cells. Our findings will be of great public health relevance, as this proposal aims to evaluate the therapeutic potential of a new gene therapy approach, which may cure PH.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: NARRATIVE Recurrence of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) causes significant morbidity and mortality and is a major problem in VA healthcare. We cannot currently predict which individuals will develop recurrent CDI. The proposed study will determine bacterial and functional correlates of recurrent CDI, which could be validated and developed as biomarkers to predict C. difficile recurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM) is an incurable disease with short median overall survival. Macrophage and microglia mediate resistance to current therapies and are profoundly immunosuppressive. Our studies provide the novel mechanisms elucidating why macrophage and microglia are suppressed and highly possible lead to novel therapeutics targets for GBM treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria is the leading parasitic threat to humans and a major infectious cause of morbidity and mortality. While there have been concerted efforts to address vector-borne transmission, blood transfusion remains a neglected mode of transmission and strategies to contend with transfusion-transmitted malaria (TTM) are the exception. We propose to conduct one of the largest studies of TTM to date, to characterize the epidemiology of malaria in blood donors, as well as the risk of infection to transfusion recipients in a malaria-endemic country. We will also evaluate the economic viability and relative performance of different testing modalities to develop evidence-based strategies to contend with TTM in endemic and non-endemic countries alike.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: In older adults, mild dementia is associated with impaired function within several brain networks that causes numerous symptoms including loss of memory, the ability to complete complex mental tasks, and the capacity to control one’s walking and thus avoid falling and fall-related injuries. This study seeks to assess the separate and combined potential of two different types of transcranial current stimulation (tCS), which are safe and noninvasive technologies that enable selective modulation of brain network function, to provide multi-symptom relief to older men and women with mild dementia. By using state-of-the-art technology to 1) stimulate more than one brain network at the same, and 2) study the relationship between the electrical fields created by tCS and the therapeutic benefit of this intervention for each individual, this trial is expected result in the development of tCS interventions that have maximal impact on daily life function within this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spanish-English emergent bilinguals (EBs) are large and growing proportion of school-aged children in the United States, and approximately 6-8% are affected by developmental language disorder (DLD). Caregiver- delivered language interventions are a practical and promising approach to preventing and treating DLD in the home language, yet little is known about the specific caregiver behaviors that sustain home language development in EBs with or at-risk for DLD in preschool (age 3-5), a period when overall exposure to English increases. By drawing on naturalistic language observations (video observations and daylong recordings), the proposed research will advance our understanding of language development in EBs at risk for DLD, identify promising targets for future strength-based interventions, and develop new approaches to analyzing daylong recordings in bilingual settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The engineering of living cells as programmable therapeutic system is poised to transform therapeutic paradigms, particularly for cancer where some bacteria selectively colonize solid tumors. A central challenge for developing living microbial therapies is the inaccessibility to study this dynamical system consisting of interacting populations of bacteria and cancer cells. This research proposal leverages 3D multicellular coculture technologies and syn- thetic biology tools to engineer novel bacterial systems that sense and express therapeutics specifically in tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will dissect the dysregulated molecular circuitry in the brains of individuals with opioid use disorder and/or HIV infection. The proposal will identify genes that contribute to opioid use disorder and HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders. These approaches could lead to novel gene therapies to control and perhaps reverse the relentless disease state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The main goal of the Oregon Health & Science University Biomedical Informatics and Data Science College Undergraduate Summer Internship Program is to provide a rich, full-time experience to students to graduate study and careers in biomedical informatics and data science. The funding from this R25 grant will be used to support summer experiences for students with backgrounds that are underrepresented in biomedical informatics and data science. With assistance and coordination from Portland State University, we will support nine students per summer in an experience that includes knowledge and skills development, participation in a research project, a health data ethics and equity seminar, and scientific and career mentoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Adipose inflammation plays a significant role in the wasting of cancer cachexia but is poorly understood. In this proposal, we will dissect the cellular and molecular contributors to a JAK-dependent Tumor-Cytokine-Adipose Axis that increases lipolysis and subsequent wasting in cancer cachexia. Validating this axis in longitudinal cancer patient samples and optimizing inhibition of this axis will improve cancer cachexia patient quality of life and survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Glioblastoma (GBM) is an incurable primary brain tumor of high heterogeneity. This heterogeneity is one of the major obstacles to GBM treatment. To this end, we identified four molecular targets that are over-expressed collectively in all patients with GBM, but not normal brain. This is a unique development and we generated cytotoxic drug conjugates targeting these receptors simultaneously with an increased access to tumors to produce effective molecular resection with long-lasting anti-tumor response. In addition, we will also inflame these immunologically cold tumors with a targeted conjugate so they can mount more effective immune responses to complement the direct killing action of the cytotoxins. This approach has a great potential of significantly improving the management of the disease.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Safety concerns for children receiving mental and behavioral health care in the emergency department (ED) include delays in care, lack of appropriate psychiatric consults during visits, self-harm, harm against others or the environment, and involuntary restraint use resulting in patient and staff injury. Given the alarming rise in the utilization of the ED for pediatric mental and behavioral health care, there is a critical need to design the work systems in the ED to support safe and effective care. A highly experienced multi-disciplinary team of clinicians, scientists and engineers, will develop safer work systems in the ED for pediatric mental and behavioral health care using a combination of innovative techniques, to address the threats to patient safety.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Realizing Improved Patient Care through Human-centered Design for Pediatric mental and behavioral health in the Emergency Department(RIPCHD.PED)
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to develop reliable methods to proactively identify and improve work environments with high risk for physician burnout, and doing so will have broad public health relevance by reducing risk for burnout and its negative effects on quality and safety of care. Addressing physician burnout in primary care carries relevance for AHRQ’s priority populations of women, children, the elderly, and low-income patients, who are particularly dependent on high quality primary care. This project will support AHRQ’s mission of producing evidence to make health care safer and higher quality by developing and validating a prediction model to identify high-risk primary care clinics for physician burnout in order to 1) inform resource allocation to clinics with the highest need, 2) tailor process improvements to reduce risk for burnout and poor quality of care, and 3) lay the groundwork for expanding this model to other high-risk practice settings and provider types.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Development and Validation of a Prediction Model to Address Physician Burnout

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will develop a new class of Ubiquitin-independent protein-degrading small molecules that function by recruiting target proteins directly to the proteasome. This approach is quite novel and differs from any existing degrader strategy and will greatly simplify the development of degraders. Critical to this effort will be the discovery of high-quality ligands for the 19S Regulatory Particle of the proteasome, which will be accomplished by a novel DNA-encoded library screening strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Auditory processing abnormalities (e.g. auditory hypersensitivity and reduced auditory spatial attention) are common and prominent features in neurodevelopmental disorders such as autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The long-term goal is to investigate the mechanisms how altered myelination and brain connectivity impair auditory processing in neurodevelopmental disorders. A better understanding of the contributions of the neural mechanisms underlying the auditory processing abnormalities to ASD will help guide better therapeutic strategies for individuals with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Septic shock develops when infection overwhelms the body, causing low blood pressure that requires treatment with life-saving medications called vasopressors. The best way to use vasopressors to treat blood pressure in septic shock is unknown. This project aims to better understand how patients respond to vasopressors and predict which medication is best for individuals, which may improve how patients with septic shock are treated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In an effort to achieve diversity in substance use and addiction science, we propose the Addiction Scientists Strengthened through Education and Training (ASSET) program. This program is designed to improve long- term engagement of a diverse addiction scientist workforce to meet the growing U.S. need for effective prevention and treatment of substance use disorders. The ASSET program (10-weeks plus ongoing mentorship for 12 months) will provide junior investigators (postdoctoral and clinical fellows, and junior faculty) with research knowledge, skills, and mentored career development training that will build their long-term confidence and resilience to become independent researchers and leaders in the field of substance use and addiction science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Electronic health records (EHR) provide a population-scale resource to improve the diagnoses of rare diseases, which go unrecognized by most providers due to lack of familiarity. This proposal aims to leverage cutting-edge biomedical informatics and data science methodology to develop, validate and demonstrate the clinical utility of an EHR-driven SMART-on-FHIR based rare diseases clinical decision support system. Support for diagnosis of rare diseases will enable patients and providers to move efficiently beyond diagnoses to treatments and support for their condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We propose to advance a novel liquid biopsy, focused on urine, to monitor bladder cancer patients under immunotherapy treatment. We will specifically exploit urinary extracellular vesicles (uEVs) as a novel biomarker, and molecularly profile them using an enhanced nanoplasmonic-electrochemical platform. Our translational study will critically evaluate and establish this new EV assay for accurate and timelier bladder cancer cancer detection and treatment monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Chronic pain is a serious health concern effecting millions of American annually. In this application we are proposing to use innovative physiological, pharmacological and calcium imaging approaches, together with a novel somatosensory preparation to characterize the spinal circuitry involved in processing both nociceptive and non-nociceptive information. These studies will provide new knowledge about how specific populations of spinal neurons interact to form networks that process peripheral sensory information under normal conditions and following neuropathic injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE)  The impact of gene loss on complex phenotypes is strongly influenced by the cellular context and the genetic background. Working with consortium partners, we will prioritize the target genes for Phase 1 of the MorPhiC project, develop standards for data and resource sharing, and optimize methods for joint analyses. Our Production Center is expected to deliver a rich resource of knockout human pluripotent stem cell lines from diverse genetic backgrounds, extensive knockout phenotyping datasets in multicellular contexts that are informative of diverse human biology, robust and scalable knockout and phenotyping pipelines along with associated transferable methods and establish strong use cases for the MorPhiC catalog.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR
PHR: Narrative The broad use of anti-inflammatory steroids in millions of patients can cause elevated pressure inside eyes leading to glaucomatous loss of vision in susceptible individuals, which is a clinically significant problem. This steroid response is found in most glaucoma patients and is an important risk factor in the development of glaucoma. We have discovered a likely mechanism and are identifying genes responsible for this steroid responsiveness, which may play a major role in the development of glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Exposure to environmental agents can induce abnormal skeletal development posing lifelong implications for the patient’s health. This study is significant because it will reveal a novel mechanism whereby environmental toxicants influence osteoblast differentiation through alterations in microRNA expression. Through this, this proposal is relevant to the mission of NIH to increase understanding of how the environment affects biological processes to advance disease diagnosis, treatment, prevention, and ultimately support healthier lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lysine methylation is a widespread posttranslational modification, and the enzymes responsible for adding and removing lysine methylation are dysregulated in many human diseases. While we understand much about lysine methylation on histone proteins, thousands of non-histone proteins are also methylated. Our research aims to determine how non-histone lysine methylation regulates protein function and ultimately impacts cellular processes.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (OVERALL) Every undiagnosed disease program faces a huge problem of having identified significant numbers of genomic variants with insufficient functional evidence for clinical reporting and thus lacking clinical actionability. The UAB Center for Precision Animal Modeling (C-PAM) will develop a strategy and pipeline for efficient modeling and analysis of genomic variants of uncertain significance that are associated with a disease to determine if the variant is causal of the disease, to evaluate the significance on gene function and disease pathophysiology, and to support identification and evaluation of therapeutic targets. C-PAM will accomplish this by analyzing variants using a series of rigorous clinical and innovative bioinformatic tools and through the generation and distribution of clinically and molecular informative animal models to the research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - MECHANOSURVEILLANCE IN BREAST CANCER METASTASIS Metastasis is the leading cause of breast cancer related deaths, but the majority of treatment options that target known abnormalities in cancer cells are not curative. In our effort to identify additional abnormalities in cancer cells for therapeutic targeting, we found that the immune system could sense and destroy cancer cells based on cancer cells’ altered biophysical stiffness. In this project, we aim to close the knowledge gap in our molecular understanding of this novel mode of immune surveillance, which we termed mechanosurveillance, in order to facilitate clinical progress in metastatic breast cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The current lack of translatability with current pharmacologic strategies for traumatic brain injury (TBI) dictates that other therapeutic strategies be evaluated thereby increasing the probability of bench-to-bedside success. Neural stem cell therapies may be a feasible alternative to pharmacotherapies for improving function after TBI as they can exploit their inherent ability to migrate and stimulate endogenous repair mechanisms, and thus the proposed studies will use an established rat model of TBI to test LM-NSC008 cell migration, distribution, and therapeutic efficacy in both sexes. A rehabilitative approach is also included and consists of using environmental enrichment, a well validated preclinical model of neurorehabilitation combined with LM-NSC008 cells to accelerate clinical translation to patients with TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE  This project will study the effectiveness of performing "clinical trials in a dish" for an inherited arrythmia known as catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycadia. The study will advance our understanding of how iPSC-based, personalized tissue chip models can be used to predict individual patient responses and to plan and de-risk clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  Aging and related neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease (AD) are an escalating major health concern in the US. The proposed research will examine the molecular 4D nucleome changes that occur in human hippocampus during the course of aging, and the positive effects of physical activity. The proposed research will produce multi-omics cell atlases of the human hippocampus to delineate molecular profiles of normal aging, and uncover potential transcriptional regulatory programs that are impacted by aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People living with HIV are at higher risk for severe COVID-19, hospitalization, and mortality, but the immune mechanisms contributing to the enhanced disease are unclear. This project will investigate the role of HIV-related dysregulation of immune responses and the microbiome on SARS-CoV-2 disease using a nonhuman primate model of HIV/AIDS. This innovative study will contribute to our understanding of how normal immunity drives SARS-CoV-2 lung pathophysiology and how immunodeficiencies promote enhanced COVID-19 disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Functional gastrointestinal disorders (FGIDs) are common, costly, cause significant pain and distress and yet are often ineffectively treated because they remain poorly understood. Our published and preliminary data strongly support the ideas that: (1) selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressant exposure in pregnancy is a major unexplored contributor to FGIDs in children and (2) that a serotonin-producing microbiota enterotype that is highly linked to FGID onset is transferrable from adult to child where it continues to drive elevated 5-HT signaling. This proposal will test whether SSRI antidepressant exposure impacts GI function triggering pathology consistent with FGID diagnoses and whether 5-HT producing microbiota provide a synergistic mechanism for these associations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative. Friedreich’s ataxia (FA) is a common, fatal hereditary disorder associated with devastating clinical manifestations. While neurologic disease limits mobility, 60% of individuals with FA die from progressive cardiomyopathy. The goal of this R61/R33 proposal is to carry out a phase IA/IB clinical study of AAVrh.10hFXN (a serotype rh.10 adeno-associated virus coding for human frataxin) to reverse cardiac manifestations of Friedreich’s ataxia.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: P50 Project Narrative The Population Council P50 Contraception Development Research Center aims to develop a new vaginal ring without any hormones that will prevent pregnancy and that may better meet the needs of many women around the world. The prevention of unintended pregnancy is a public health priority with approximately half of all pregnancies in the world being unintended. As a significant added benefit, this new contraceptive will also protect women from sexually transmitted infections, which continue to occur at high rates and cause problems in women such as infertility, premature delivery of babies, and increased risk of HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposal will characterize the role of mitochondrial unfolded protein response in prostate cancer progression leading to aggressive disease. The proposed research will define the underlying mechanism of mitochondrial regulation of therapeutic resistance and its translational relevance in prostate cancer. The successful completion this study will provide alternative treatment options for men with this lethal prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The psychological and socioeconomic effects of DMD on families are enormous. These include medical care costs, opportunity costs for career and work, and the psychological toll taken on parents and siblings. The identification of genetic modifiers of DMD will allow for patient stratification in upcoming clinical trials of novel therapies, may reveal novel targets for potential therapies, and may allow patient-specific tailoring of current therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is estimated that high blood pressure affects nearly 75 million persons, contributes to the death of over 410,000 Americans each year, and results in more than $51.2 billion in annual treatment costs. Due to high treatment costs, adverse side effects of existing drugs, and high risk of drug-drug interactions, only approximately 50% of adults with hypertension have their blood pressure adequately controlled. This project seeks to investigate isothiocyanates (ITCs), natural products derived from cruciferous vegetables as a cheaper alternative to effectively treat or protect against hypertension with minimal side effects and minimal risk of drug interactions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drastic shifts in family and community life associated with the spread of COVID-19 have been especially challenging for families of children with neurogenetic conditions (NGC), who are particularly vulnerable to reductions in targeted therapeutic services, and whose children are more likely to experience increases in challenging behavior as a result of the changes. The proposed study will test the feasibility, efficacy, and impact of a personalized digital assessment and treatment network for reducing secondary health effects of COVID-19 on NGC caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Schistosomiasis is a parasitic infection affecting more than 250 million individuals in many tropical countries, and is a major cause of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) worldwide. How this parasite together with the body’s immune system injure the lung blood vessels to cause PAH is not well understood. Using a series of experiments with mice experimentally exposed to the parasite, along with analysis of blood samples collected from patients with this condition in Brazil, we seek to understand how this happens, and identify new ways to diagnose the disease and potentially prevent it or treat it in the future.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Overall Project Narrative Antiretroviral treatment (ART) options for pregnant women and children living with HIV have fallen behind those for adults, reflecting the substantial research gap for modern ART regimens in these groups. Here we propose a series of interrelated projects that expand the scientific objectives and data utilization of a valuable nationwide birth surveillance system in Botswana (the Tsepamo Study), and connect it with the infrastructure provided by an existing program for identifying and treating infants with HIV (the Early Infant Treatment Study). The four proposed projects, anchored by two cores, include: 1) expanded congenital abnormality surveillance and performance of an emulated clinical trial to address critical questions related to the use of ART regimens by maternal weight strata; 2) creation of surveillance reporting criteria in pregnancy and validation of a target trial approach to ART regimen comparisons; 3) use of Tsepamo data and EIT infrastructure to perform targeted point- of-care HIV testing at birth followed by optimized Dolutegravir-based ART for infants; and 4) utilizing point-of- care diagnostics and the Dolutegravir treatment cohort, and specimens from mRNA vaccine recipients, to support laboratory-based precision medicine approaches for immune control of pediatric HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mistakes in cell division result in cells having extra or missing genetic information, a state which is associated with cancer, miscarriage, and birth defects. The results of this study will provide insight on how components of the machine that segregates genetic information are built, and how their mechanical properties are tuned to ensure that genetic information is segregated accurately when cells divide. In the long run, this approach will potentially suggest new explanations for how disease states related to cell division arise, and new strategies for targeting them.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project narrative Dysfunctional maturation of GABAergic neurotransmission and excitatory/inhibitory [E/I] balance in the brain is implicated in several neurodevelopmental disorders. Identification of the ontogenic, molecular, cellular and circuit mechanisms is crucial for understanding childhood social, cognitive and anxiety disorders and for the identification of intervention and treatment advances. Neuregulin 1 (NRG1), and CHRNA7 [15q13.3] (encoding the a7nAChR) are key modulators of nervous system development. Signaling via the a7nAChR is a critical driver of the GABA excitatory/inhibitory [E/I] shift, mediated via the chloride transporters, NKCC1 and KCC2. Here we will use a novel transgenic mouse model of NRG1 overexpression, molecular biology, cell biology, slice electrophysiological approaches and behavioral neuroscience to examine the role of a novel NRG1 isoform on brain development (spanning from birth to adulthood) as it mechanistically relates to cortical maturation of GABA transmission and E/I balance, neurobehavior. The project will also provide mechanistic data and identify prenatal intervention strategies to improve brain development in-utero.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC), a highly lethal form of breast cancer, disproportionately affects African American (AA) compared with non-Hispanic White women (W) with hazard ratios for death 30% higher in AA compared to W even after adjusting for socioeconomic position, age at diagnosis, treatment, and hormone receptor status. Recently, we discovered that this disparity may be the result of a heightened adaptive stress response signaling in the tumor microenvironment of AA linked to IBC risk factors, which can lead to greater capacity for clonal evolution of death-resistant tumor cells contributing to aggressive, therapy-resistant disease. As the incidence is rising and targets for therapy are scant, IBC has the potential to become a major public health disparity concern. This study has the potential to lead to new treatment options, provide a biomarker for stress related progression and therapy resistance in AA-IBC, and predict those who would benefit from these targeted approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Targeting of essential viral RNA structures rather than proteins is a potentially transformative antiviral strategy. This project seeks to develop a novel antiviral discovery platform that overcomes many of the challenges associated with selective RNA targeting, leading to increased productivity of RNA-targeted screening campaigns. The proposed technologies will be developed around severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), with the goal of identifying RNA-targeted small molecules that inhibit viral replication.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Bicycling is a leading cause of childhood injury and crashes with motor vehicles cause fatalities and severe injuries with long-term physical and psychological sequelae. This project will use novel technology to observe real-world naturalistic bicycling (safety behaviors and errors) to evaluate the impact of an early adolescent bicycle safety education program and parent training session component. The long-term goal of this project is to reduce the burden of childhood bicycling injuries and increase bicycling safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current genetic studies largely ignore most of the entire human history that gave rise to genetic variation. This proposal will leverage recent breakthroughs in inferring the sequence of genealogies across the genome to develop novel analytical methods in multiple subdisciplines of human genetic research. The result of our proposal will improve the way genetic studies are designed and analyzed, leading to a better understanding of the genetic risk factors to diseases, particularly in understudied admixed populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The treatment of pediatric cancers has remained largely unchanged in decades, relying primarily on aggressive cytotoxic chemotherapy and radiation, however, these therapies have debilitating long-term consequences. We will use new computational methodologies applied to large preclinical screening data from cancer cell lines and patient -omics datasets to investigate unmutated genes as potential drug targets in pediatric cancers (non-oncogene dependencies). We will perform the requisite downstream experimental work, including studying drug combinations and resistance mechanisms, necessary to motivate the clinical translation of our findings.
