IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) affects millions of Americans, yet there are no treatments that significantly slow disease progression once symptoms manifest, making early intervention crucial to reduce the individual and societal burden of this disease. Existing genetic risk prediction models are limited to individuals of European descent, and this proposal seeks to create a truly cross-ancestry model that can predict any individual’s AD risk, which will be made widely available as a direct-to-consumer genetic test. It will enable early intervention and life planning for at-risk individuals and allow researchers to maximize the probability of detecting treatment effects in clinical trials by assessing patients’ underlying disease risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Through the proposed study, we hope to understand how many African Americans have a particularly severe form of high blood pressure called treatment-resistant hypertension (TRH). In order to do that, we need to rule out other conditions that are not TRH, but make a person’s blood pressure high, such as not taking medications as prescribed, kidney problems, or disordered breathing while sleeping. Finally, we want to identify the role of lifestyle factors, such as diet and exercise, on this severe form of high blood pressure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inhalation of toxic chemicals often causes late development of high blood pressures within the lungs for unclear reasons, leading to significant breathing difficulties, heart damage, and sometimes even death. In this project we will study two chemicals that injure the lungs after direct inhalation, but where only one of those chemicals causes late-onset high blood pressures in the lungs, while the other results in normally recovered lungs within days. We will investigate a possible reason for developing such high lung blood pressures, by studying the abnormal healing of the blood vessels that support the lungs. The findings of this application will improve our understanding of late-onset blood vessel problems after chemical inhalation, and will lead to the new medication testing in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The interactive scientific visualization software tools we develop directly address many of the critical challenges researchers face as they discover, analyze, and chronicle the major biological processes inherent in life and human disease. Our software enables spatially complex experimental data that often varies over time to be visualized and analyzed and, thus, directly leads to a deeper understanding of important principles in biomedicine. We strive to promote the application of interactive 3D visualization and analysis techniques to critically important cutting-edge problems in structural and computational biology, and to provide insight into molecular and cellular function that can be directly applied to problems relevant to both translational biomedical research and precision medicine.

PHR: Enhancer RNAs Boost MYC-Chromatin Interaction to Regulate Gene Expression and Tumorigenesis  In this proposal, we will test our hypothesis that (1) MYC is an RNA-binding protein and (2) eRNA- mediated MYC-chromatin binding is important for MYC’s transcriptional regulation and oncogenic function. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative More than 80% of childhood cancer survivors develop serious or life-threatening late effects after cancer therapy, but <20% receive recommended survivorship care offered at cancer center survivorship clinics. In a shared care model, we propose to investigate an innovative multi-level intervention consisting of: 1) patient survivorship education via telehealth with the cancer center, 2) ongoing patient-tailored education program within the electronic health record patient portal, 3) a structured interactive phone communication between the cancer center and the primary care clinic, and 4) an in-person visit with the primary care clinic for survivorship care with the goal of achieving high rates of adherence to recommended surveillance for late effects, as well as improving patient and physician knowledge and self-efficacy. If our scalable intervention demonstrates patient completion of recommended care comparable to cancer center survivorship clinics, our innovative study has the enormous potential to deliver recommended care to a larger proportion of childhood cancer survivors and reduce survivorship care disparities, while engaging patients and primary care providers to integrate survivorship care as part of overall, lifelong health maintenance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bladder cancer is caused by smoking and continued smoking after diagnosis leads to significant and preventable morbidity and mortality. Bladder cancer patients rely principally on their urologist for medical guidance but urology providers do not frequently use evidence-based practices (EBPs) that screen patients for smoking and provide them with the necessary counseling and medications to quit. In this study, we will characterize use of smoking cessation EBPs in the urology clinic then adapt and pilot a strategy to facilitate use of these EBPs in the urology clinic for patients with bladder cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Enhancing blood Donation at Schools and Beyond: An implementation Science study Project Narrative Inadequate blood supplies in Malawi continue to prevent optimal reduction of infant, under-5, maternal mortality and HIV associated deaths. We propose to conduct critical epidemiology surveillance and hemovigilance and qualitative research to understand facilitators and motivators of blood donation and strategies for engaging youth. Using this information, we will conduct a cluster randomized clinical trial to evaluate the effectiveness of an enhanced school-based donor program to increase both initial donation and long term retention as a donor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gastric cancer is significantly more common among Black, Asian, and Hispanic individuals than among whites in the US, and moreover individuals who self-identify as belonging to any one of these three minority groups are also more likely to die from this highly fatal cancer, which is generally asymptomatic until late stage when treatment is no longer effective. Most gastric cancers are caused by infection with the bacteria Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori), which is also more common among people of color than among whites, but even among all H. pylori-infected individuals, people of color are still more likely to develop and die from gastric cancer. This project seeks to understand the underlying reasons for the racial disparities to enable identification of key predictors to allow us to identify those at highest risk for gastric cancer, among whom H. pylori eradication and gastric cancer prevention are a high priority.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Currently, there are no effective tools for preventing or treating corneal scarring, which is a complication that potentially occurs with ocular injury, trauma, and/or surgery, and may result in decreased quality of life and possibly blindness. Extracellular vesicles (EVs), which contain cargo (e.g., RNA, protein, and lipids), are released by the corneal cells, and those released by the corneal epithelium can trigger myofibroblast differentiation, which will cause scarring and diminish vision if they persist. In this proposal, we will identify the EV-subset that is vital for corneal stromal activation and scarring, so that we may move forward with the development of novel therapies for the prevention and treatment of corneal scarring.

PHR: Project Narrative Proton and ion therapy have the potential to provide effective tumor control in cancer patients while minimizing the side effects of radiotherapy. In this proposal, we develop and evaluate innovative methods to use ionization detail for planning particle beam therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The ribosome is the macromolecular machine responsible for protein synthesis and deciphering its structure-function relationships is a fundamental biological problem. We will use a combination of genetics, molecular biology, and structural biology approaches to address basic questions of ribosome structural dynamics as they relate to function. The ribosome is also the target of more than half of all antibiotics, and a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanism of antibiotic resistance is an immediate outcome of this work.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project integrates transcriptome and methylome of Barrett’s esophagus (BE), the key cancer precursor of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC), with existing genetic and environmental risk factor data in genome-wide association studies. The goal is to identify new genetic and epigenetic loci underlying susceptibility and develop prediction models for EAC. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy is a genetically inherited disorder that causes sudden death in young people, but not every patient with Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy mutations experiences symptoms of the disease. We propose that differences in mechanical stress caused by blood pressure trigger for symptoms in Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy patients, and that understanding molecular mechanisms linking blood pressure and disease progression will help us develop new treatments. We will use human stem cells that express Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy mutations to create a heart tissue model in a dish and use these tissues to identify molecular mechanisms that cause the disease triggering mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narrative This study aims to develop an integrative modeling framework of complex genetic diseases to utilize high- resolution cell architecture from single-cell sequencing data, in conjunction with large-scale bulk sequencing data. We will systematically identify context-matched pairs of publicly available bulk and single-cell studies, characterize multi-scale cell architectures by a novel unsupervised cell clustering approach, and construct network models integrating across molecular modalities and cellular resolutions. The network models will be validated by genetic or chemical perturbation data in model systems from public databases, and shed lights on underpinning mechanisms and potential therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Conventional dendritic cells (CDC) play a central role in immunity including protective responses against pathogens and cancer, autoimmune diseases, outcome of organ transplantation, and response to vaccines. To support their many roles, CDCs have specialized subsets in tissue but mechanisms controlling their tissue distribution are poorly understood. Our work will uncover a novel pathway by which metabolic changes in tissue regulate local distribution of CDC subsets.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Creating Resources Uplifting Nutrition, Culture, and Health at Lunch (CRUNCH Lunch) is an innovative program to increase’s elementary school students Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) interest and food literacy by connecting STEM with the everyday act of eating school lunch. CRUNCH Lunch is being developed and evaluated using a diverse, urban elementary school aged population, with over 15,000 students and over 700 teachers. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive impairment after moderate to severe traumatic brain injury (msTBI) not only significantly affects the quality of life in individuals with msTBI, but also increases the possibility of late-life dementia. The goal of this study is to determine whether acute (< 1 week) cerebrovascular injury and its recovery within the first year postinjury measured by cerebral autoregulation and brain perfusion are associated with cognitive outcome at 12 months after msTBI. The results from this study will improve our understanding of cerebrovascular contributions to cognitive decline related to TBI and provide critical data to inform the development of strategies based on vascular mechanisms to improve cognition after msTBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current antibody drug therapies for proliferative diabetic retinopathy and diabetic macular edema require repeated, monthly intraocular injections to maintain the therapeutic dose, risking both injection site inflammation and drug-induced retinal injury. This project employs a targeted nanoparticle therapy containing small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) that are directed toward the pathogenic protein synthesis machinery. Our preliminary data demonstrates these nanoparticles, with further development, could greatly extend efficacy, thereby reducing the frequency of intraocular injections required to maintain disease remission and avoid the side effects of the current standard of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inhibition of coagulation factor XII (FXII) could be a transformative new approach to antithrombotic treatment that decouples therapeutic efficacy from the risk of bleeding complications. This proposal will explore the molecular mechanisms of FXII recruitment, activation, and propagation at the platelet surface. Elucidation of these processes is essential to the development of novel anti-thrombotic therapeutics based on FXII blockade.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project will investigate the effect of PM2.5, a ubiquitous air pollutant, on the biosynthesis and degradation of specialized pro-resolving mediators (SPMs) during the dynamic process of inflammation initiation to resolution in the respiratory tract. Potential differences by asthma and sex will be examined. This project will be carried out using a translational approach integrating a cell culture mechanistic investigation and a human observational study of SPMs and inflammation resolution in adults exposed to urban traffic PM2.5.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Klebsiella pneumoniae is a bacterium that frequently causes pneumonia, urinary tract infection, and bloodstream infection and is increasingly causing severe illness and death in hospitalized patients. A vaccine to prevent infection with antibiotic-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae could potentially save many lives, but little is known about the how the immune system responds to this organism. This proposal focuses on the sugars attached to the surface of Klebsiella pneumoniae and how these perform as components of vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Neurofluid circulation has gained much attention in light of its likely relevance to neurodegenerative and cerebrovascular disorders, including but not limited to Alzheimer’s Disease Related Dementias (ADRDs). Fundamental to the effective circulation of neurofluids is cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) production activity, which occurs within the choroid plexus (ChP) complexes located within each of the four brain ventricles; despite this, we lack rigorous and quantitative methods for quantifying ChP activity, thereby limiting abilities to evaluate CSF circulation in different neurodegenerative disorders, as well as in response to emerging therapies. The overall goal of this work is to refine and clinically evaluate neuroimaging methods to enable quantitation of ChP anatomy and function non-invasively in vivo; if successful, this will allow for ChP function to be interrogated reliably in the growing number of applications where neurofluid and CSF circulatory dysfunction are implicated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Brain metastases (BM) are the most commonly diagnosed type of central nervous system tumor. Arterial spin labeling (ASL) is ideal for frequent non-invasive longitudinal monitoring of tumor vascularity. This project proposes a prospective and comprehensive evaluation of state-of-art ASL perfusion mapping methods on BM patients for both early predicting treatment outcome and distinguishing true recurrence from radiation effects during the follow-up monitoring, which can be readily utilized as a practical and cost-effective imaging biomarker for multi-center and multi-vendor clinical studies of BM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative HIV infection of the brain leads to neuropathogenesis despite antiretroviral therapy (ART)-mediated viral suppression via complex mechanisms that remain largely unknown. We propose to develop a new human model to study the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying HIV neuropathogenesis, and the potential interactive, additive, or synergistic effects of ART and opioid exposure, using a microglia-infused brain cortical organoid system. This model will allow HIV infection and its related pathophysiological events and help to disentangle the contribution and interplay of relevant immune cells to neuronal damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The current proposal seeks to compare the effectiveness of specific inpatient rehabilitation approaches to optimize functional outcomes and community participation for persons with traumatic brain injury. Revealing the most effective approaches associated with the best outcomes will be investigated through a prospective observational dataset based on clinician-driven design of standardized electronic medical records documentation and analyzed with advanced statistical methods. The results will have the potential to advance standards of practice in rehabilitation and to arm clinicians and healthcare administrators with evidence-based results to advocate for the use of the most effective practices in TBI rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The findings from this project will determine the degree to which sex and sex hormones influence alcohol effects on sleep physiology. The results will inform future interventions aimed at reducing alcohol consumption and the negative impacts of alcohol on sleep in women. Given the wide-ranging impact of sleep on other areas of function, including cognition, stress, and well-being, such an intervention will have a substantial positive impact on women’s health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Mitochondria are the site of essential cellular processes such as metabolism and apoptosis (controlled cell death), which are often misregulated in cancer and neurodegenerative diseases. Proper mitochondrial function depends on a robust quality control system to remove old, damaged, or mislocalized proteins. Here, I propose experiments to test how mitochondrial protein quality control systems function, which could lead to new therapeutic approaches to cancer and neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative The limitation of druggable targets, the challenge of tumor heterogeneity and drug resistance to kinase inhibitors  in cancer therapy highlight the urgent need of developing new high-throughput drug screening strategies to  identify kinase modulators in complex cancer models. The objective of this proposal is to develop a novel multi pathway kinase activity assay and apply it to profile a large cysteine-reactive covalent fragment library in 2D and  3D cancer cell culture models to identify kinase modulator leads. The findings from this study hold promise to  not only advance kinase research overall, but also to identify candidate kinase modulators for future cancer drug  development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Several cell death types are involved in the pathogenesis of myocardial infarction and ischemia- reperfusion injury. This project will elucidate the role of ferroptosis, a recently discovered cell death mechanism, in cardiac dysfunction induced by ischemia-reperfusion. These studies will be useful for the development of new therapeutic strategies to mitigate cardiac ischemia-reperfusion injury by targeting ferroptotic cell death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Molecular classification has transformed the diagnosis and treatment of brain tumors and created promising avenues for targeted therapies. However, the molecular makeup of brain tumors remains difficult to access and apply to patient care in an effective and timely fashion. Through this academic-industrial partnership, we aim to develop and validate a means of unlocking the key genetic alterations in brain tumors through optics and artificial intelligence that could improve patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Kidney diseases affect 37 million people in the United States. Despite recent advances in treatment options, there remains an urgent unmet need to identify new therapeutic targets and treatments to bend the arc of kidney diseases and reduce these staggering numbers. The Northwestern University National Resource Core Center (NU-NRC) will harness the power of the physical sciences to provide innovative platforms, new approaches and reagents to kidney researchers to enable new solutions and find cures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Successful completion of the proposed experiments will characterize the role of astrocytic circadian clock in regulating synaptic rhythmicity and cognitive performance. There is a strong comorbidity between disruptions to the circadian cycle, and cognitive impairments, yet the mechanistic link is not well understood. We will examine how astrocytic molecular clock regulates time-of-day-dependent changes in synapse number and activity, determine the mechanisms controlling its function, and identify the rhythmic astrocytic factors that can be targeted to correct clock-related cognitive deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Oncogenic human viruses are associated with many human malignancies. The mechanisms regulating transcription and replication in hypoxia is not well investigated. This program will explore their strategies for control in establishing long-term viral infection and will provide new clues for development of targeted therapies for treatment of the associated cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: KSHV is an important pathogenic oncovirus associated with human cancers. Kaposi’s sarcoma (KS) and pleural effusion lymphomas (PELs) are tightly linked to KSHV-infection, seen in immunocompromised individuals, as well as endemic populations. This study aims to understand the replication of KSHV, and to elucidate the molecular mechanisms that drive persistence of KSHV in daughter cells in the hypoxic microenvironment of associated cancers. 15

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging data suggests that SARS-CoV-2 infections may lead to neurocognitive deficits, which can have a duration of at least a year post-infection, and are thereby very distressing. We have been following a cohort of 650 patients since discharge from our hospital, who were previously cognitively normal, and for whom 30% of returning subjects have progressive cognitive decline. Here we propose to follow and thoroughly investigate these subjects to answer these critical questions: (1) what are the characteristics of COVID-19 induced neurocognitive dysfunction, including its duration and anatomic localization; (2) what are its risk factors, including possibly sex, age, race/ethnicity and medical comorbidities; and, (3) what is the role of persistent inflammation in producing it, which is vital because a positive finding would lead immediately to trials of anti-inflammatory interventions for this devastating disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) is a lethal disease demanding new treatment strategies. Aggressive phenotypes and/or therapy failure seen in CRPC patients have been linked to the increased tumor cell metabolism and an androgen receptor (AR) splicing variant termed AR-V7, both of which are correlated with poorer prognosis in the clinic. However, the mechanisms underlying altered tumor metabolism and AR-V7- releated oncogenic programs in CRPC are far from clear. Our recent preliminary studies point to YY1, a zinc finger transcription factor showing significant overexpression during disease progression of CRPC. YY1 maintains high expression of both metabolic genes and the AR-V7-related gene targets. YY1 thus constitutes a completely new mechanism that might account for major malignant alterations in metabolism and androgen signaling seen in CRPC. The current proposal will explore this novel mechanism that underscores CRPC progression and therapeutic resistance. The successful completion of the proposed research shall allow a deeper understanding of how the terminal CRPC disease progresses and will help to rationally develop novel strategies to treat the affected patients. Thus, this proposal is significant, innovative and may potentially translate into the clinic to improve CRPC treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Evidence from our recent study suggests that Kaposi’s sarcoma (KS) originates from oral mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) through KSHV-induced mesenchymal-to-endothelial transition (MEndT). In this proposal, we will investigate the hypothesis that KSHV hijacks the cellular intrinsic hypoxia response to drive MSC to special lineage differentiation and commit oncogenesis. This study will provide mechanistic insights into how KSHV promotes MSC MEndT and oncogenic properties leading to KS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The OSU Medical Scientist Training Program (MSTP) will train outstanding and driven students in the research and clinical skills needed to position these individuals as the future physician-scientist leaders in the biomedical research workforce. Our program focuses on providing time-efficient instruction that includes key emphasis on rigorous experimental design, ethical conduct in the clinic and the lab, and strong communication skills. By providing state-of-the art medical education with in-depth and technologically advanced graduate training, OSU MSTP graduates will have an optimal skill set to discover fundamental disease mechanisms and use this information to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-surgical pain is common amongst those recovering from a surgical procedure. However, a small but significant surgical population experience chronic post-surgical pain. Although it is generally understood that sex hormones contribute to the development and maintenance of pain, including chronic pain, little is known about the role that basal sex hormone alterations play in development and maintenance of chronic post- surgical pain or analgesic post-surgical pain management. The work proposed herein seeks to develop novel altered sex hormone models that mirror the surgical patient population, as well as elucidate antinociceptive profiles.

ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a growing public health problem in the U.S., which presently affects at least 37 million Americans with an estimated 1.4 million new cases diagnosed very year. It is primarily caused by obesity- associated insulin resistance and dysfunction of insulin producing beta-cells. This research is aimed at identifying and developing safe and low-cost agents that simultaneously promote weight loss and reverse T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative MCPyV represents a ubiquitous skin infection that can cause an extremely lethal skin cancer, MCC. In this project, we propose to examine how the MCPyV-host interaction controls hypoxic gene expression during MCPyV infection and MCC tumorigenic progression. Knowledge gained from this study will provide new insights into the oncogenic mechanism of MCPyV, which contributes significantly to HIV/AIDS-associated malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is responsible for 200,000 new cancers each year. Like other DNA tumor viruses, EBV utilizes cellular oxygen-dependent metabolism and signaling pathways to drive oncogenic transformation. This proposal focuses on understanding how EBV responds to hypoxia and oxidative stress to drive epigenetic changes associated with viral latency and cellular oncogenesis. This study is highly aligned with other projects of this Program Project and will enhance our knowledge and strategies for therapeutic intervention in viral associated cancers.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New drugs and shortened combination regimens have been introduced for the prevention and treatment drug- susceptible and drug-resistant tuberculosis (TB) but their impact on pregnant people and their infants, including TB transmission and pediatric TB, is uncertain. This partnership between the Centre for Infectious Disease Epidemiology & Research, University of Cape Town and the Western Cape Health Intelligence Directorate will consolidate existing relationships across clinical, epidemiological and data science disciplines to establish a scalable data infrastructure for the management of maternal TB at the regional and individual clinical levels. Data science techniques will be employed to develop and enhance a novel and robust public service population-level data harmonization platform to i) create actionable clinical tools to optimize person-level interventions and monitor programs; ii) generate large, linked cohorts to address epidemiological questions and assess the impact of policy interventions and clinical tools at the population and individual levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE With successful treatment of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, many people with HIV are now living a normal lifespan and advancing toward ages when physical and cognitive declines emerge. It is not known, however, whether treated HIV infection carries a liability for accelerated aging and signs of frailty or whether common comorbidities, notably alcohol use disorder (AUD), contribute to further decline. Elucidation of brain alterations associated with cognitive and motor deterioration in people aging with HIV will advance our understanding of underlying pathology and lend insight into prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Breast cancers are poorly immunogenic, which significantly hampers breast cancer immunotherapy. The finding that DN T cells can inhibit tripe-negative breast cancer growth is novel and has not been explored. Deciphering the cellular and molecular mechanism of how DN T cells orchestrate antitumor immune response in breast cancer will fundamentally advance our knowledge in tumor immunology and allow us to develop more effective DN T cell-based cancer immunotherapy for breast cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of blood-based biomarkers to test for the earliest stages of Alzheimer’s Disease has significant potential to improve care, by allowing affordable, accessible, and non-invasive testing to identify patients at risk for cognitive impairment in primary care. Primary care providers and patients will face new challenges in deciding whether and when to use blood biomarker tests in their patients. This study seeks to understand how decisions about diagnosing cognitive complaints are made, and to use healthcare engineering approaches to design and test a communication intervention to support decisions about blood biomarker testing in primary care.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This career development award supports the transition to independence for a veterinary scientist with an interest in reproduction/contraception. In this application, our goal is to 1) demonstrate that extracellular vesicles (EVs) display tropism toward their tissue of origin and 2) establish gene editing by EVs loaded with CRISPR-cas9 ribonucleoproteins in vitro and in vivo in a mouse model. The findings of the proposed studies may lead to a novel, non-surgical, permanent contraceptive for women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Information is believed to be encoded at the cellular level through alterations in synaptic weights, and changes in connections between neurons are correlated with structural modifications of spines, such as growth or elimination. Additional forms of plasticity also impinge on these structures, such as homeostatic modulation of synaptic strength. In this proposal, we will use two-photon imaging and glutamate uncaging to test a variety of plasticity mechanisms at individual spines and between groups of spines, to understand with high precision how information is physically stored in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Debilitating pain, a hallmark of tissue injury and neuropathy, is an unmet clinical challenge in heterotopic ossification (HO) that occurs following orthopedic surgery and traumatic injuries. With an aim at developing new strategies to manage injury-induced chronic pain and pathological HO, we will use novel preclinical models to elucidate the mechanisms downstream of active sensory neuron-specific ACVR1, mechanisms that may be shared by other chronic pain and musculoskeletal injury conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Sepsis is a global healthcare problem with high incidence and mortality rates, responsible for 20% of deaths worldwide. The goal of this program is to develop an ultra-sensitive, highly selective, and portable solid-state nanopore sensing platform to profile sepsis protein biomarkers in clinical samples and take advantage of a panel of protein markers instead of one specific biomarker as currently done in the clinical setting for rapid and more accurate sepsis early diagnosis and prognosis. Success in this endeavor will be followed by extensive work to construct multi-channel nanopore measurement systems for high-throughput sepsis diagnosis, which should have a broad impact on a variety of areas such as clinical diagnosis, pharmaceutical industry, biosensing, and nanotechnology, offering the potential to lead to remarkable improvement in many facets of human life and society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiac sympathetic overexcitation-related fatal arrhythmia is the most common cause of death in patients with chronic heart failure (CHF). However, concerns about the safety and tolerability of current therapies, such as surgical procedures and medications, are emerging as a limitation to their prescriptions in the clinic. This project will introduce a novel therapeutic strategy using an optogenetic technique to restore CHF-induced cardiac sympathetic overexcitation, and observe whether this strategy reduces cardiac arrhythmia and mortality in animals with CHF, which will provide a novel clinical intervention to avoid the limitation of current therapies and improve prognosis and quality of life in patients with CHF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Development of an UNC13A antisense oligonucleotide treatment for ALS and FTD Project Narrative Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD) are complex diseases that result from many diverse causes. While there are currently no drugs that slow the progression of ALS or FTD, most of the new promising therapeutic strategies are focused narrowly on modifying the specific genetic mutations known to cause disease, however these treatments won’t work for the vast majority (>80% in ALS) of patients for whom the genetic cause of their disease is not known. Therefore, AcuraStem’s focus has been to develop treatments that can work for all ALS and FTD patients, including those for whom the genetic factors driving their disease have yet to be discovered - a large population with urgent unmet need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Dysfunction of prefrontal cortex has been implicated a wide array of neuropsychiatric disorders, including obsessive-compulsive disorder, mood disorders, attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder and addiction. The proposed research on the role the prefrontal cortex in attention and value-based decision will have clear implications for mental health. For example, a better understanding of the representation of cognitive processes in PFC could open the door to more targeted stimulation that uses decoded cognitive states to control the application of stimulation.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative There is rapidly growing evidence that the health and development of the child and adult can be traced to early environmental influences, but fundamental questions remain about which specific early exposures confer risk and by what mechanisms. We pool three Rochester-based cohort studies and collect a new pregnancy cohort to add to and extend the NIH ECHO program into a second phase. We will institute practices to maximize retention of existing participants, ensure recruitment of diverse new pregnant/preconception participants, implement the ECHO Cohort Protocol with high fidelity, and lead analyses of novel and solution-oriented research that will yield robust recommendations for promoting child health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Overall The UCSD Center Core Grant for Vision Research will provide core services and resources to enhance and accelerate the productivity and impact of vision research at UCSD. These resources will be used to foster collaboration among faculty from the Jacobs School of Engineering, Halicioglu Data Science Institute, Institute for Genomic Medicine, and the Departments of Ophthalmology, Neurosciences, Biomedical Informatics, Pharmacology and Psychology to bring us closer to our goal of the prevention and cure of blinding eye diseases such as glaucoma, macular degeneration and diabetic retinopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Overall: Project Narrative Frailty is an age-related syndrome of multisystemic decline which confers vulnerability to many other adverse outcomes including loss of independence. This OAIC is designed to foster high quality research which will identify etiologies of frailty and develop clinical and prevention strategies that will improve function, health and independence for millions of older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The Deep South Resource Center for Minority Aging Research (RCMAR) is designed to enhance the size and diversity of the scientific workforce advancing the fields of minority aging and health disparities. We are a research-based, mentoring partnership of four academic institutions working together to recruit investigators from under-represented backgrounds, provide education in aging and health disparities research, guide career development through collaborative mentoring, and sustain progress to successful, independent research careers. The research focus of the Deep South RCMAR is on reducing health disparities between Black/ African American and White older adults in the Deep South.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Algorithms continue to proliferate in the health care system, often with dire consequences for marginalized groups. This research proposes building a framework for evaluating the social impact of algorithms in health care before they are deployed to avoid such harms using mathematical decision science modeling. Developing this open-source framework will have the potential for broad impact in reducing health care disparities with a flexible design to allow adaptation to many health settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The origination and progression of cancer remain largely unknown due to the lack of effective approaches for the comprehensive characterization of tumor heterogeneity. The goal of this project is to develop and validate a next-generation proteomics platform to enable the characterization of massive single cells based on microfluidic sample preparation and mass spectrometry. The new platform will allow us to assess the heterogeneity of tumor cells and their interactions with the microenvironment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative This project aims to identify developmental and biomedical markers of risk for autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in young children with Down syndrome to advance early screening procedures. This project will focus on two areas of potential ASD risk: (1) developmental presentation during early childhood and (2) co-occurring biomedical conditions. Results will inform revised recommendations regarding early ASD screening in children with Down syndrome ages 18 to 45 months, which will be disseminated to medical providers, interventionists, and researchers aiming to advance treatment for ASD and other co- occurring conditions associated with Down syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eye pain, which is associated with dry eye disease and other conditions, is difficult to manage and can lead to a significant loss in quality of life. Though nerve cells in the cornea play a role in eye pain, the exact processes are unknown. The focus of this grant is to understand corneal nerve cells in greater depth and thereby lay the groundwork for future identification of new drug targets to treat eye pain and dry eye disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The public health implications of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) in young adults is vast, and given limited therapies and the heterogeneity of affected individuals, there is an urgent and unmet need to identify tailored therapeutic targets for distinct at-risk populations. Androgens may reflect such target for the 10-15%, or nearly 10 million reproductive-aged women with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), a common endocrinopathy with classically elevated androgens, that is marked by early onset NAFLD and greater risk of NASH. In the proposed study, we will determine whether androgens are the driver of NASH severity and progression in PCOS and the mechanistic contributions of visceral fat and aberrant lipid metabolism to this process – findings that are directly relevant to future efficacy studies evaluating androgen modulation in these young women with early onset liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although obesity is a major risk factor for type 2 diabetes, only about 30% of obese patients develop diabetes due to their genetic risk. The current proposal identifies genetic variants that reduce a gene called ZC3H13, leading to impaired function of insulin-producing cells. The results may help develop tools to identify high-risk obese patients for diabetes prevention and early intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Thousands of critically ill adults require placement of an endotracheal tube in emergency departments each year, with up to one-in-five experiencing hypoxemia and one-in-forty experiencing cardiac arrest. Yet the optimal approach to providing bag-mask ventilation, the most effective tool in preventing hypoxemia, remains unknown in this setting. Therefore, we designed the SAFEty of bag-mask VENTilation in the ED (SAFE- VENTED) study, to determine the effect of bag-mask ventilation on hypoxemia during tracheal intubation in the ED and to provide critical preliminary data for a future, definitive, multicenter trial evaluating the effect of bag- mask ventilation on hypoxemia, aspiration, and clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research seeks to characterize the evolving dynamic relationships between childhood asthma, obesity, and neurodevelopmental outcomes, and the influencing and moderating factors that act that the child, family, and neighborhood levels. Taking an unbiased and intentional approach towards inclusivity, we will use innovative remote data collection and mobile labs to engage traditionally under-represented families and communities, and collect rich multi-level child health, neurodevelopment, and important contextual social, socioeconomic, and social inequity data. Leveraging the ECHO Cohort, and our own Cohort Study Site, we will take a team science approach to identify periods of peak risk and key moderating factors that impact child weight, asthma, and cognitive development, to improve health outcomes for all children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance Measuring the strength of patient antibody responses in clinical samples is important in cancer biology and diagnostics. We propose to develop an innovative high-throughput platform, in which we will marry the powerful DNA sequencing technology and immunoassay to assess antibody response to many hundreds of cancer related pathogens in many thousands of individuals simultaneously. This will create a fast, sensitive, low cost, robust research tool for early screening of pathogen induced cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Immunotherapy is a promising treatment for pediatric cancer that can improve outcomes while minimizing toxicity and the long-term adverse effects associated with other types of therapy. The success of this treatment requires more discovery-based researchers who aim to improve understanding of how pediatric cancer cells interact with the immune system, and translational researchers to refine immunotherapeutic approaches for use in early phase clinical studies. The Pediatric Immuno-Oncology and Immunotherapy training program is designed to provide integrated training in advanced research approaches in a clinical context to foster the development of the next generation of independent scientists leading the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Protein synthesis is essential in all domains of life. Our recent work has shown that deviations from the canonical model of translation are frequent and directly cause to human disease. This research program seeks to mechanistically define how non-canonical initiation and regulation occurs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: CALIFORNIA PACIFIC MED CTR RES INSTITUTE
PHR: The prevalence of Alzheimer disease (AD) is high and projected to increase. Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is common among the elderly (30-55%), and we and others have shown that older adults with OSA are at increased risk for dementia and AD. We propose a novel and flexible approach to treating OSA in cognitively normal older adults, and will test whether those successfully treated for OSA have slower decline in cognitive function, and improved AD biomarkers (measured in blood) compared to those who are untreated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Interception of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) by eradication dysplasia when detected in its precursor Barrett’s esophagus (BE) is required for a cancer whose rate has more than sextupled in the past three decades. Biomarkers that can a) effectively identify dysplasia and risk-stratify patients with BE who are at risk for progression to cancer and those who are not; and b) effectively identify those who are likely to recur after successful ablative therapy for dysplastic BE and those who are not will prevent unnecessary ablative therapy and minimize costs by decreasing the frequency of endoscopy after successful ablative therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Although vaccines have been effective at protecting against infectious diseases that pose serious threats to human health, they can also be limited when variants of the pathogen emerge, yielding lower neutralization efficacy, and requiring booster immunizations – consequences which are observed in the current COVID-19 global pandemic. This work aims to redesign conventional vaccines using hydrogels to improve their durability and breadth of immune response. Ultimately, successful implementation of this approach could provide a more effective immune response to the SARS-CoV-2 virus and its emerging variants and provide a general vaccine design strategy that could have broader applicability toward other infectious pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative There is an urgent need to adapt and implement effective tobacco cessation interventions in HIV care programs in low- and middle-income settings. This study will evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of an integrated varenicline and mobile behavioral intervention among smokers and dual tobacco users in HIV care in Chennai, India. Combining a scalable mobile health intervention with cost-effective pharmacotherapy could reduce the harmful impacts of tobacco among people living with HIV.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE The burden of bacterial infectious disease in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) is considerable and increasing at an alarming rate due to factors that are both different from and/or amplifications of those found in high income countries. A research training program leveraging and transferring the University of California Davis (UCD) unrivaled strengths in animal modeling of bacterial infection to generate a center of excellence in pre-clinical bacterial infection biology at the University of Cape Town (UCT), is urgently needed to establish pre-clinical research capacity to complement existing clinical research and, ultimately, tackle the key research needs required for regional control of devastating bacterial infections. A Fogarty research training program at UCT will allow us to train the next generation of researchers to acquire the advanced understanding and associated laboratory skills needed to develop animal models of bacterial infections of enormous local impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Older adults in rural communities disproportionately experience food and nutrition insecurity, which may contribute to urban/rural disparities in cardiovascular disease outcomes. The emergency food system, particularly food pantries, serve as a safety net for rural older adults who are ineligible for or underserved by government food assistance programs, but there are barriers to accessing this resource and it is particularly underutilized by older adults and in non-metropolitan areas. By co-producing research with stakeholders in the emergency food system and rural older adults, findings from this proposed project will inform interventions in the emergency food system to enhance food and nutrition security, improve dietary intake, and benefit rural older adults with cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Persons with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) have higher risk of developing fatty liver disease (NAFLD) than HIV-negative persons but the reasons for this discrepancy are not known. Changes in the intestinal microbiome may contribute to the development of NAFLD in persons with HIV (PWH) through impairment of barrier function of the intestinal wall and by producing metabolites that are harmful to the liver. This project will test the hypothesis that HIV-related NAFLD is associated with differences in the intestinal microbiome and that supplementation with probiotic and prebiotic fiber will lead to improvements in markers of NAFLD in PWH.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A large number of bacterial species produce a small molecule called c-di-AMP that regulates bacterial growth, stress response, and adaptation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: UPWARDS Training Program Public Health Relevance Statement/Project Narrative As a recognized leader in cancer research, MD Anderson Cancer Center is well poised to address the critical lack of diversity plaguing the cancer research workforce and educational pipeline via early intervention programs that foster sustained interest in cancer research for young scientists. Our comprehensive UPWARDS Training Program (Underrepresented Minorities Working Towards Research Diversity in Science) addresses major barriers deterring and preventing many minority students from pursuing and succeeding in graduate programs and in cancer research careers. The UPWARDS Training Program will cultivate high school and undergraduate minority scientists with the goal of increasing diversity in biomedical graduate programs and in the cancer research workforce through 1) minority-focused recruitment, 2) hands-on cancer research experiences, 3) a strong mentoring and career/professional development, 4) education and engagement of minority communities and younger generations in the STEM pipeline through outreach and community education activities, and 5) a rigorous assessment plan with dissemination of best practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal responds to NIMH Objective 4.2.c to develop “decision-support tools and technologies that increase the effectiveness and continuous improvement of mental health interventions” by leveraging the Family First Prevention Services Act (FFPSA) policy opportunity. First, a web-based platform to host (a) a decision-support tool and (b) automated facilitation for group decisions with the tool will be developed with state partners’ feedback. Next, decision makers leading their states’ FFPSA quality improvement efforts will be engaged to pilot a decision-support intervention comprised of the tool and live or automated facilitation, and to evaluate the implementation quality of evidence-based programs adopted with the decision-support intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Over 10 million Americans have peripheral arterial disease, a disease that, if left untreated, leads to amputation. This proposal seeks to develop and begin the commercialization of a novel and more robust treatment for this devastating disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic kidney disease (CKD) and Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) remain a major health problem that causes substantial disability and premature death. The University of Michigan George M. O'Brien Kidney Translational Resource Center will provide researchers the opportunity to utilize advanced technologies by providing the necessary infrastructure and tools to improve care of patients with AKI and CKD. Through its research cores, enrichment activities, and community outreach, it will serve as a national resource for enabling new discoveries and enhance scientific progress supporting cutting-edge basic, clinical and translational kidney research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Structural characterization of biomolecules important in human health and disease is crucial to under- standing how these molecules function, as well as to designing therapeutics. Structural methods that make use of vanishingly small crystals have the potential to revolutionize how we obtain highly detailed structural `snapshots' of biomolecules. This technology development proposal will enable fundamen- tal advances by developing pipelines for enhanced detection, imaging, and sample handling to enable these structural methods, accelerating our understanding of the molecules involved in many diseases and biological processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lethal exposure to organophosphate (OP) compounds, including household pesticides and chemical warfare nerve agents (CWNA), produces status epilepticus (SE) and leads to the development of chronic neurological morbidities. This project will conduct safety and pharmacokinetic studies of intramuscular verapamil and study its neuroprotective and anti-inflammatory actions in a rat model of DFP-SE. In addition, we will optimize VPM therapy and study its effect in improving long-term cognitive impairment and seizure outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: TITLE: Spatial Organization of the Oral Microbiome Project Narrative:  Bacteria colonizing the human mouth play important roles not only in oral health, but in systemic health and disease. This project addresses the key unsolved question of how micrometer-scale spatial organization of the oral microbiota is connected to its function. We will investigate how the spatial structure of bacterial communities affects their response to dietary nitrate, will determine whether bacteria function as clones or as complex mixtures of strains at micrometer scales, and will develop a new method for micrometer-scale imaging of the dynamics of multitaxon bacterial communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will use a comprehensive dataset of diverse Latinos from the Hispanic Community Health Study/Study of Latinos to characterize biological mechanism underlying the relationship between sleep and incident cardiometabolic and neurocognitive outcomes. We will identify and construct metabolomics and methylation biomarkers of sleep phenotypes and study how these biomarkers associate with health and disease outcomes. We will study how sleep modifies effects of polygenic risk scores on outcomes and quantify the potential reduction in risk due to intervention on sleep and the resulting modification of omics pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Fetal brain-derived signals in the blood of pregnant women represent a way to get a snapshot of fetal brain health during development, but analyzing these signals requires highly sensitive technology. Our proposed studies will use our newly developed highly sensitive flow technologies to analyze these particles in women with healthy pregnancies and in women using opioid drugs. This will allow us to develop biomarkers to determine if newborns exposed to opioid drugs in utero will need treatment for neonatal abstinence syndrome.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project uses a piglet model of Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD), a pediatric disease affecting the hip, to determine the cell signaling changes that underlie tissue damage observed on the microscopic level and with MRI. By learning about the cell signaling, we will better understand the biology of the disease and we can determine whether a particular treatment that is effective in adults might be appropriate in children with LCPD. The children most likely to benefit are those that have a growth disturbance secondary to this disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE Disparities in kidney health are profound; and for decades, have been documented for socially marginalized populations, yet little progress has been made to mitigate them. The overarching goal of the Johns Hopkins O’Brien Center to Advance Kidney Health Equity is to serve as a national resource for investigators conducting pre-clinical (basic), clinical or population health research addressing kidney health disparities, and make recommendations to inform strategies, interventions, and approaches aimed at achieving kidney health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed longitudinal study will provide a comprehensive picture of the biological underpinnings and the sequence of events that increase the risk of obesity and type 2 diabetes in children who were exposed in utero to mothers with gestational diabetes and/or obesity during pregnancy. The proposed work will contribute critical knowledge to breaking the vicious cycle of maternal-child obesity and type 2 diabetes that is contributing to one of the fastest growing global health problems.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will develop and validate a novel behavioral outcome measure, the Behavior Inventory for Down Syndrome (BIDS) for children and adolescents with Down syndrome, in both English and Spanish. Current clinical trials are plagued by the dearth of clinical outcome measures appropriate and sensitive for individuals with Down syndrome. As our field continues to develop new pharmaceutical and clinical interventions, our project will support this work and have an impact on the 400,000 individuals with Down syndrome living in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) such as gonorrhea, chlamydia, and trichomoniasis are common in sub- Saharan Africa, and if left untreated they can increase the risk of HIV infection and lead to severe impacts on reproductive health. The proposed research will leverage the infrastructure of a clinical trial in rural South Africa to develop and evaluate a community-based method of screening for STIs among adolescents and young adults living with and at risk for HIV. We will measure uptake, acceptability, and process measures of the STI screening strategy in this population to inform future efforts to evaluate the effectiveness and implementation of scaled-up STI screening programs in South Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Since its inception, the Center for AIDS Prevention Studies (CAPS) has been at the forefront of conducting theory-driven, rigorous research to prevent new HIV infections, improve health outcomes among those infected and reduce significant HIV-related health disparities. The Center will build on its long and successful history of providing critical support to its cadre of world-class scientists that conduct interdisciplinary research to achieve an end to the HIV epidemic. .

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly 2 million of the 3 million women who labor and deliver each year in the United States receive supplemental oxygen in labor in response to electronic fetal monitoring. Despite the theoretic goal of administering oxygen to the mother to improve fetal hypoxia and to prevent adverse neonatal outcomes or operative delivery for fetal concerns, there is no high quality evidence to support this practice. The proposed multicenter randomized trial has important public health implications because it will yield clinically applicable data for managing fetal monitoring during labor, minimizing neonatal morbidity among full-term infants and operative deliveries associated with short and long-term maternal morbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health, because antibiotic resistance of bacterial pathogens is one of the greatest public health challenges of our time. As the emergence of resistance is outpacing the development of small-molecule antibiotics, this project aims to design new antimicrobial peptides against bacterial pathogens with innovative integration of computational, chemical, and biological approaches. These studies will provide a deeper understanding into the molecular mechanisms of antimicrobial peptides and provide new capacity to discover novel therapeutics to treat dangerous bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide is the second leading cause of death among U.S. children: suicide attempts are common, costly, and preventable, and reduction in youth suicide is a national and international priority area. Computational approaches to predict risk of future suicide attempts using medical records have emerged as a promising means to address the crisis of youth suicide by identifying children who could benefit from early, evidence- based intervention before suicidal behavior occurs or escalates. This study seeks to improve detection and prediction of emergency department visits for suicide attempts among children aged 10 to 17 by newly adapting a computational method applied to existing medical records (electronic health record phenotyping), and then assessing the perceived added clinical benefit of an electronic health record-integrated personalized risk prediction software prototype among potential end users.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Sleep is an extremely conserved drive across the animal kingdom, but its function remains a mystery. We hypothesize that one of the evolutionary conserved functions of sleep is to influence gene expression and chromatin regulation. This proposal will utilize state of the art single-cell genomic technology to define, for the first time, sleep-dependent transcriptional and epigenetic programs conserved between two distantly related vertebrate species: Mouse and Zebrafish.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In managed long-term care, care coordinators (i.e., registered nurses and social workers) periodically communicate with the patients over the telephone to ensure that they receive care congruent with the patient’s health needs. These verbal communications between patients with heart failure and care coordinators may include clues on risk factors for hospitalizations and emergency department visits. With cutting-edge artificial intelligence techniques, this project aims to examine whether audio-recorded verbal telephone communication (i.e., verbal communication) can be analyzed and utilized to improve risk prediction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative New technologies, methods and models are needed to advance our scientific understanding of how the nervous system maintains the surface of the eye. We will apply several new technologies, animal models, and methods to study molecular, cellular, and functional interactions across the surface of the eye and regions controlling it. We will compare how these interactions change under inflammatory and pain conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The Cancer Research Scholars Program (CRSP) will equip outstanding undergraduate students with research skills applicable across the cancer continuum, as well as skills in professionalism, cultural competence and team science that will enable them to thrive in cutting-edge cancer research graduate programs and cancer career pathways. By creating and engaging faculty as part of CRSP's Cancer Mentor Network in our innovative educational and underserved, communityengaged field experiences, we will empower future collaboration between scholars and mentors across the cancer continuum and encourage mutually beneficial community outreach and community-tailored education activities that will meaningfully inform and inspire their future research choices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study aims to apply empirically supported implementation science strategies, including task shifting, audit and feedback, and eHealth clinical decision support to integrate management of cardiovascular disease risk factors and cardiometabolic complications of HIV within a robust HIV service delivery platform in Lusaka, Zambia. We will use established implementation science theories, strategies, and constructs to implement an adapted version of the evidence-based WHO Package of essential noncommunicable disease interventions (WHO PEN) using non-physician health workers, and rigorously evaluate the intervention using a pragmatic, stepped-wedged trial design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bone marrow transplantation can cure many cancers, blood disorders and metabolic or genetic diseases; however, it can be accompanied by life-threatening pulmonary complications. Respiratory failure can be extremely severe, carries a mortality rate up to 60%, and has little directed treatment outside of supportive care. We propose to study a novel method to predict which patients are at the highest risk to develop respiratory failure using objective biomarkers that may allow for early identification of risk, development of new drugs for respiratory failure based on the biologic pathways identified with biomarkers, and ultimately targeted therapies to prevent the occurrence of respiratory failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose a Center Without Walls focused on deciphering the mechanisms of the neurodegenerative disease FTLD-TDP. We have brought together experts in neurology, human genetics, pathology, and genomics to focus intensely on an exciting new role of cryptic exon splicing as a key driver of neurodegeneration. We have discovered dozens of novel cryptic exon splicing events in FTLD-TDP and these will inform disease mechanisms, serve as sensitive biomarkers, and point to new therapeutic targets for this devastating human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People receiving chimeric antigen receptor T cell therapy (CARTx) for cancer treatment are often given immunoglobulin G (IgG) replacement therapy (IGRT) to prevent infections; however, no data support this practice in this patient population, and IGRT requires careful stewardship given national shortages, potential side effects, and high expense. To establish the risks and benefits of this frequently used infection-prevention strategy, we will conduct a randomized, placebo-controlled trial of IGRT in CARTx patients. We will compare infection rates, antibody levels, health resource utilization, and CAR-T cell kinetics and function among participants who do and do not receive IGRT to establish evidence-based data to guide the use of IGRT in the rapidly growing population of CARTx recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite many years of research that have focused almost exclusively on patient-level barriers to care (despite the importance of positive patient-provider relationships in HIV care engagement), there are still significant gaps in the number of persons living with HIV (PLWH) who are fully engaged in care, making the HIV epidemic difficult to control. Nurses who provide care in the public sector in South Africa (SA) are the frontline providers of HIV care and experience extremely high levels of stress as a consequence of limited resources, hindering their ability to provide effective care, a situation that has been exacerbated by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. This study will tailor an established stress management and resilience-enhancing intervention to meet the needs and improve the well-being of nurses providing HIV care in the public sector in SA, and then evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of our program, with the goal of developing a scalable intervention that could be used across similar settings worldwide to improve the treatment and care of PLWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Older women have worse outcomes from breast cancer treatment, in part due to under treatment and toxicities. Exercise and protein intake support, in combination, are a promising intervention to improve these outcomes. We propose a randomized controlled trial to assess the effects of a multicomponent, hybrid telehealth (TH) exercise and protein intake support (the THRIVE Intervention) on received dose intensity, incidence and severity of chemotoxicities, functional status, muscle mass, and patient reported outcomes in 270 breast cancer patients age ≥ 65 receiving neo/adjuvant chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative In recent years it has become increasingly evident that the gut microbiome, the resident population of bacteria in the intestines, plays a key role in health and homeostasis throughout the body including the brain. Our laboratory has found that changes in the gut microbiome can alter the development of drug craving in animal models of relapse and affect how genes are expressed in the brain. These studies will identify how specific manipulations of the microbiome and its molecular byproducts affect brain and behavior, and will provide strategies for targeting the gut microbiome to reduce substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Dysfunction and exhaustion of T cells is a major barrier in successful immunotherapy for cancer. We propose to investigate the molecular mechanism by which the novel Zbtb42/T-bet complex regulates effector function vs. exhaustion of CD8+T cells. Our studies could lead to clinical trials to overcome the current limitations of CAR-T cell therapy for cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative  Interpreting the world around us requires putting together current sensory experiences and our prior experience. It has been known for a long time that such prior core knowledge of the world plays a critical role in our perceptions. Yet, the mechanisms by which such experiences are merged with sensory stimuli remain poorly understood and elusive. Here we combine behavioral measurements, direct recordings of neural data from inside the human brain, invasive electrical stimulation, and computational models to investigate the neural circuits that combine the senses and prior experiences during visual search. There are multiple neurological and psychiatric conditions that are characterized by abnormal top-down signaling, conditions that remain poorly understood and where successful treatment will necessitate deep understanding of their mechanistic basis. The current proposal combines state-of-the-art technologies, methods and models to tackle these questions and begin to shed light on one of the most challenging mysteries of the mind, the interplay between the senses and high-level cognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Our recently published studies have identified the protein Fidgetin-like 2 (FL2) as a novel regulator of microtubule dynamics. With targeted FL2-depletion, there is accelerated nerve regeneration and improved erectile function outcomes in animal models of radical prostatectomy (RP). The present proposal expands these studies by investigating mechanisms by which FL2-depletion enhances nerve regeneration through the recruitment of cells involved in nerve repair and determining the extent to which targeted FL2-depletion improves erectile function outcomes in rat models of nerve injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to perform research and development to refine and extend a commercial application that can predict an individual's cognitive and mobility-based health using patterns learned from sensor data collected from a smart watch, and effectively and efficiently present this information to the caregiver. The application also provides opportunities to learn about healthy brain behavior and to track the integration of these behaviors into a person's routine. This research is relevant to public health because these technologies can extend the functional independence of our aging society through technology-assisted health self-management, reduce caregiver burden, and improve quality of life.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: For infants admitted to a Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU), successful oral feeding is a requirement for discharge home, but preterm infants often struggle with oral feeding skills largely due to problems coordinating swallowing with breathing due to neurodevelopmental immaturities. Our technology is a clinical decision support tool that optimizes feeding of the preterm infant as it quantifies the complexity of breathing patterns giving clinicians a tool to better inform decisions related to oral feeding advancement. Creating technology that helps infants feed better so they can go home sooner promotes parent-infant interactions and optimizes infant development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The standard of care is ineffective for a subset of the CF patient population. Direct gene modulation via gene therapy, despite a highly safe profile with partial therapeutic effects after successful delivery in CF patients, remains limited due to viral-based methods. This proposal intends to develop a non-viral gene therapy method to treat cystic fibrosis that will move a novel non-viral platform one step closer to FDA IND filing and commercialization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Over 38 million people in the world live with HIV and are at greater risk of developing cardiovascular diseases, even when receiving treatment for HIV. Because people living with HIV receive medications that affect the body’s metabolism towards developing cardiovascular diseases, we will use state-of-the-art methodologies to determine the relationship between exposure from these drugs and important metabolism markers. We will identify the effects of drug exposure and pioneer a new area of HIV/AIDS research and more reliably predict the development of cardiovascular diseases for those living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to explore how neuromodulation, specifically neurotensin, plays a critical role in valence assignment in the basolateral amygdala, a site identified as a divergence point in circuits mediating positive and negative valence. This project will test the hypotheses that neurotensin directs valence-specific information to the appropriate downstream BLA projections during valence processing and modulates compulsive cocaine- seeking behavior. The proposed research project will broaden our understanding of the fundamental neuromodulatory mechanisms underlying valence processing and motivated behavior and identify neurotensin as a novel target for treating valence-disorders including substance use disorders.
