IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder with severe impairment of memory, cognition and executive functions that has a tremendous health and economic burden as more people live longer. Neurovascular unit (NVU) damage, blood-brain barrier (BBB) dysfunction and extracellular matrix (ECM) disruption play a key etiological role in AD progression; yet the contribution of genetic and/or environmental risk factors for brain vascular pathology is unclear. This project will focus on AD genetic risk factor and isogenic control astrocytes, a key component of the NVU, and how they are altered in function including after being chemically aged in both monolayer culture and 3D multicellular NVU systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Cross-species transmission events from animal hosts gave rise to several deadly human pathogens including the recent SARS-CoV-2. Simian Immunodeficiency Viruses (SIV) in West and Central Africa gave rise to HIV-1 and HIV-2 from chimpanzee SIVcpz and sooty mangabey SIVsm, respectively. To prepare for future incidents such as these, the main goal of our proposed studies is to evaluate select SIVs, namely SIVrcm from red capped mangabeys and SIVmnd from mandrills for their potential for human transmission using a human surrogate hu- mouse animal model. This will be the first time these above viruses will be examined in an in vivo setting and the results from here will contribute to our knowledge on the initial steps in cross-species transmission and lay the ground work for using this model for evaluating other potentially zoonotic viral candidates in the future.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Down's syndrome (DS), the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability, is associated with a wide range of cognitive and behavioral impairments. Through the use of cutting edge MRI technology that allows us to look at the shape, function, and connections within the brain, we will be able to study and better understand early brain development in infants with DS. Working toward the goal to be able to assess the impact of specific early intervention therapies that are most helpful in improving the developmental outcomes of children with DS. This study mirrors and expands on the study designs and techniques that were developed to study infants with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), Fragile X, and typically developing infants, and will allow us to further our understanding of maturation patterns of infant brains that we can apply to DS, ASD, Fragile X, and other disabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services has targeted reducing heart failure hospital readmissions as a major need, and recent clinical studies have shown that these readmissions can be significantly reduced through rapid treatment up-titration after heart failure diagnosis. Unfortunately, the technological infrastructure needed to support rapid treatment up-titration is insufficient for most health-care providers. This SBIR Phase 1 project will provide initial animal demonstration of the first ever factory-calibrated continuous molecular monitor for NT-proBNP and potassium in heart failure patients, for reducing hospital readmissions and adverse events during up-titration of heart failure treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Functional MRI (fMRI) is the most widely-used tool to measure human brain function and has contributed enormously to human neuroscience, however fMRI does not measure neuron firing rather it detects brain activity by measuring changes in blood flow in the brain that delivers oxygen to the neurons. These changes in blood flow that occur in the smallest blood vessels near to the neurons provide more accurate information about which neurons are firing, whereas it is more difficult to know the location of neuron firing when observing changes blood flow within the largest vessels, yet standard fMRI methods mix together signal from large and small blood vessels. Here we seek to develop MRI technology that can enable the observation of blood flow changes exclusively from the smallest blood vessels, and we will use this to show that these changes are faster than those found in the largest blood vessels and so our technology can therefore be used to better track rapid changes in neuron firing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: In sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), despite major successes scaling up antiretroviral therapy (ART) for people living with HIV (PLWH), deaths continue to occur in 5-10% of PLWH during the first year after ART initiation. A significant number of these early deaths are likely attributed to lymphoproliferative disorders including lymphoma and multicentric Castleman disease, comorbidities caused by co-infections with Epstein-Barr virus and Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus. In this project, I propose to address these gaps in knowledge by 1) assessing multifactorial causes of diagnostic delay for cancer broadly and lymphoproliferative disorders specifically in Malawi, 2) comprehensively describe clinical characteristics and diagnoses in PLWH presenting with lymphadenopathy in community HIV clinics, and 3) assessing utility of novel molecular diagnostics to speed the diagnoses at an earlier stage and less invasively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Rare genetic diseases are an emerging global public health priority that disproportionately affect children, causing early childhood death and long-term morbidity in the survivors. Inadequate access to genetics evaluation and genomic testing in the Hispanic minorities living along the Texas-Mexico has marginalized the most vulnerable pediatric group. This proposal aims to transform the current clinical practice paradigm by leveraging an internally designed web-based model of delivery of care to provide timely evaluation and genomic sequencing for improving genetic health of less resourced children with rare disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to shorten the diagnostic odysseys for rare genetic diseases, which can last for years, by using electronic health record-based identification of patients likely to have such disorders. In the first phase of the project, we will test out our existing algorithms for infants and children with a pilot study and also attempt to improve those algorithms. During the second phase of the project, we will develop algorithms for similar purposes but for adolescent and adult patients as well as deploy our algorithms in a different, non-academic health care setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will lead to the digital standardisation of chemistry from analog synthesis and discovery of both known and unknown molecules of biological interest on any compatible hardware using a new programming language based upon our open-source chemical description language (χDL). We will leverage our expertise and invention of the Chemputer, a programmable chemical synthesis and discovery engine, to develop an architecture that can bridge commercial, bespoke, and new automation technologies and showcase this with specific hardware developments that will help create the missing link between automation workflows. We will apply our language and hardware pipeline that incorporates novel separation and workup technologies, as well as in-line spectroscopy, for the real-time synthesis, screening, and discovery of new chemical compounds for drug discovery

This technology will expand the capabilities of the NCATS ASPIRE laboratory, where it will provide unparalleled access to previously unexplored chemical space with potential to accelerate drug discovery. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a worldwide public health problem, occurring in ~25% of the global adult population. Despite major investments by the pharmaceutical industry, there are no approved drugs for the treatment of NAFLD, reflecting the heterogeneous pathophysiology of this disease. We have begun implementing an all human-iPSC liver microphysiology system (MPS) platform to test drugs/drug combinations as potential NAFLD therapeutics. There is a critical need to develop and implement high content and throughput NAFLD MPS models based on iPSC-derived cells that demonstrate maximal reproducibility. The goal of this proposal is the development of a combined high throughput and high content NAFLD experimental model for a primary screen of predicted drugs and optimal combinations using human, patient-specific iPSC- derived liver cells bioprinted in transwell plates will transform the approach to NAFLD drug discovery to precision medicine. The more detailed analysis of the best drugs and drug combinations in the bioprinted version of the vLAMPS models will refine the selection of drugs/combinations for select patient cohorts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: NARRATIVE To overcome the limitations of no existing drugs against preterm birth as well as challenges in conducting clinical trials during pregnancy, we will develop an in vitro model: a 3D bioprinted feto-maternal interface (part of uterine tissue) tissue chip that can model the disease state of pregnancy. In collaboration with the National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences (NCATS), the tissue chip model capable of conducting high- throughput screening of drug libraries will be utilized to test up to 1,000 drug compounds for their usefulness in treating pregnant women and their fetuses and for testing potential adverse effects of the drug compounds. Successful development of this high-throughput model will allow testing of many drugs currently in use for other clinical indications, but not for pregnant women due to uncertainty of their adverse effects on pregnancy, as well as initiating discovery of new drugs that can reduce the risk of preterm birth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), a biomedical prevention intervention with proven effectiveness at preventing HIV transmission, is not widely accessed or used by cisgender Black women (CBW) in Houston/Harris County who are at significant risk for HIV through heterosexual sex. We propose to develop an innovative video-log (vlog) series intervention with single sessions that are specific to both CBW and healthcare providers (HCPs) of CBW, and assess its feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary impact through a pilot randomized controlled trial and a social media campaign. The vlog series will leverage relatable, culturally competent, and engaging narratives (i.e. stories) to increase willingness of 1) CBW in the Houston area to access and use PrEP and 2) HCPs in the Houston area to prescribe and refer PrEP to CBW.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Recent advances by the two major long-read sequencing companies, PacBio and Oxford Nanopore, have enabled complete sequencing of the human genome and as a result, many major genomic research programs and genetic testing companies are racing to implement long-read whole genome sequencing (WGS) as a standard of care for genetic testing in the near term, and for comprehensive precision medicine programs in the future. For such an effort to succeed, long read sequencing workflows must be adapted to use high- throughput automated liquid handling equipment to further reduce sequencing costs, to improve workflow reproducibility, and to eliminate sources of operator error. This grant proposal seeks to accelerate implementation of long-read sequencing in precision medicine (and genomic research broadly) by creating a high-throughput, flexible, cost-effective size-selection system for DNA sequencing library preparation that is easy to integrate with standard liquid handling robotics.

PHR: The Congenital and Perinatal Infections Consortium (CPIC) brings together a group of 28 study sites that have a longstanding history of research in pediatric infectious diseases with community and industry stakeholders. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: 8. Project Narrative . Cardiac arrest is a common and devastating cardiac and neurological emergency affecting almost 400,000 victims in the US every year, many of whom are successfully resuscitated but then die in the hospital or are left with severe disability from injury to the brain during the cardiac arrest. Immediate temperature control and cooling of comatose survivors of cardiac arrest is now commonly used to try to reduce the brain injury, but it remains uncertain whether it is truly effective, how long a survivor of cardiac arrest should be cooled, and which patients are more likely to benefit. This clinical trial proposes to first determine whether longer durations of cooling improve recovery better than shorter durations, and secondly to determine the best duration of cooling, in comatose patients resuscitated from either of two different types of cardiac arrest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Recent data suggest that first-degree relatives of patients with T1D have a smaller pancreas than control subjects, including those without islet- autoantibodies. This application proposes a collaborative, multicenter TrialNet study of relative pancreas volume and morphological changes using noninvasive radiology with correlations to β-cell and acinar cell functions and genotype. The data and analyses emanating from this multicenter study have the potential to greatly improve our understanding of the endocrine-exocrine interactions during the natural history of T1D and may thus change the way we view T1D pathogenesis, which in turn, will impact our ability to affect clinical intervention of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The identification of new antibiotics with activity against multidrug-resistant pathogens is currently a critical unmet medical need. Although many discovery programs deprioritized natural products as a source of new antibiotics due to high rediscovery rates, it is now clear that the global microbiome encodes a very large, previously inaccessible, reservoir of novel natural products that can serve as starting points for the development of new antibiotics. The work described here is designed to continue our development of methods for accessing novel natural products from soil metagenomes and increasingly focus on applying these methods to the discovery of new bioactive natural products, in particular, new antibiotics with activity against multidrug- resistant pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Our studies are focusing on a recently discovered pathway of innate immunity called the “Complosome” that is present inside of most, if not all, cells. Because it is so new, we are addressing fundamental questions about who are the key players, what are their functions and how is this system disrupted by disease (as in autoimmunity and cancer). Such knowledge is likely to lead to increased understanding of undesirable inflammatory responses and identification of novel therapeutic targets.

PHR: In this project we will assess how temperature impacts selective and stochastic alterations to WNV populations during systemic mosquito infection. We also will explore how virus particle aggregates and infection of individual cells by multiple WNV genotypes may influence the amount and type of genetic diversity that is maintained in the virus population. This project leverages over 15 years’ worth of WNV and ZIKV research and makes innovative use of new molecular tools that we have developed as part of this project.

PHR: Health relevance: Despite forty years of research on language impairments in children, information on effective treatment is sparse. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to develop tools for analyzing data from intense X-ray sources in order to obtain information concerning the structure of muscle. By understanding how muscle works, and how it is controlled, it is possible to determine changes to muscle structure and performance due to genetic changes associated with inherited muscle diseases, including heart diseases. Such understanding can provide clues as to how to treat these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Acute chemical exposure to organophosphorus compounds arising from terrorist attacks or accidental poisonings pose a serious threat to human health, but current treatment strategies are not suitable for administering to large civilian populations. The goal of this research is to develop a cost-effective organismal platform using planarians for screening of possible therapeutics for treatment of acute toxicity induced by organophosphorus compounds. Cost-effective, rapid screening platforms, such as the one developed here, promise to accelerate the discovery of new therapeutics to better prevent against mass casualties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will (1) improve the safety of concussed individuals and the general population that use roadways, (2) guide the practices of health professionals, and (3) substantiate the work of policy-makers by providing strong evidence-based recommendations for managing post-concussion driving. This translational study is relevant to the mission of both the NIH and NINDS because it provides fundamental knowledge about how brain injury burdens concussed drivers, while also identifying which widely used clinical outcomes are associated with post-concussion driving impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Candida auris is an emerging fungal pathogen that is notable for its resistance to commonly used antifungal therapy. We have discovered that C. auris contains sugar molecules on its cell surface that are unique and that are not found in other fungal pathogens. In this research we will develop a prototype C. auris vaccine based on this novel carbohydrate and we will evaluate the efficacy of the vaccine in mouse models of C. auris infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Risk of smoking cigarettes depends on interactions between environmental factors, age, and genetics. This project uses advanced long-read genome sequencing and unbiased pangenomic analysis to fully identify genetic variants in the hybrid rat diversity panel. Combined with nicotine self-administration data from this panel, our ad- vanced systems genetics approach will define causal linkages between DNA variants and key nicotine-dependent behaviors including initial acquisition and motivation to take nicotine, withdrawal from nicotine dependence, and nicotine seeking under conditions that model aspects of human relapse to smoking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Allowing the use of low frame rate videos for cell tracking will enable researchers to study cell dynamics at scale, multiplying the number of experimental treatments tracked concurrently, and reducing the number of experimental artifacts generated. This proposal focuses on cell displacement prediction to overcome the limitations of current cell tracking approaches. Given the importance of studying cell dynamics, the results of our research will have very broad applicability in many areas of biomedical science, including developmental biology, drug discovery, and regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Overall Project Narrative: Emerging infectious diseases are diseases that have newly appeared or whose incidence has increased in the past years or could increase in the near future; many emerging diseases are also zoonotic. This COBRE application will form a thematic center focused on Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases (EZID) and will study virulence factors and host-pathogen interactions in both in vitro systems and in animal models, using basic and translational research approaches, with support from two multi-user core facilities. The overarching goal is to develop a unique, nationally and internationally recognized Research Center on Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases at Kansas State University.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In the United States, approximately 350,000 people suffer out-of-hospital cardiac arrest per year, and there is an urgent need to generate evidence on how to integrate effective treatments into a coordinated system of care at the community and state levels. Our study will test a customized strategic intervention program that focuses on community interventions to improve key process of care measures in the critical minutes after cardiac arrest. If successful, our intervention would provide a roadmap for communities throughout the United States to save lives and improve patient outcomes after cardiac arrest. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Disruptions to the process of eye formation can result in ocular birth defects and pediatric blindness; although some of the genetic causes of ocular birth defects have been identified, we still don’t have a good understanding of exactly how mutations in these genes cause visual system dysfunction. In this grant proposal we will study the function of the chromatin remodeling factor CHD7 during eye development; these studies are important because loss of expression of CHD7 causes CHARGE syndrome (also known as CHD7 disorder), a genetic disorder that results in defects in the eyes, ears, heart, brain, nose, and genitourinary system. The results of our experiments will help us better understand the chain of events that leads to abnormal eye formation during embryonic development, and this knowledge may improve the identification, management, and treatment of congenital sight-threatening diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will utilize a large (N=307,719) dataset from the UK Biobank cohort and will apply advanced causal machine learning methods, specifically the honest causal forest/policy tree, doubly robust adaptive LASSO, and Bayesian Adaptive Regression Trees (BART), to identify novel effect modifiers and heterogeneous subgroups for the relationship between statin use and the risk for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). This F31 application will help me to gain valuable training in causal machine learning methods and cognitive aging, while also pursuing my goal of becoming an independent investigator.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal tests the efficacy of a phone-based tobacco cessation intervention for people living with HIV (PLWH) in comparison to the standard of care (brief advice to quit) and nicotine replacement therapy (nicotine patches) in Uganda and Zambia. Our study will provide insight into the efficacy, feasibility, applicability, and affordability of delivering tobacco cessation interventions through health care professionals at HIV treatment centers in two countries with different tobacco use patterns, policy environments, and health care resources. The previously tested SMS-platform to be used in our study is uniquely positioned to be scaled in low- and middle-income countries worldwide, in which case rigorous research showing even modest success in reducing the prevalence of tobacco consumption among PLWH could confer substantial health and economic benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Komor – Project Narrative – “Development and Application of New Genome Editing Tools for the Functional Investigation of Genetic Variants of Uncertain Significance”  Our inability to interpret the clinical consequences of genetic variants discovered by sequencing remains a critical obstacle to the progress of precision medicine: out of the 4.6 million missense variants identified in the Genome Aggregation Database, over half are admitted to be variants of uncertain significance (VUS). New methods capable of interpreting VUS would not only enhance the efficacy of current therapies by better informing patient selection strategies, but also accelerate the development of new approaches to combat diseases with a genetic component. Here we propose the development of new genome editing tools and platforms that will allow researchers to functionally interrogate thousands of VUS individually, in combination, and in aggregate, to produce clinically-relevant information on how genetic variations cause human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: We and others have identified resident memory T cells in secondary lymphoid organs (SLO TRM). Despite their broad distribution after systemic infection in mice and seeming abundance in human lymph nodes, the roles of SLO TRM in immunity have not been investigated. This proposal will evaluate the abundance and microanatomical location of SLO TRM after diverse pathogen experience, the migratory fate and developmental potential of SLO TRM upon reactivation, and the protective functions of SLO TRM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ocular anterior chamber paracentesis (ACP) has the potential to transform the standard of care in ophthalmology. For decades ACP has saved countless patients from irreversible blindness by alleviating acutely elevated intraocular pressure, and now pioneering labs are recognizing aqueous humor as a reservoir rich in diagnostic and predictive biomarkers. Unfortunately, there is no instrument specifically designed for ACP; instead, off-the-shelf tuberculin syringes with excessively long needles and cumbersome handling are repurposed with serious risks of intraocular trauma, poorly controlled aspiration rates, unpredictable fluid volumes, and often require an assistant. To address this major and urgent unmet medical need, F Square Medical is developing and commercializing the first-ever instrument designed and optimized for ACP: Parasafe™.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research is relevant to public health because it seeks to advance our understanding of causes of birth defects. It investigates how physical and mechanical forces impact organogenesis, and specifically affect the vertebrate left-right organizer, as errors in left-right patterning are a common cause of birth defects. This project will identify mechanical mechanisms underlying organogenesis that may present new ideas to predict or prevent birth defects, and is therefore relevant to NIH’s mission to develop foundational knowledge to enhance health and reduce disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This proposal aims to determine whether the action potential operates as a mechanical, as well as electrical, pulse in myelinated axons. The planned research uses photoswitchable tethered ligands to control the mechanosensitive two-pore domain potassium channel TRAAK in order to investigate its contributions to action potential repolarization and propagation in myelinated axons of the optic nerve. This work has implications for the study of electric signaling, as a field, as well as for diseases of the node of Ranvier (e.g., multiple sclerosis, stroke, glaucoma).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Osteoporosis medications are extremely effective in reducing hip and spine fractures, however, their use has declined dramatically over the past decade, partially due to concerns about a rare adverse event called atypical femur fractures (AFF). Our project, which includes data from 3 large, population-based studies of AFF, will help identify women at particularly high or low risk for AFF, facilitating the development of prediction models and risk score tools. These tools will enable providers to individualize their recommendations to patients about the use of these important medications for managing osteoporosis, balancing AFF risk against osteoporosis-related fracture prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rotavirus remains a major source of morbidity and mortality in low- and middle-income countries, even despite the introduction of live oral rotavirus vaccines. In collaboration with researchers in Malawi and Ghana, we will use mathematical models combined with economic models to evaluate the potential impact and cost- effectiveness of different rotavirus vaccination strategies, including those based on next-generation neonatal and parenteral rotavirus vaccines. Our analysis will provide a validated platform for assessing the cost- effectiveness of different rotavirus vaccination strategies in low- and middle-income countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Relevance to public health: Adult stem cells maintain and rejuvenate tissues by producing new cells to augment and replace existing cells, and during aging, the activity of stem cells progressively declines, which contributes to age-related tissue degeneration. To understand this process and stimulate the development of new approaches to sustain stem cell activity and improve human health, I will define mechanisms of adult stem cell failure during aging in the germline of a small animal, Caenorhabditis elegans. The results will address fundamental gaps in our knowledge of adult stem cell exhaustion and advance the fields of stem cell and reproductive aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma is a complex, multifactorial disease characterized by a slow and progressive degeneration of the optic nerve, leading to visual impairment. Despite the widely appreciated disease relevance of neuroinflammation and mitochondrial dysfunction as critical pathogenic elements, the mechanisms underlying glia-mediated neuroinflammation and the contribution of compromised mitochondrial network and function in glaucoma remain unknown. The proposed study explores novel pathways of potential links between AIBP and neuroinflammation, cholesterol efflux and mitochondrial function, and develops new therapy for glaucoma

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is the causative agent of CMV retinitis (CMVR), which is known to cause blindness. In this grant, I propose to develop a computational model of HCMV lytic and persistent-like replication kinetics. The findings from this research will advance the understanding of HCMV biology and the pathogenesis of CMVR for both scientists and clinicians by providing (1) a dynamic computational model of the complex lytic replication cycle, and (2) predictive quantitation of the response of a persistence-like HCMV infection in adult retinal pigment epithelial cells to antivirals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will study different kinds of medical illustrations used in patient education materials to understand the impact these have on patient understanding and anxiety. We will also develop a conversational agent that can explain patient education documents to people, and evaluate different versions of the agent in an experiment to determine which version leads to the most learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Transcription is a necessary process for gene expression, which results in a copy of RNA from the DNA template. In some cases, the RNA can intertwine with the DNA, forming a structure called an “R-loop.” This project will explore how abnormal R-loop formation leads to severe DNA damage by utilizing unbiased genomics approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New technologies have identified translation from previously overlooked short open reading frames. Micropeptides translated from these open reading frames have been shown to contribute to important biological processes including cancer, development and inflammation. This project seeks to identify micropeptides that are important to innate immunity and inflammation, which may have important scientific and therapeutic, implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The growing need for identifying effective therapeutics for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) can be met by bettering our understanding of the biological mechanisms by which genetic variants modify disease risk. By combining human induced pluripotent stem cells and an innovative xenotransplantation method, this proposal seeks to investigate the impact of a candidate risk variant in the MS4A locus and its causal genes on the function of disease- implicated microglia. This study will provide a blueprint for translating findings of genomic studies from statistical associations to biological function and serve to elucidate the contribution of MS4A genes to disease susceptibility, suggesting a mechanism of action that can be used for future drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging causes a decline in neurogenesis and decreased ability for the brain to recover after injury and a better understanding of the processes that underlie this change would reveal new therapeutic targets which could be used to ameliorating age-related decline in stroke recovery, cognitive decline, and Alzheimer’s disease. This study is based on unbiased approaches to identify adhesion and migration genes and pathways that change with age that result in defects in neural stem cell adhesion and migration. It will functionally validate and perturb these genes or pathways, with the goal of improving neurogenesis and repair after stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Stroke is a leading cause of death, and social isolation, shown to increase mortality, has become a widespread exposure among the general population due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The goals of these studies are to identify sex differences, if any, in prior-SIS and stroke severity, to elucidate the mechanism by which prior-SIS affects stroke outcomes, and to identify potential therapeutic targets for severe stroke after a stressor such as social isolation. These goals are consistent with the mission of the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke, which is to find ways to ‘reduce the burden of neurological disease for all people’ through research on ‘the brain and nervous system’.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will test the novel hypothesis that aberrant vascular lipid metabolism is a component of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). To do so, I will identify the molecular changes to the brain vasculature in patients with AD and will then model these changes in mice to clarify their relevance to vascular function and AD pathophysiology. This study may provide meaningful insights into the role of the cerebral vasculature in dementias such as AD, and may reveal novel therapeutic avenues for patients with AD.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a severe disease with a delayed diagnosis and markedly elevated mortality. High-risk populations, such as those with known genetic defects, provide a unique opportunity to determine the features of susceptibility and resilience to PAH. This proposal will fundamentally overturn the prevailing understanding of PAH by creating molecularly-driven signatures of susceptibility and resilience, provide novel insight into disease severity, and potentially identify new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While healthcare advances have more than doubled the average human lifespan in the last century, the accompanying loss of learning and memory with age significantly compromises quality of life. Therefore, uncoupling pathways that regulate lifespan and healthspan is critical for mitigating the increasing rate of cognitive decline in aged individuals, of which there are few effective treatments available. The proposed research will use the nematode worm C. elegans as a model to discover conserved mechanisms that slow the decline of learning and memory with age, with the ultimate goal of identifying new drug targets that boost healthspan in higher organisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to determine the role of a novel and poorly understood population of inhibitory cells in a region of the brain known as the thalamus, which is critical for processing sensory information and controlling brain-wide rhythms. The short-term goal of this project is to determine how these cells process inputs to regulate activity within the thalamus. In the long-term, the results obtained from this study will advance our ultimate goal of understanding how mammals perceive sensory information, in addition to guiding the development and testing of targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Memory concerns are associated with lower quality of life and are the most common cognitive complaint amongst healthy older adults. False memory – remembering events differently than how they happened – and a bias toward semantic memory – memory for concepts – both increase across the lifespan, but it is not well understood how the bias toward semantic memory contributes to false memory increases. This proposal seeks to identify semantic contributions to false memory by directly linking semantic processing and neural pattern similarity to false memory in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Systematic cancer screening has led to a surge of cases of clinically invisible “dormant” tumors, raising the im- portant question for every diagnosed patient of whether a microscopic lesion poses a risk of becoming an inva- sive cancer or not. This project is motivated by a new theory of complex systems that explains their “tipping point” behaviors and uses a new scheme of single-cell resolution molecular profiling of minuscule tumor cell populations and tunable mouse tumors to study how tipping point dynamics drives a dormant tumor to become destabilized and become poised between staying dormant or “taking-off” and grow. The new approach could be used to detect when the dormant tumor enters the phase of instability that precedes an escape from dor- mancy to become clinical.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: HEALTH RELEVANCE The sense of smell plays a critical role in preferences and aversions for specific foods. The proposed research will combine machine learning techniques with high quality human psychophysics to create a model that can predict the smell of odorous molecules. This model will allow us to describe and control odors, which will increase our understanding of food preference and eating-related health and wellness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is known that cerebrovascular health is a significant risk factor for Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) dementia, the current leading cause of dementia worldwide. In this project, we will develop cerebrovascular health metrics from resting-state functional MRI data of the human connectome project to first understand cerebrovascular changes in a typical aging population and then apply these metrics to a large AD dataset. This project aims to develop reproducible measures of cerebrovascular health and then assess the association of these metrics with the cognitive impairments seen in AD dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The formation of protein amyloid fibrils is associated with over 30 human diseases, including Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, type II diabetes, and dialysis-related amyloidosis (DRA), but the molecular details of how these amyloids begin to form are not well understood, which limits our ability to treat these diseases. We intend to develop and apply new mass spectrometry based measurement tools that will yield new molecular-level insight into the early stages of amyloid formation by β-2-microglobulin, which is the protein associated with DRA. This new insight combined with new approaches to screen for amyloid inhibitors will allow us to discover potential treatments for DRA.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE  Male adolescents have substantial sexual and reproductive health (SRH) needs, including high rates of  sexually transmitted infections, human immunodeficiency virus, cancer prevention, and unintended partner  pregnancies; yet despite clinical guidelines that recommend primary care providers deliver SRH care to all  male adolescents, very few males receive any singular SRH service. Computer- and clinic-based strategies  have potential to address this gap, but to date, there are not any approaches that promote the recommended  SRH care package for diverse groups of males presenting to care. This project will adapt Health-E You/Salud  iTu, a pre-visit, individually tailored, web-based mobile app that improved female adolescents’ contraceptive  knowledge and contraceptive care receipt, for use with diverse male adolescents; and will examine its  acceptability, usability, and satisfaction among male adolescents and providers; and its efficacy on improving  male adolescents’ knowledge, self-efficacy, beliefs, and behaviors about SRH care after the visit and method  use 2 months later.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative While Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is the leading cause of dementia, affecting over 26 million people worldwide, treatment options have been limited due to the unclear mechanism of disease. The proposed research will use genomic data to identify which genetic variants and genes influence AD risk. The results of this study will increase our mechanistic understanding of AD and reveal new genes for further research and drug develop- ment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondrial reactive oxygen species (ROS) are strongly implicated in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and other aging-related dementias. Mitochondria produce ROS from numerous sites, but the exact roles of individual sites of ROS production in disease-related processes require investigation. The proposed study will determine the roles of mitochondrial complex III-derived ROS in neural signaling, neuroinflammation, and proteinopathy and may reveal complex III as a novel therapeutic target for AD and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A small fraction of Postdoctoral Fellows conducting research in the life sciences come from groups that are traditionally underrepresented in the STEM fields. An even smaller fraction of these individuals advance to become faculty and principal investigators of NIH research grants. Through a partnership of Atlanta institutions of higher education, Spelman, Morehouse, and Clark Atlanta, we have a unique opportunity to help address these problems and enhance inclusive excellence by providing Postdoctoral Fellows with a traditional research-intensive experience coupled with mentored teaching activities at these Minority Serving Institutions in the Atlanta metropolitan area.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative New technologies, including screening tests and vaccines against human papillomavirus (HPV), a sexually- transmitted virus known to cause cervical cancer, are dramatically changing the landscape of cervical cancer control in the US and worldwide. In order to address important evidence gaps, our CISNET-Cervical working group – consisting of five teams who have been at the forefront of modeling cervical cancer prevention over the last decade – will continue this comparative modeling collaboration to evaluate the harms, benefits, and cost-effectiveness of screening and vaccination strategies, and disseminate findings to inform health policies and decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Aging-related cognitive decline is a significant concern amongst the elderly, and disruptions in memory can drastically reduce independence and quality of life. This study aims to further our understanding of the mechanisms that underlie learning by studying the dynamics of plasticity signals and how those might change in the context of aging. This knowledge could then inform the development new therapies for improving memory deficits, which has the potential to significantly improve the quality of life for a large portion of the aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Health relatedness: Refractory asthma manifests with persistent symptoms such as airway inflammation and airway hyperresponsiveness despite the use of existing therapies and poses a major healthcare challenge. Our studies will identify the molecular mechanisms underlying regulation of airway inflammation and airway hyperresponsiveness by p63RhoGEF and its small molecule inhibitor CXN-8, leading to increased understanding of pathogenesis and therapeutic resistance in asthma. CXN-8 may offer a novel multisystem treatment approach to address the overarching challenge of refractory asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The inability to quickly and accurately diagnose tuberculosis (TB) in children and initiate treatment is a major contributor to the high mortality of childhood TB worldwide. This study will identify novel Mtb- and host-derived biomarkers, and determine the best biomarker panels (i.e., biosignatures) that can meet the World Health Organization-recommended diagnostic accuracy thresholds for a TB triage or diagnostic test. If successful, the results will the first step needed to make progress toward addressing the critical unmet need for non-sputum biomarker-based tests for childhood TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Viruses that infect bacteria – bacteriophages – are exceptionally numerous, and the largest structural family has deep and important connection with human herpesviruses, an important pathogen for which no effective long-term remedies are available. They have potential for use as antibiotics and in drug and vaccine development. Our study aims to understand the organization and functions of the virus proteins required for assembly and that incorporate the viral genome. This knowledge will form a framework for understanding the structure and assembly of this large virus family and will inform the development of therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Massachusetts, Boston (UMass Boston) and Dana-Farber/Harvard Cancer Center (DF/HCC) Partnership is committed to further developing a shared rigorous and collaborative transdisciplinary cancer and disparities-related research program that is primed for “Bridging the Divides: Innovations to Address Gaps in Cancer Disparities Research, Education, Outreach and Infrastructure.” Sophisticated research projects are proposed across several areas of basic biomedical and population sciences that will employ evidence and methods to converge upon and impact cancer and cancer health disparities at multiple levels of analysis. These projects, together with state-of-the-art Outreach and Research Education Cores and creative Research Design and Analysis Core and Genomics Cores, will serve to build research capacity and infrastructure at UMass Boston, expand the cancer disparities platform and community outreach programs at DF/HCC; and make, at an elevated level, significant advances to the science of cancer control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Whether the moon can affect sleep has been a matter of high controversy for decades. Our published and preliminary data clearly show that sleep timing is synchronized with the lunar cycle, leading to large changes in sleep duration even in people living in highly urbanized communities. The main goal of this project it to elucidate the mechanisms by which the moon cycle regulates sleep by focusing on two key sleep regulators, the circadian and homeostatic processes of sleep regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nuclear pore complexes (NPCs) selectively transport material into and out of the cell’s nucleus and directly control gene expression. Despite detailed structural studies, we still do not know much about how NPCs work, therefore this project intends to understand how they mediate and control key elements of nuclear transport and regulate their associated DNA, and how defects in these processes might lead to many developmental, viral or oncogenic diseases. This knowledge will ultimately open the possibility of therapeutically controlling nuclear pore complexes to correct defects that result in these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative People with psychotic disorders are excluded from most suicide-focused clinical trials despite incredibly high rates of completed suicide, and interventions that have been tested for this population have shown limited impact on suicide. Emotion dysregulation is a significant suicidogenic factor that is understudied in people with psychotic disorders. We propose to implement and evaluate an intervention targeting emotion dysregulation in people with psychotic disorders while employing rigorous statistical modeling and measurement techniques including Ecological Momentary Assessment, which will support future advanced research on suicide and suicide prevention for this high-risk group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goals of this project are to understand the immune bone marrow environment and disseminated tumor cells interactions which lead to metastases in triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) as well as develop biomarkers for therapy selection. We will accomplish this by 1: evaluating the ability of an 8-gene DTC gene panel to predict distant disease development in TNBC patients enrolled in a therapeutic trial of carboplatin/paclitaxel/nivolumab with or without cabiralizumab; Aim 2: understanding the extent of intra- and inter-patient molecular heterogeneity of BM DTCs in TNBC patients treated with conventional chemotherapy and ICI therapy and Aim 3: Correlating alterations in specific T cell and conventional dendritic cells (cDCs) populations in the BM with the presence of DTCs, and to determine the impact of conventional and ICI therapy.
PI_NAMEs: AFT, REBECCA L. (contact);DENARDO, DAVID G;WATSON, MARK A.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is often accompanied by other autoimmune disorders. The goal of this proposal is to gain a clearer understanding of the spatial, temporal, cellular, and genetic contributions to T1D-associated autoimmune neuritis development. Gaining a better understanding of each of these contributory factors will provide a means to potentially pre-screen patients with T1D for a future risk of developing autoimmune nervous system disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the MUSC Core Center for Clinical Research is to provide unique research resources to enable and enhance clinical and translational research designed to improve the health of individuals with rheumatic diseases, with a focus on scleroderma and lupus that have a disparate impact on women and minorities. A major emphasis is to communicate and collaborate with minority patient groups and communities to encourage input and participation in clinical research, dissemination and health promotion activities. These goals have been met with extensive use of the Cores and community engagement activities in the past four years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the interdisciplinary PASSCODE (Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma Stromal Reprograming ConSortium COordination, Data Management and Education) is to serve as an organizing “hub” for coordination, communication and collaboration within the Pancreatic Cancer Stromal Reprogramming Consortium (PSRC). The PASSCODE will provide administrative support, facilitate communication and collaboration, provide a centralized venue for data management, analysis and storage, and serve as a platform for consortium outreach and educational activities. Through its efforts, PASSCODE will significantly enhance the meaningful progress made by PSRC in improving survival outcomes for pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Diabetes increases the occurrence and severity of heart disease and heart failure. This occurs because diabetes impairs heart metabolism and function. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Imaging biological tissue such as brains at subcellular resolution is of fundamental importance for the understanding of biological processes. With iterative thinning multibeam transmission electron microscopy, the detailed cellular ultrastructure in very large tissue samples such as entire brains could be visualized. This will enable researchers and clinicians to visualize the biological organization and cellular interactions of entire organs at centimeter-scale down to cellular compartments at nanometer resolution.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: As a group, intellectual and developmental disabilities, including Down syndrome and autism spectrum disorder, have dramatic effects on affected people’s and their caregiver’s lives. Unfortunately, there remains a lack of understanding about what causes these disabilities and, critically, how to treat them with targeted therapies. The Vanderbilt Kennedy Center’s Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities Research Center serves as the hub for Vanderbilt’s research efforts focusing on improving the lives of people with intellectual and developmental disabilities by understanding the causes of these disorders and developing and testing therapies tailored to each individual’s precise needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to elucidate how manipulation of PTH receptor interaction with beta-catenin can prevent cartilage lesions and increase cartilage repair via shifting the PTH receptor signaling toward its therapeutic pathway. Thus, the therapeutic strategies in the present proposal help overcome the limitation of current usage of PTH or PTHrP for the prevention and treatment of osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Behavioral problems in autism are often managed using antipsychotic drugs that can cause weight gain and obesity. In this work, we will try to identify clinical and genetic features that might indicate who is at increased risk for this weight gain, as well as compare how often the weight gain occurs depending on which drug is used. Understanding these things could help develop methods to better use these drugs, or identify ways to avoid use altogether.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  The Collaborative Pediatric Critical Care Research Network (CPCCRN) includes 24 pediatric intensive care units and an established Data Coordinating Center with independent medical and biostatistical expertise. Build- ing on its strong track record of successful clinical trials and innovative work in immune phenotyping in pediatric sepsis, the CPCCRN will carry out a large-scale multicenter randomized controlled trial using personalized test- ing and targeted management of immune function in infants and children with sepsis-induced multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS), one of the most frequent causes of mortality and morbidity in critical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The standard-of-care way in clinical oncology to evaluate the drug response of a tumor is through in vitro and ex vivo protocols done on cells or tissues excised from the live tumor, which is incapable of investigating many important and often critical events that only occur in vivo. The proposed multi-modality microimaging-microdevice (MI-MD) system provides such a technology for high throughput testing of drug response in vivo, without the need to excise any tissues from the native tumor. The MI-MD system to be developed in this project will have high potential impacts on drug development, individualized health care, and fundamental biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Only two in eight young adults (18-30 years old) with type 1 diabetes achieve glucose targets and a majority are at an increased risk for complications such as premature coronary artery disease, stroke, vision loss, kidney disease and nerve damage compared to the general population. The primary goal of this study is to determine whether a cognitive-behavioral sleep self-management intervention can improve sleep health and glucose targets in young adults with type 1 diabetes. The key findings generated from this study including wearable technologies (e.g., actigraphy and continuous glucose monitors) may help support provider clinical decision making and self-management for young adult with type 1 diabetes to help them achieve glucose targets.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prevention of child maltreatment (CM), exposure to domestic violence (DV) and other ACEs are of paramount importance to individual, family and community wellbeing. To address the needs of families at risk for ACEs, we propose to adapt and pilot an innovative prevention program combining family-focused (Multiple Family Groups or MFG), school-based (School Children and Their Families or SAF), financial economic empowerment (FEE) interventions to promote positive health and socioeconomic outcomes for children and families. Although there is strong evidence about the efficacy of each of these interventions individually in the general population in the U.S. and other global contexts, these approaches have never been deployed jointly or adapted and rigorously evaluated among Central Asian (CA) populations; therefore, the proposed study will adapt and carry out this combined prevention program on a pilot basis in Kyrgyzstan and assess its overall effectiveness qualitatively and through a randomized trial.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This mHealth project seeks to address some of the most pressing and current public health concerns, namely extremely high rates of maternal and perinatal deaths in resource-poor settings. Our study proposes to adapt and test the University of Alabama at Birmingham's (UAB) 24/7 Medical Information Service via Telephone (MISTTM) for rural providers for use with mobile-phone technology (mMIST) in Cameroon, a low-income nation that holds some of the highest rates of maternal mortality and perinatal mortality globally. We will accomplish this by partnering with the Cameroon Baptist Convention Health Services (CBCHS), the local Ministry of Health authority, and the African Coalition of the Global Health Committee of the Society of Maternal-Fetal Medicine; this study employs a stakeholder participatory approach and stepped wedge cluster randomized trial design in 19 health districts (clusters) informed by the validated ADAPT-ITT model for intervention adaptation and the Implementation Science (IS) Exploration, Preparation, Implementation, Sustainment (EPIS) framework, making this study scientifically rigorous and innovative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) is the second most common cancer overall in the United States, of which a substantial number of cases are unresectable and lack treatment options. Therapeutic strategies are limited in part due to poor understanding of how intratumoral heterogeneity (ITH) arises and triggers invasive behavior in cSCC, but recent work suggests that factors from the tumor microenvironment (TME) and cancer cell-intrinsic factors both contribute to ITH. This work aims to identify specific crosstalk pathways between the tumor and TME that lead to invasion and tumor progression to aid in developing therapeutic strategies to disable these processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emotion dysregulation contributes to many psychiatric disorders and results in significant impairment across multiple domains of function from social to health-related outcomes. This project will investigate the separable developmental trajectories, ability to predict impairment and psychopathology, and neural markers of clinical dysregulation of negative affect (irritability), clinical dysregulation of positive affect (excitability), and normative high positive affect (surgency). Elucidating the developmental effects of excitability and irritability will have implications for transdiagnostic models of psychiatric illness and will inform development of targeted interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Results from this study will help identify markers of vulnerability to psychopathology during early adolescence and early adulthood by investigating the neurodevelopmental mechanisms supporting the ability to modulate attention toward or away from emotional information in the context of goal-directed behavior, which is integral to emotion regulation. This information is lacking and critical for characterizing neurodevelopmental pathways of risk for internalizing and externalizing disorders. Additionally, the study will provide rigorous longitudinal data on the neurodevelopment of the ability to resist interference from emotional distracters contributing to the discovery of critical windows of brain plasticity when early interventions designed to strengthen neural networks supporting emotional interference resistance could be most effective in promoting emotion regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The microbes in the gut can contribute to disease and inflammation, but we lack fundamental knowledge about how microbial genes impact inflammation or treatment. We plan to use new state-of-the-art genomic technologies to understand how gut microbes respond and contribute to inflammation. This information will be critical to more effectively design new therapies that target the microbes in our gut.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Although diabetic retinopathy (DR) is the leading cause of blindness among American adults, many diabetic patients do not comply with the recommended ophthalmic exams because DR is asymptomatic in the early stages, and thus patients miss the most effective period to halt DR progression and prevent vision loss. To improve the compliance rate of the recommended ophthalmic exams and detect DR early, our long-term goal is to develop a cost-effective, nonimage based, artificial intelligence (AI) tool for primary care physicians to assess patients’ risk for DR using routine lab results, and recommend ophthalmic exams and personalized screening frequency for at-risk patients confidently. As the next step in pursuing this goal, this project aims to develop advanced machine learning algorithms to realize the full potential of electronic-healthrecord (EHR) data by harnessing tensor information to improve the quality of EHR data and prediction accuracy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - Duke University By joining the newly organized and expanded Collaborative Pediatric Critical Care Research Network, Duke Children’s and our ancillary site at the Medical University of South Carolina will enhance the scientific breadth and reach of the network. Our sites are the leading academic centers in North and South Carolina, and will ensure that critically ill children in both states have access to the cutting edge clinical trials and research studies conducted by the network. Building on our experiences and expertise, we will provide deep scientific expertise and training and mentoring opportunities to enrich the network with a focus on the areas of clinical pharmacology, real-world evidence generation, and regulatory science.

PHR: For over 40 years, the UCLA IDDRC has committed to improving the lives of individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDDs) through basic and translational research, education, and outreach. Our center aims to provide outstanding resources and infrastructure to UCLA researchers focused on IDDs using the most innovative technologies that will significantly impact the well-being of individuals with IDDs and their families. This application requests 5 years of funding to support our Core infrastructure and a novel multidisciplinary project that examines the origins of abnormal sleep physiology and cognition. A new dissemination program extends our reach into the community to enhance inclusiveness and two-way communication with the public and stakeholders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although prostate cancer stem cells have been investigated for the past twenty years, it has been difficult to provide definitive evidence for their existence or properties. In part, previous studies have been hampered by the lack of high-resolution methods to examine the behavior of individual cells within tumors, such as single-cell RNA-sequencing, as well as sophisticated computational approaches for the precise identification of candidate markers. Leveraging techniques from theoretical physics and algebraic topology, we will provide a statistical framework to identify and characterize tumor stem cells using single-cell data, and will validate our findings using mouse models and human prostate tumor samples.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ECHO IDeA States Pediatric Clinical Trials Network-2 (ISPCTN-2) seeks to develop research that closes gaps that exist in maternal, infant, and child health, seeking to reduce rates of preterm birth and infant mortality by increasing access to pediatric clinical trials in rural and underserved communities. The Mississippi ECHO ISPCTN-2 (MS-CTN2) project provides a vital pediatric research resource in rural and medically underserved communities in the deep South. MS-CTN2 creates access for historically disenfranchised pediatric populations to participate in multisite pediatric trials and, in turn, these children and their families contribute to findings that inform the health of all children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although genetic studies of complex traits have found many trait-associated loci, they rarely reveal new biology and they yield genetic predictions biased toward European-ancestry individuals. Studies of interactions between genes (GxG) or between genes and the environment (GxE) have potential to address these limitations, but current models are unrealistic and underpowered. I will develop new rigorous models of GxG and GxE and apply them in diverse ancestries and traits—from single cell ‘omics to Major Depressive Disorder—to better understand complex trait biology and to improve equity in genetic medicine.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - University of California Consortium The Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institutes of Child Health and Development (NICHD) Collaborative Pediatric Critical Care Research Network (CPCCRN) was established in 2004 to address the need for carefully planned and well designed, prospective, multicenter clinical trials for infants and children with Critical Illness. This proposal seeks to establish a University of California Consortium (UCC) hub site consisting of UCSF Benioff Children Hospital's at San Francisco and Oakland along with UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital. UC Davis will join the UCC as ancillary site, allowing us to participate fully in the “Personalized Immunomodulation in Sepsis-induced MODS” trial described in this application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Photon-driven chemical reactions can enable the synthesis of complex, biologically relevant molecules, important in the pharmaceutical industry. However, many reactions commonly used to build molecules rely on bulk heating to break strong chemical bonds. This proposal will leverage an underused light-to-heat conversion strategy to avoid the energy intensive and inefficiencies associated with bulk heating. The success of the proposed research will ultimately enable new methods in organic synthesis for building complex molecules using energy efficient visible light.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: RATIONALE The goal of the project described in this revised proposal is to extend our ongoing clinical trials to determine whether wounding of aged skin can prevent the occurrence of non-melanoma skin cancers. Furthermore, studies are designed to examine the mechanisms responsible for wounding-induced protection from ultraviolet- light induced skin cancer, namely, how new fibroblasts populate aged skin in response to wounding. Finally, these studies will test a novel non-invasive imaging platform designed to predict skin cancer occurrence.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - University of Minnesota This proposal is relevant to public health because the University of Minnesota Masonic Children's Hospital and our ancillary site, Children's Minnesota, will enroll children from a variety of social, economic, and racial backgrounds from throughout the Upper Midwest to CPCCRN studies. The proposed project investigates the impact of individual immune function profiles and treatment on organ dysfunction from sepsis and whether treated children recover more fully following their illness and therefore requires a diverse patient population to adequately address this personalized question. UMMCH's role as a clinical site is relevant to the NICHD CPCCRN's mission to care for all critically ill and injured children, and to reduce the impact of illness and disability on every child.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Overall – Narrative Despite the rapidly growing US Asian population, there are vast gaps in translational research on comorbid cardiometabolic and mental health outcomes. In the Rutgers-NYU Center for Asian Health Promotion and Equity, we will establish three complementary cores and three research projects to achieve the mission of the center: to improve cardiometabolic and mental health of US Asians through a robust research infrastructure and resource structure and developing the next generation of scientists focused on these health disparity issues.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Nationwide Children’s Hospital This project is relevant to public health because, as one of the nation’s largest children’s hospitals, Nationwide Children’s Hospital has the patient population, research infrastructure, and investigator expertise to contribute fundamentally to our understanding the pathophysiology and treatment of pediatric critical illness. In particular, we expect the “Personalized Immunomodulation in Sepsis-Induced MODS” study to improve the survival of children with sepsis-induced MODS and to improve their functional status and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Opioid abuse in HIV-infected individuals is associated with treatment non-compliance, greater risk of viral transmission, and more rapid disease progression. To investigate the molecular mechanisms behind the interactions of HIV and opioid use disorder (OUD), this interdisciplinary project will profile gene expression at the single cell level in key brain regions relevant to the effects of persistent HIV infection and OUD in a small animal model of neuroHIV in a behavioral paradigm of voluntary intravenous drug self-administration. We will bring to bear computational methods to elucidate the key genes driving the altered gene expression at the single cell level, which will provide a framework for new testable hypotheses on the mechanisms underlying the neuropathogenesis of the neuronal damage and neuroinflammation in the context of OUD in HIV infection that can reveal new pathogenic concepts and more effective therapeutic targets to improve neuropsychological functioning in people with HIV and OUD comorbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although there are thousands of genetic variations that are associated with human diseases, the underlying mechanisms of how these variants contribute to disease pathogenesis remain obscure. In this proposal, we will use a combination of high throughput genomics assays and CRISPR-based technologies to identify functional regulatory elements and the novel regulators for 3D genome organization. We will investigate how genetic variants can affect the function of regulatory elements and alter chromatin interactions and eventually contribute to human diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – University of Pittsburgh Medical Center Review of 109 million death records from the Global Burden of Disease study (1991-2017) found that one in five people in the world die from sepsis caused by overwhelming infection, with the majority of these being children. The new Eunice Kennedy Shriver NICHD Collaborative Pediatric Critical Research Network comprised of 12 primary sites and 12 ancillary sites proposes to perform a placebo controlled randomized trial to test the hypothesis that personalized utilization of molecular biology revolution breakthrough diagnostics and recombinant therapies to improve a child’s ability to fight infection and control inflammation will reduce this public health burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is the most common lethal genetic disease in US Caucasians, arising from mutations in the gene encoding CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR). CF-related diabetes (CFRD), the most prevalent co-morbidity, develops at the early age of childhood. The proposal will help to understand the pathogenesis in the pancreas during the development of CFRD, and to provide all people with CF the opportunity to lead long, fulfilling lives.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Children’s National Hospital Pediatric sepsis and multiple organ failure are identified as conditions that adversely affect the public health of children by NICHD, leading to increased mortality and morbidity. Beside supportive care with antibiotics, resuscitative measures to augment oxygen delivery and mechanical support for failing organs, no therapies have been identified to decrease the burden of illness for children with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS). In this new application, the Collaborative Pediatric Critical Care Research Network will perform two randomized controlled trials to determine whether immunomodulation after sepsis-induced MODS decreases organ failure and improves outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Dizziness is a common reason for visiting the emergency department (ED). Guideline-supported evidence- based practices exist but are substantially underused while many unnecessary tests are overused. The DIZZTINCT-2 study builds on the results of DIZZTINCT-1 and will evaluate the effect of an implementation strategy that focuses on evidence-based practices for dizziness visits and uses provider- and patient-oriented resources.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – University of Michigan The incidences of some of the most challenging diseases that contribute to pediatric critical illness, notably acute respiratory distress syndrome and sepsis, are such that relying on any one center to execute a single- site study that will advance both our understanding and management of these diseases is ineffective. In order to improve the care of this vulnerable population of critically ill children, the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD) has addressed this by funding an infrastructure for a multicenter research network, the Collaborative Pediatric Critical Care Research Network (CPCCRN) and the accompanying clinical trial examining the efficacy of GM-CSF in children with sepsis entitiled, Personalized Immunomodulation in Sepsis-induced Multiple Organ Dysfunction Syndrome (MODS). This application will position our Pediatric Critical Care Medicine Research Program at the University of Michigan and our ancillary site at the Pediatric Critical Care Division at the Medical College of Wisconsin to actively participate and contribute in this important national network.
