IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioids act as agonists of opioid receptors and are amongst the most effective analgesics, but they come with serious side effects and a high potential for abuse. To date, we know little about the molecular mechanisms mediating the beneficial and adverse actions of opioids. Our proposed studies combine proteomics and functional genomics to discover regulators of mu-opioid receptor activation, which may identify new therapeutic targets for pain and addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Identification of senescent cells in tissues is particularly challenging as it requires detection of sets of markers that can be cell type specific. Our goal is to develop single cell multi-omic imaging technology to measure proteins, RNA and the DNA’s 3-dimensional conformation in senescent cells and in their microenvironment, in a diverse set of tissues. This new technology will allow us to better understand the heterogeneity of the senescent phenotype in tissues, and to study how senescent cells affect the status of neighboring cells.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to understand the mechanism of the eukaryotic chaperonin TRiC/CCT, a ring- shaped hetero-oligomeric complex that folds many essential cellular proteins in an ATP- dependent manner. Recent observations have highlighted the links between TRiC and several pathological states incuding cancer, viral infection and neurodegeneration. Thus our project deciphering the mechanism of this chaperonin in cellular folding will help develop therapies to ameliorate these human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative: Patients suffering from sickle cell disease (SCD) present with repetitive, intermittent and painful blood vessel blockage and can succumb to premature death caused by accumulating damage to all major organs. Our preliminary data suggest that gut bacteria mediate the development of chronic organ damage in SCD. The proposed studies will advance our understanding of SCD pathophysiology and may lead to the development of new cost-effective, microbiome-based therapies for SCD patients so that they can live longer and more fulfilling lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal, we will test the impact of cocaine use on the microbiota of selected tissues associated with the gut-brain axis. Knowing that imbalances in microbial composition or activity arising from chronic cocaine use influences health and is implicated in various diseases (e.g., leaky gut and mood disorders), our studies will be executed in tissues extracted from African-American overdose cases from three Southern regions of the United States. Since the gut microbiome plays major roles in maintaining human health, our studies will contribute fundamental knowledge to enhancing the well-being of individuals with cocaine abuse disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Overall Narrative Molecular blueprints would dramatically enhance our ability to design effective approaches to intervene and prevent kidney dysfunction in children. The objective of the Washington University Kidney Single Cell Atlas Project (pKidCAP) is to create a highly unique and innovative Pediatric Center of Excellence that delivers novel concepts, knowledge and resources by providing spatially resolved single cell molecular maps of pediatric reference and diseased kidneys at several time points across the pediatric lifespan. The pKidCAP investigators will apply paired snRNAseq, snATACseq technologies for decoding gene regulation and expression from the same cell and use spatial transcriptomics to resolve the cellular diversity with morphology using healthy and disease samples from pediatric kidneys procured from the Biomedical core and in mouse model of glomerular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE A multifaceted research approach is required to eliminate the human immunodeficiency virus type one (HIV-1) from its myeloid reservoirs that include the central nervous system. To this end, biological, biochemical, molecular, theranostic and immunological approaches are outlined to detect, target then eliminate HIV-1 infectious myeloid reservoirs. The proposed works include novel antiretroviral and gene therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Insomnia is prevalent among adults who engage in heavy drinking, but it is rarely targeted in alcohol prevention or treatment. The proposed study will test the efficacy of an evidence-based insomnia treatment in reducing heavy alcohol use and related problems among adult men and women in the United States. Findings will directly inform clinical practice by documenting the impact and potential mechanisms of insomnia treatment on alcohol-related outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Currently, there are limited therapeutic options for treating pediatric kidney disorders because of a limited understanding of disease mechanisms. To advance the field, we will use state-of-the-art interrogation technologies to create a molecular atlas of the maturing post-natal kidney in healthy mice and in a model of human disease. The proposed research is relevant to public health and to the NIH’s mission because the information learned from these studies will provide novel insights that may lead to rational therapeutic targets for kidney diseases affecting infants, children and adolescents.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to adapt and pilot a guided self-help stress management program from the World Health Organization and to incorporate peer cancer survivors in providing psychosocial support to breast cancer patients in Viet Nam. We seek to demonstrate the feasibility of the culturally and contextually adapted intervention in reducing the psychological distress associated with cancer diagnosis and treatment, to ultimately improve cancer patients’ health outcomes. Successful completion of the project begins to fill the gaps in the lack of culturally appropriate evidence-based mental health interventions for cancer patients in many low- and middle-income countries, and in many racial/ethnic groups in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Unhealthy alcohol use represents an unaddressed barrier to achieving and maintaining control of the HIV epidemic globally. In the Zambia Alabama HIV Alcohol Comorbidities Program (ZAMBAMA), we will compare the effectiveness of an alcohol brief intervention and a transdiagnostic cognitive behavioral therapy-based model that can address unhealthy alcohol use and a range of comorbid mental health problems to improve HIV and alcohol outcomes among low-resource and underserved patients with HIV and unhealthy alcohol use in sub- Saharan Africa and the Southern United States. ZAMBAMA’s 2 research projects and 3 resource cores were designed for integration and synergy, which will not only strengthen our ability to address our specific aims, but will also create unique scientific opportunities that would not be possible without a program structure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: ADMINISTRATIVE CORE PROJECT NARRATIVE The goals of the ZAMBAMA Administrative Core are to 1) Synchronize scientific aims and foster shared scientific progress between the projects; 2) Manage overarching program business and regulatory requirements; and 3) Enhance collaboration among investigators within and outside of the program. Through these aims the core will ensure that the activities of Projects 1 and 2 are harmonized and efficiently supported by the other cores (the Common Elements Treatment Approach [CETA] and Methods and Analysis [MAC] Cores). The Admin Core will optimize the scientific contributions of this Program Project Grant, ultimately advancing the treatment of HIV, unhealthy alcohol use, and mental health comorbidities among people living with HIV in disadvantaged communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative People with HIV often have unhealthy alcohol use, which can be complicated by psychiatric and substance use comorbidities. The CETA Core within the Zambia Alabama HIV Alcohol Comorbidities (ZAMBAMA) Program will provide clinical oversight for two clinical trials of interventions to address unhealthy alcohol use in patients with HIV in sub-Saharan Africa and the U.S. Deep South. Through training, supervision, and competency assessment activities, the CETA core will help ZAMBAMA understand the intersection of HIV, unhealthy alcohol use, and common comorbidities and evaluate new treatment approaches targeted to people receiving care at under- resourced clinics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Unhealthy alcohol use represents an unaddressed barrier to achieving and maintaining control of the HIV epidemic both in sub-Saharan Africa and in the rural United States. The Zambia Alabama HIV Alcohol Comorbidities (ZAMBAMA) program will test the effectiveness of two interventions, a brief alcohol intervention (BI) and a transdiagnostic cognitive behavioral therapy-based model called Common Elements Treatment Approach (CETA), in reducing unhealthy alcohol use and mental health comorbidities and in improving HIV outcomes among persons living with HIV in Zambia and Alabama. The Methods and Analysis Core (MAC) will support ZAMBAMA by providing expertise in data collection, management, and analyses within the CHARTZ (CETA HIV Alcohol Reduction Trial in Zambia) and TALC (Telemedicine for unhealthy Alcohol use with CETA) clinical trials, and by leveraging integrated approaches across the trials to create synergistic analyses within the P01 program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Unhealthy alcohol use represents an unaddressed barrier to achieving and maintaining control of the HIV epidemic in sub-Saharan Africa because best practices for screening and treatment are lacking, existing treatments do not address mental/behavioral health comorbidities, and there are severe shortages of professional mental/behavioral health workers. In this trial, at public sector HIV clinics in Zambia, we will evaluate the effectiveness of two alcohol-reduction interventions, a brief alcohol intervention (BI) and a transdiagnostic cognitive behavioral therapy called Common Elements Treatment Approach (CETA), which can address comorbidities in people with HIV and unhealthy alcohol use, and measure critical implementation data to inform further use of these interventions when integrated into HIV clinical care. This research will advance treatments available to people with HIV in sub-Saharan Africa, which will help achieve individual and public health goals of the HIV response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Because unhealthy alcohol use and psychosocial comorbidities are obstacles to ending the HIV epidemic in the Deep South, there is a critical need to identify low barrier treatments for these comorbidities in order to end HIV disparities in the U.S. The TALC proposal will test a transdiagnostic behavioral intervention that shows potential as an accessible, cost-effective treatment to reduce these comorbidities and thus improve HIV outcomes among people living with HIV (PLWH) in Alabama. This research will critically advance treatment for unhealthy alcohol use in PLWH in underserved areas, with the potential to greatly reduce HIV disease progression and transmission in high priority areas like Alabama.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: 8. Project Narrative There is strong evidence of co-morbid pathologies e.g. amyloid β (Aβ), tau and α-synuclein (αSyn) in Alzheimer’s Disease Related Dementias (ADRD) that account for up to 25% of all dementias in patients older than 65 years. Cognitive impairment is closely associated with synapse loss which occurs significantly prior to neuronal loss, suggesting that synaptic dysfunction is the key treatment target, and that ultimately synapse loss by multiple toxic oligomers (αSyn, Aβ, and tau) must be stopped. Creative Bio-Peptides is developing the oral chemokine antagonist peptide RAP-103 to prevent or reverse early synapse loss and cognitive decline in mixed-etiology dementias like ADRDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Strokes are the second leading cause of death worldwide yet despite improvements to mechanical thrombectomy techniques in recent years, revascularization of occluded vessels is not achieved in up to 33% of cases and only ~50% of cases have good clinical outcomes. Von Medical is developing an innovative aspiration pump to improve revascularization rates following stroke. This pump operates through a unique and novel mechanism that we will show, through the work described in this Phase I proposal, leads to high revascularization rates on the first pass with any diameter catheter currently on the market.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Stroke is a leading cause of disability in the United States, affecting ~795,000 people annually. The Veteran's Health Administration provides over 60,000 outpatient visits for stroke-related care annually at a cost of over $250 million. Among ambulatory people with chronic stroke (PwCS), impaired balance is a common health concern that substantially limits mobility (those with the worst balance walk the least). This project will explore adaptive strategies employed by PwCS in balance challenging environments and if a novel gait training intervention using a robotic device to amplify a person's self-generated movements can improve walking balance. The development of effective interventions to increase walking balance among PwCS will positively impact Veterans' health, quality of life, and ability to participate in walking activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Fat grafting is a compelling option for over 1.6 million Americans in need of soft tissue repair procedures, however surgical harvesting of fat via liposuction destroys its structural integrity and viability, reducing the resilience of the repaired tissue. During this Phase I proposal, inSoma will collaborate with MTF Biologics to develop an off- the-shelf product capable of replicating the results of autologous fat grafting without the need for surgical tissue harvest. The resulting product would expand the range of surgical procedures suited to fat grafting and provide a safer and cost-effective in-office procedure that would eliminate the need for patients to undergo reconstructive surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is growing evidence that maternal health and behaviors in pregnancy, such as pre-pregnancy obesity, excessive gestational weight gain, poor diet, smoking, and adverse pregnancy outcomes, are linked to fetal programming for obesity and cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk in the offspring. Yet, there is a surprising lack of research on the role of prenatal sedentary behavior, physical activity, and sleep (conceptualized together as 24-hour behavior) on offspring obesity risk and CVD risk; this is an unfortunate research gap since there is strong physiological rationale that these behaviors in pregnancy could influence offspring health and are modifiable intervention targets in pregnancy. This multi-site observational cohort study will leverage state-of- the-art, 24-hour behavior assessment in each trimester of pregnancy, collected as part of the ongoing Pregnancy 24/7 cohort study and add additional assessments of offspring growth, adiposity, and CVD risk through 24 months to inform future primordial prevention interventions to decrease the risk of offspring obesity and CVD across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The majority of biopsies in both basic and translational cancer studies are preserved in the format of archived formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded (FFPE) samples, and studying tumors in a spatial context will advance understanding of how the complex cross-talk between cancer and surrounding non-cancer cells. Accordingly, spatial omics profiling in archived FFPE tissue can be invaluable for cancer research and potential novel biomarker or molecular regulators discovery. This research proposal will develop a novel technology for spatially resolved co-mapping of epigenome, transcriptome, and proteins in FFPE tissues.

PHR: Key challenges to the sustenance of a workforce that conducts research which will impact individual and community health include inadequate training (a) in translational science, which is focused on understanding the scientific and operational principles underlying each step of the translational process, and to acquire the unique attributes of a translational scientist, and (b) to advance a culture of inclusive excellence that promotes problem solving and innovation by maximizing contributions from different perspectives and lived experiences. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Joinpoint regression developed by the NCI Surveillance Research Program is increasingly used to identify the timing and extent of changes in time series of health outcomes and to project future disease burden. Many analyses of population data (e.g., cancer stage at diagnosis, causes of death, and patterns of health behavior), including those often used in joinpoint regression, are based on percentages or proportions, as the focus is typically on relative, not absolute frequencies. Such time series of compositional variables need to be modeled simultaneously to guarantee the coherency of the individual temporal trends; that is the predicted percentages sum to 100% at each time step. This SBIR project is developing the first commercial software to offer tools for geostatistical noise-filtering and joinpoint regression analysis of time series of compositional variables in epidemiology.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: One-third of all Veterans have chronic low back pain (CLBP), and Veterans with CLBP are twice as likely to have co-occurring depression. Compared with the general population, Veterans are both more likely to have CLBP and their pain is more likely to be severe. Even though the proportion of Veterans with medical comorbidities such as diabetes or heart disease is stable or decreasing over time, chronic pain and depression are both increasing. Unfortunately, many Veterans with CLBP (especially those with comorbid depression) experience little to no functional improvement with current treatments. We propose to address this gap by developing an effective and acceptable treatment for Veterans with CLBP and comorbid depression. We will obtain extensive Veteran input during each phase of the project (development, pilot testing, and initial efficacy testing). This work will inform a high-quality clinical trial, thus aligning with the VA Office of Research and Development’s Strategic Research Priority of improving Veterans’ access to high-quality clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Hypertension and cardiovascular disease occur at substantially greater rates in optimally treated people with HIV, though the etiology of this elevated comorbidity risk remains poorly understood. The gut microbiota of people with HIV exhibits a loss of microbes that metabolize dietary fiber into key metabolites that can ameliorate hypertension. We will investigate the dynamics of fiber metabolism and uptake in the setting of HIV, the role of these phenomena in cardiovascular comorbidities, and whether capacity for fiber metabolism can be restored within the HIV-associated gut microbiome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a disease characterized by abnormal changes to the structure of lung arteries (i.e., ‘remodeling’), and is a major cause of heart failure and death among patients with various disorders of the heart, lung, blood, and connective tissue organ systems. Despite its importance to outcome in patients with PAH, effective therapies that reverse or prevent lung blood vessel remodeling are lacking. We propose an innovative approach that targets the key remodeling protein, NEDD9, selectively using a novel small molecule to establish a potential new treatment for PAH patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Every year silent aspiration during ventilation leads to nearly 500,000 pulmonary infections with a mortality rate of 1 in 3, adding more than $8 billion to healthcare spending in the United States. Respair is developing a novel endotracheal tube with ultra-soft baffles (thin, flexible discs) attached to the tube to create a seal that prevents silent aspiration while putting less force on the airway than current balloon sealing mechanisms. Respair aims to validate the baffle design through FDA verified safety and usability tests that will support the commercialization of a new device for patients on ventilators and create a technology platform for airway device innovation that further improves patient outcomes and reduces healthcare costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In sub-Saharan Africa, where Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) seroprevalence and HIV incidence are highest in the world, the effects of the oral environment on oral KSHV reactivation and shedding in people living with HIV (PLWH) before Kaposi’s sarcoma (KS) development are unknown. We propose the first and largest longitudinal study to our knowledge that will assess the effects of oral health, oral environment, and the oral microbiome on KSHV reactivation and shedding in rural Ugandan adults living with and without HIV infection. We will leverage an experienced multi-disciplinary team, a strong study design, and innovative and validated research techniques to identify the effects of the oral environment on KSHV reactivation in PLWH, a profound knowledge gap integral to identifying pre-risk measures for oral cavity KS involvement and developing prevention tactics in the region most affected.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Narrative Sleep disorders are among the most common reasons for seeing a physician and chronic insomnia, which greatly increases the risk of suicide, is by far the most common sleep disorder. Our recent work suggests that sleep in the natural world is linked to daily and seasonal temperature rhythms and that the rhythmic alternation of nonREM and REM sleep is driven by the brainstem thermoregulation. Disruption of these rhythms may be responsible for insomnia and hypersomnia and a better understanding of these rhythms may lead to more effective treatment of these sleep disorders by regulating environmental temperature.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Cancer research is often driven by hypotheses that see a specific extracellular protein as important for the disease, hypotheses often tested by developing an antibody to that protein. The technology to be developed here will create a new capability, reagents that not only bind a target protein, but also cleave it, to be available from suppliers in weeks (not months) at 10-100 fold lower cost than antibodies. In addition to having a transformative impact on cancer research, the hitherto unavailable properties of this new reagent class may make them eventually available for cancer diagnostics, to guide therapy, or as therapeutic agents.

PHR: NARRATIVE Pharmacist-prescribed contraceptive services have the potential to lower the rate of unplanned pregnancy in the US, however, several barriers must be addressed to incentivize widespread adoption. During Phase I, the OvaryIt Platform proved itself as a smart, contraceptive specific electronic health record (EHR) system with embedded clinical decision support (CDS) tools to increase workflow efficiencies and assist pharmacists in delivering safe, high-quality contraceptive care to patients. The successful completion of this SBIR Phase II project is expected to result in the creation and commercialization of an end-user driven SaaS platform that encourages the adoption of pharmacist prescribed contraceptive services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, STD AND TB PREVENTION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black women experience one of the highest incidences of HIV among all U.S. subpopulations and despite national PrEP implementation efforts, uptake among Black women remains low with only 10% who could benefit from PrEP prescribed it in 2020. Given the 2021 PrEP guidance to inform all sexually active patients of PrEP and 2022 FDA approval of cabotegravir injections, it is essential that health systems implement interventions to increase PrEP uptake and improve persistence among Black women. Project PrOVIDE: PrEP Optimization Via Implementation, Dissemination, and Evaluation will evaluate implementation strategies to address barriers and increase uptake of and persistence on PrEP among Black cisgender women in six distinct counties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR IMMUNIZATION AND RESPIRATORY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This study will generate information on health system and economic impact of Influenza and SARSCoV-2 related severe acute respiratory infections among adults in India. Such information from Low-middle income countries is sparse. In addition, this will strengthen capacity among the participating institutions to conduct disease registries and cohort to assess long-term sequelae of such infections. The evidence so generated will be disseminated to provincial and national government through a well thought out advocacy strategy leading to mitigation of the impact of these two infections in the community.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-IP-22-001 - Burden and sequelae of influenza, SARS-CoV-2 and other respiratory viruses associated Severe Acute Respiratory Infections among Indian adult population aged 18-60yrs

IC_NAME: Center for Global Health
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This CoAg supports a collaboration between the Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI), the US CDC and the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine (LSTM) to support the Kenyan Ministry of Health to achieve major reductions in the malaria burden in areas with intense year-round transmission in western Kenya by 2025. The partnership will support the expansion of the malaria surveillance infrastructure to track the progress towards malaria transmission targets, evaluate different combinations of area-wide interventions targeting the malaria vector and asymptomatic parasite reservoir to reduce malaria transmission and strengthen case management. These activities will provide pivotal critical scientific knowledge to inform and guide malaria program implementation and reduce malaria-associated morbidity and mortality through the identification and scale-up and continued evaluation of evidence-based intervention strategies.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-GH-20-002, Malaria Operations Research to Improve Malaria Control and Reduce Morbidity and Mortality in Western Kenya

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed phase 2 multicenter study will evaluate seliciclib in patients with Cushing disease caused by an adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH)-secreting pituitary adenoma. Seliciclib is the only new agent currently in clinical trials in the US directly targeting pituitary corticotroph ACTH secretion and the consequent hypercortisolism that underlies excess morbidity and mortality associated with this rare disease. Results of the trial, conducted through a collaborative effort among all five major specialty pituitary centers in greater Los Angeles, will lay the foundation for additional trials of seliciclib in treating Cushing disease.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Ph 2 Multicenter study of seliciclib for Cushing Disease IND 120,848 (10/10/2017)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The goal of this P01 Program is to develop novel strategies to selectively promote entry of antitumor killer cells (CTLs) into tumor microenvironments (TME) and reduce local accumulation of suppressive cells, in order to sensitize “cold” tumors to immune checkpoint inhibition (ICI) therapy. Our preclinical and early clinical data demonstrate that we can uniformly correct cancer TMEs using chemokine-modulating (CKM) regimen which concomitantly targets toll-like receptor-3 (TLR3), type-1 interferon (IFN) and prostaglandin systems, and specialized dendritic cell vaccines (αDC1). We will now test the immunologic and clinical efficacy of our novel therapies, identify the biomarkers of their antitumor effectiveness and potential undesirable effects, and will develop optimized and logistically feasible treatments for large groups of patients with immunotherapy- resistant tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 1 NARRATIVE We developed a novel combinatorial adjuvant (chemokine-modulatory regimen; CKM) to promote selective accumulation of anticancer immune cells (CTLs), uniformly throughout multiple colorectal cancer (CRC) lesions, but not healthy tissues, and suppress accumulation of tumor-promoting immune cells (Tregs). CKM showed immunologic and therapeutic efficacy in mice, showing strong synergy with checkpoint blockade in inducing cures in mice with established cancers and demonstrated safety end preliminary signs of local efficacy in patients with liver-metastatic CRC who received systemic (i.v) CKM (trial NCT01545141). Now, we propose to: 1) Perform phase IIa trial to demonstrate the immunologic activity of i.v.- administered CKM to promote in-patient increases in intratumoral CTL numbers; 2) Evaluate the impact of CKM on antitumor effectiveness of PD-1 blockade and vaccines in preclinical settings and identify the underlying mechanisms; and 3) Test the clinical activity of CKM combined with PD-1 blockade in CRC patients in inducing objective clinical responses (iRECIST).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The human papillomavirus (HPV) is a major public health threat that attributes to 34, 800 cancer cases annually in the United States, with the majority of these cases occurring in racial/ethnic minorities. Successful HPV vaccine coverage programs can reduce HPV-associated cancer disparities by ensuring that all populations are spared the morbidity and mortality due to HPV-related cancers. This proposal is relevant to the part of NCI's mission that pertains to leading the nation's research efforts to not only improve cancer prevention, but to also reduce disparities in cancer outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to perform phase II component of the clinical trial (NCT02432378) to test if local chemokine modulating regimen (CKM) involving (i.p.) rintatolimod and IFNα is effective in guiding the αDC1 vaccine-induced CTLs to tumor tissues of patients with resectable ovarian cancer. We will evaluate COX2/PGE2 and PD-1/PD- L1/PD-L2 systems, as two complementary pathways of “secondary” suppression mobilized in OvCa TME in response to immune attack, and test and if the elimination of both these systems will result in therapeutic synergy in mice. Guided by the results of these studies, we will finalize the design and perform a trial to test if the combined treatment with αDC1 vaccines, CKM and PD-1 blockade, induces clinical responses in patients with unresectable OvCa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE In a recently completed pilot clinical trial administering a dendritic cell-based vaccine targeting tumor vascular antigens (αDC1/TBVA) + dasatinib, we observed a high rate of responses (4 of 7 patients; 57% ORR) in melanoma patients who had previously exhibited primary resistance to anti-PD1 checkpoint blockade and objective clinical benefit overall in 6 of 13 patients (46% DCR) on that trial. Treatment benefit was associated with changes in the balance of pro-inflammatory vs. regulatory chemokines and with immune infiltration (including the formation of tertiary lymphoid structures and evidence for T cell repertoire diversification) within patients’ tumors. These striking clinical data and our mouse studies showing much stronger therapeutic synergy between αDC1/TBVA and the chemokine-modulating regimen (CKM) developed within Project 1, compared to dasatinib, prompted us to perform a larger phase II study to evaluate the ability of αDC1/TBVA+CKM to induce objective clinical responses in patients with primary PD1-refractory, advanced-stage melanoma, identify the underlying mechanisms, and develop tools for prospective studies of survival benefit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Targeting neutrophils to harness myeloid responses for wound healing Project narrative: Chronic wounds represent a significant health problem in the United States with millions of afflicted patients and the associated treatment billions of dollars per year. In the proposed research, we will investigate how chronic wounds and associated obesity dysregulate white blood cells that contribute to the poor healing responses in these conditions. Findings from our experiments will provide insight into whether therapies and tests targeting a type of white blood cells can improve the healing of wounds and can aid in the selection of treatment options that are currently available for treating chronic wounds. The long-term goal of this project is to reduce the socioeconomic burden of chronic wounds and associated obesity and improve the quality of life of these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anticoagulant treatment can prevent thrombosis and major ischemic events, such as pulmonary embolism, heart attack, and stroke, but the anticoagulant/reversal agent pair most commonly used during surgical procedures, unfractionated heparin (UFH) and protamine, is associated with serious acute side effects, dosing errors, hemorrhage, and thrombosis. To meet the need for safer alternatives to UFH and protamine, Helixomer, Inc. is developing an innovative RNA-origami-based anticoagulant and a corresponding DNA-based reversal agent with predictable dose response profiles. In this Direct-to-Phase II project, Helixomer will validate essential bioanalytical methods for quantifying drug concentrations in plasma, determine dosing strategies in a large- animal model, determine the maximum tolerated dose, and assess the safety and toxicity of these novel drugs in preparation for a future first-in-human clinical trial.

This application proposes support for the UCSF pulmonary training program that for the past 44 years has trained many of the world’s leading scientists in lung biology and medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: /// PROJECT NARRATIVE \\\ Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a common medical condition characterized by an impaired ability to stop or control alcohol use despite adverse social, occupational, or health consequences. To better understand gene expression changes in the brain associated with AUD, we propose single nuclei sequencing of the brain transcriptome in multiple brain regions to identify cell-type specific gene expression differences. Successful completion of this project will yield (i) unprecedented insights into AUD disease mechanisms, (ii) possible blood biomarkers of genes differentially expressed in brain, and (iii) lay the foundation for functional follow-up studies and, eventually, novel highly specific clinical interventions for improving AUD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-traumatic osteoarthritis is a crippling disease that can rapidly affect over half of patients suffering acute joint injuries, such as ACL ruptures and meniscal tears, as well as patients with overuse injuries. Presently, there are no clinical treatments that can prevent the initiation and progression of PTOA after joint injury, and the translation of therapeutic candidates with PTOA-disease modifying potential has been hindered by poor targeting to and rapid clearance of therapeutics from the joint. In this program, we will demonstrate the feasibility of novel collagen-targeting, thermoresponsive approaches for localizing candidate drugs to the injured joint and extending their ability to prevent/mitigate PTOA, thereby improving treatment efficacy and reducing costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Asthma is a major global health burden, yet research on the potential utility of large-scale genome-wide and phenome-wide approaches for asthma risk prediction remains limited. This project proposes to apply statistical methods to develop integrated models of asthma risk with polygenic and environmental risk predictors in diverse populations. These analyses will advance our understanding of genetic and environmental contributions to asthma risk and provide novel approaches for studying asthma across populations.

PHR: Acquisition of invasive phenotypes is critical for progression from primary to metastatic melanoma which is most detrimental for patient survival in case of melanoma brain metastases (MBMs). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE X-ray crystallography is responsible for the majority of structural knowledge of biology at the molecular level. However, most of this knowledge has been established by observing static endpoints related to macromolecular function. We are developing novel fixed-target approaches to enable the next generation of serial time-resolved X-ray crystallography experiments to directly probe structural dynamics and advance the field of structural biology as a whole.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Osteosarcoma is a bone cancer that kills young people when it spreads to the lungs, which it does with unusual frequency. While seeking to understand why this tumor has such preference for lung tissue, we discovered that the structural cells of the lung (epithelial cells) induce changes in osteosarcoma cells that creates cells with different behaviors. By understanding the ways that these distinct subpopulations of tumor cells cooperate to establish metastases and resist the effects of chemotherapy, we hope to design therapies that make this previously-untreatable disease treatable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer researchers and clinicians are now using the power of human genome sequencing to analyze tumor samples from many thousands of cancer patients in their quest to cure cancer. The cBioPortal for Cancer Genomics is a widely used, user-friendly web resource that enables researchers to visualize, analyze, and interpret these big and complex data sets to make new discoveries. In this project, a collaborative team from major cancer centers will maintain and further develop the cBioPortal software, facilitating a better understanding of the genomic basis of cancer and guiding personalized therapy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dramatic increases in mothers' labor force participation coupled with increases in precarious and nonstandard jobs over the past 50 years call for new research to examine how these changes have transformed families' daily lives, and in turn, impacted children's health and development. The proposed research aims to: (1) document and explain trends in mothers' work hours and schedules over the past 30 years; (2) assess how the associations between mothers' work schedules, mothers' time with children, and child care arrangements have changed over time and as a result of increased public spending on child care and early education programs; and (3) determine how mothers' work schedules are associated with children's health and developmental outcomes in a contemporary, nationally-representative sample of U.S. children. The project will generate novel findings on how mothers' employment matters for child health and development that are necessary for making informed policy decisions about how to best support families in order to improve child health and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE In Mali, the 8th largest African country, a low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) located in West Africa, infection-associated cancers (IACs) are increasing and represent more than a quarter (27%) of all cancers. Few African scientists have the epidemiological, molecular pathology, biostatistics and bioinformatics training needed to design and conduct population-based and mechanistic studies on IACs. This research training program will capitalize on a decade of collaboration between Malian and US investigators to create capacity to develop and implement new contextually appropriate and culturally adaptive strategies to reduce in incidence, morbidity, and mortality of IAC in Mali and other LMICs in the region.

ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Meiosis is an essential stage of egg and sperm formation, errors in which can lead to infertility. Meiotic errors also cause eggs or sperm to have abnormal chromosome numbers, which results in miscarriage or developmental disabilities. This project will address fundamental questions about the mechanisms that regulate meiosis and thus is of direct relevance to human reproductive health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The investigators aim to explore how an informatics resource providing information on social determinants of health (SDoH) may facilitate identification and prevention of asthma exacerbations in school-based health centers. These contributions are expected to be significant because making informatics resources accessible to school-based health providers holds promise for increasing SDoH, further addressing SDoH to decrease asthma exacerbations. The findings of this study will open new horizons on the use of publicly available SDoH data in the unique model of school-based health centers, which are highly relevant to the SDoH and Health Equity research lenses of the National Institute of Nursing Research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL Prostate cancer is the most common cancer and second leading cause of cancer death for men in the United States. By bringing together basic and clinical investigators across the Dana-Farber/Harvard Cancer Center (DF/HCC) and fostering a research community focused on collaboration and innovation, the DF/HCC Prostate SPORE will address the most important translational research questions and unmet needs in prostate cancer. The three projects take distinct approaches to address the identification and treatment of aggressive prostate cancer, mechanisms of resistance to existing and emerging therapies, and the development of biomarker-driven tailored treatment approaches for patients. These projects will combine biologic studies with patient data to provide new insights into prostate cancer initiation and progression and to develop novel clinical approaches for patients. The DF/HCC Prostate SPORE will also catalyze and enhance interactions within and beyond the DF/HCC that will generate new discoveries, foster diversity, identify future research questions, and promote the next generation of prostate cancer researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Sleep apnea and insomnia, the two most common sleep disorders, are thought to be comprised of distinct subtypes, which remain poorly defined and may contribute differently to the risk of cardiopulmonary, metabolic and psychiatric diseases. Current critical gaps in our understanding and treatment of SA and insomnia include reliable phenotyping of sufficient participants to discover additional genetic associations and identifying clinically diagnosed sleep apnea and insomnia subtypes that lead to increased risk of disease. This project will address these challenges by discovering novel genetic associations with sleep disorders, resolving disease heterogeneity, and helping to clarify the overlap of SA and insomnia with other diseases, with a goal of improving the treatment of heart, lung, blood, and sleep disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 1 We propose comprehensive molecular analyses of responding and resistant tumors in a series of neoadjuvant clinical trials of intensive androgen signaling inhibition (ASI) in men with localized high-risk primary prostate cancer. Moreover, we will test the hypothesis that CDK4/6 activation is driving resistance by conducting a phase 2 clinical trial of neoadjuvant intensive ASI (leuprolide plus darolutamide) combined a CDK4/6 inhibitor (abemaciclib).These studies have important biomarker implications for the selection of patients most likely to benefit from intensive ASI, and for determination of mechanisms of resistance, with additional implications for metastatic castration-sensitive prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: This Metagenomics Education Partnership will immerse students and teachers within a citizen science research project focusing on assessing waterway health within the Western New York region consistent with the goals of the NIH Science Education Partnership Award (SEPA) R25 program. It will involve a novel third generation sequencing platform to determine the composition of the microbial communities present in those waterways, and to perform complete sequencing of one of the microbial genomes in the sample. The project will promote the role of genomics education in workforce development by informing high school students, educators and other relevant organizations how genomics integrates into future STEM jobs and careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite significant progress in understanding cognitive change around the time of breast cancer diagnosis and treatment, little is known regarding long-term cognitive trajectories and how these might be impacted by a history of cancer and cancer treatment. The overall goal of this proposal is to collect and analyze cognitive performance data at developmentally meaningful intervals 5-20 years post-treatment in older cancer survivors to determine whether cognitive performance remains stable or instead increasingly declines compared to individuals without a cancer history. We will also examine cognitive trajectories for their association with differential deficit accumulation in survivors compared to controls. This research is significant and innovative because little is known about potentially altered cognitive trajectories and the design and methods proposed will be able to characterize these trajectories and potential association with deficit accumulation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  DS patients experience low bone mineral density and are at increased risk of fracture. The proposed research will investigate the bone healing response in DS using mouse models of DS to study tissue and bone injury repair, and will determine the extent to which prostaglandin signaling, known to enhance bone formation and crucial for wound healing, may be disrupted in mouse models of DS. These studies will provide crucial information regarding the extent of compromised regeneration in DS and determine whether treatment with known pro-inflammatory and wound healing agents are able to correct the impaired bone and wound healing in murine DS model(s).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 2 We recently discovered a novel interaction between the enhance of zeste homolog 2 (EZH2) and DNA repair processes in castration resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) and a synergy between EZH2 and PARP inhibition. In this project, we will elucidate the mechanisms by which EZH2 regulates DNA repair, define how DNA repair pathways impact EZH2 drug sensitivity, and understand the biologic impact of EZH2 plus PARP inhibition across the heterogenous spectrum of CRPC. We will conduct a first -in-field combination EZH2 plus PARP inhibitor therapy clinical trial with extensive translational /biomarker correlates. Results from this project will provide the basis for a new therapeutic strategy for men with CRPC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We seek to develop new deep learning algorithms to utilize already-acquired abdominal computed tomography scans and pair them with a patient’s electronic medical records to predict the risk of future cardiovascular disease. Unlike traditional risk prediction techniques, our proposed tools utilize quantitative imaging measures of multiple tissues related to cardiovascular health as well as a patient’s prior clinical history. If successful, our algorithms could be used to explain a patient’s risk status to their clinician and ultimately, could be used to screen and intervene in millions of patients from diverse backgrounds who are unaware of their risk for heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT THREE Determination of the coordinated molecular and histopathologic features underlying diverse clinical states is critically needed to enable molecularly guided therapeutic strategies and biologically grounded predictive models for patients with localized prostate cancer who undergo surgery. We are developing biologically- guided artificial intelligence algorithms to understand the molecular and histopathologic features that distinguish key clinical outcomes in this context. This project will guide the convergence of artificial intelligence with translational prostate cancer research to enable precision oncology strategies for this patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Based on existing literature and clinical trials, 2-hydroxbenzylamine (2-HOBA) has clear impact on mechanisms that much of the international field of pulmonary hypertension (PH) research agrees are central to disease progression. Our preliminary data and Phase I studies demonstrate not only clear positive impact on reducing pulmonary vascular resistances in Group I and II PH, and both cytokine and molecular biomarkers of disease, but also indicated the potential for a substantial positive effect on heart function under load stress. In this Phase II project, we will test the safety and efficiacy of 2-HOBA in PH patients, improving function of the right ventricle under stress in a large animal model, and effectiveness in the context of standard-of-care in mouse models and large animals, to establish the remaining data needed to proceed to commercialization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The University of Washington CFRTC focuses its research on developing new and improved treatments for patients with Cystic Fibrosis and understanding the impact of these new therapies on patient heath. The Center has a long history of strong partnerships between laboratory and clinically based scientists working together to take observations from the laboratory and transforming these findings into better therapies to treat the nutritional, digestive, metabolic and lung aspects of CF. The CFRTC has 3 biomedical cores (Genomic, Host-Microbe, and Clinical), a pilot and feasibility program, and enrichment programs to encourage research collaborations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This study aims to advance understanding of adjunctive cryoablation’s ability to increase checkpoint inhibitor response by identifying biomarkers predictive of response as well as mechanisms of resistance. Biomarkers will be identified in preclinical murine models with the aid of granzyme B PET imaging and also identified from clinical biopsy specimens obtained from a prospective clinical trial of cryoablation and pembrolizumab in metastatic urothelial carcinoma. This study will help to define which cancer patients on immunotherapy are most likely to benefit from the addition of cryoablation and how resistance to adjunctive cryoablation can be overcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Relevance / Narrative Gastric dysmotility is a pervasive problem in critical illness that results in significant morbidity and mortality. There are knowledge gaps regarding the mechanisms for gastric dysmotility in this cohort. This proposal exam- ines a novel mechanism for gastric dysmotility in critical illness which will impact clinical outcomes for this co- hort by advancing the development of new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Fibromyalgia is difficult to diagnose and treat with current approaches based primarily on symptoms. The primary goal of this proposed research is to assess and validate candidate metabolic biomarkers to diagnose fibromyalgia and evaluate the relationships between metabolic biomarkers and fibromyalgia symptoms. These studies will provide results for development of potential diagnostic tests and therapeutic biomarkers to improve outcomes for individuals with fibromyalgia.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Uterine fibroids are common noncancerous tumors that can cause women to have severe bleeding, pelvic pressure and pain, urinary dysfunction, and adverse pregnancy outcomes. Although hysterectomy has traditionally been the most common treatment, many women seek alternative procedures that remove just the fibroid and preserve the uterus (myomectomy), leave the fibroids in the uterus but destroy fibroid tissue by heat (radiofrequency ablation) or by blocking blood flow (uterine artery embolization), or destroy the uterine lining to stop bleeding (endometrial ablation); however, there is no information on what happens to women after they have these treatments. Our goal is to study how well these hysterectomy alternatives improve fibroid symptoms and prevent the need for future fibroid treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate the risk of TB transmission from people with TB to children in their households. We will compare transmission risk between HIV-positive people taking antiretroviral therapy (ART) to HIV-positive people who are not taking ART, and compare people with TB who have symptoms to those who do not have symptoms (the "walking well"). The results will help target strategies to find people with TB who are infectious, so that TB transmission can be halted.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes remains a major cause of vision loss in the United States and new therapies are needed. The disease process includes loss of normal retinal blood vessel barrier properties, damaging the retina and leading to loss of vision. Here, we explore the possibility of utilizing natural cytokines involved in retinal vessel development, to restore blood vessel function in models of diabetic retinopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To survive and thrive in a dynamic environment, humans require the ability to focus on a task at hand while ignoring distraction (“cognitive stability”) as well as the ability to switch focus to a different task when goals or circumstances change (“cognitive flexibility”). The context-appropriate matching of cognitive stability and flexibility levels to different challenges in everyday life is severely impaired in many clinical conditions, but the underlying mechanisms of how the human brain dynamically regulates stability and flexibility are presently not well understood. This project combines a novel behavioral test of concurrent stability and flexibility adjustments with computational modeling of the underlying cognitive processes, and electrical and blood-flow measurements of brain activity, which together will allow us to reveal how the brain strategically adapts cognitive stability and flexibility to changing demands, and by inference, how these processes might be impaired in clinical populations.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The EHE initiative has presented an unprecedented opportunity to reduce the burden of HIV/AIDS across the nation. The simulation modeling platform and underlying evidence synthesis we have developed provides a flexible tool to help decision-makers allocate funds to maximize the impact of our efforts towards EHE. With this renewal application we will expand the reach and impact of our work, advance our efforts on identifying strategies to address the inequities in healthcare access in HIV prevention and treatment, and ultimately reach the ambitious goals of the EHE initiative by 2030.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The gaseous signaling molecule nitric oxide is known to have important roles in regulating gene expression through numerous transcriptional pathways, enabling a cell to adapt to its environment by dynamically regulating the set of genes it transcribes. We have recently determined that nitric oxide, through covalent S- nitrosylation of cysteine residues in target proteins, also regulates alternative splicing of mRNAs, a crucial mechanism by which cells expand the protein-coding capacity of the genome. The goal of this project is to understand the effect of nitric oxide in regulation of alternative splicing through S-nitrosylation of a key RNA- binding regulatory protein, defining a novel fundamental role by which NO exerts global effects on gene expression profiles in health and disease.

The Modules allow individual researchers to have access to expertise and state-of-the-art facilities that are not available in their laboratories, supporting important and interdisciplinary investigation of ocular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing a practical, proactive approach to management of geriatric problems in hemodialysis clinics. This research will fill the gap in geriatric care for older adults receiving hemodialysis and potentially increase quality of life and decrease healthcare utilization. The proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIA’s mission to maintain health, well-being, and function for older adults with multiple chronic conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to understand the role of hypoxia on the pathogenesis of glucose dysregulation in a high altitude model of sleep disordered breathing. We will also determine whether specific patterns of hypoxemia predispose to hyperglycemia during sleep in sleep disordered breathing patients. This study will establish whether targeting hypoxemia during sleep could improve glucose levels at night, potentially preventing or delaying the progression of diabetes and its sequelae.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health While there have been many advances in the treatment of liver cancer over the past half century, approximately 85% of patients with this disease will die within five years of diagnosis. Algorithmically controlled electroporation (ACE) is a new cancer therapy which uses ultrashort electrical pulses designed for the treatment of inoperable liver cancers. This Academic-Industrial Partnership proposal aims to develop the instrumentation and protocols necessary to translate ACE to the clinic and demonstrate the safety, efficacy and reproducibility of the treatment in a relevant spontaneous large animal model of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ubiquitylation is one of the most common post-translational modifications employed by cells and is essential for gene regulation. While the ubiquitin-dependent control of gene expression during interphase is well documented, it remains incompletely understood how ubiquitin-dependent enzymes regulate transcription during mitosis, a time in which there is limited gene activity. This work will shed new light on how ubiquitin- dependent enzymes control gene expression throughout the cell cycle, and we anticipate that this mechanistic study will provide a better context for understanding ubiquitin-dependent disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed educational plan will develop holistic medical need-driven design and device commercialization pipelines that expand from the freshman through super-senior years. The proposed activities will help engineering faculty and clinical faculty prepare the next generation biomedical engineering workforce. These engineers will be able to work effectively in multidisciplinary teams; have skills in idea generation and refinement; have social competence and skills to communicate with healthcare professionals; and, most importantly, design and translate new medical device ideas into products to improve human health and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glaucoma is the leading cause of irreversible blindness worldwide and is an important women’s health issue since women represent 59% of glaucoma patients. Menopause and altered estrogen levels are associated with changes in intraocular pressure (a known risk factor for glaucoma) and modulate biomechanical properties and protein expression tissues throughout the body (also potential risk factors for glaucoma). This proposal studies how menopause and topical estrogen therapy affect risk factors associated with glaucoma at the functional and mechanistic levels.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Center for Sleep in Autism Spectrum Disorder As many as 80% of children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) experience sleep disruptions including sleep fragmentation and delayed sleep onset. Animal data demonstrate sleep is essential for brain maturation, including neuronal development and synaptic plasticity, but sleep impairments in ASD are frequently considered only as secondary, co-occurring symptoms. Taking advantage of the conservation of similar sleep signatures and behavior across humans and animals we will employ a multi-modal, human subjects and animal models program to determine if sleep dysregulation is central to the development and exacerbation of symptoms in ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The next generation of technologies for regenerative medicine application will be fueled by cell- derived, self-packaged therapeutics known as extracellular vesicles (EVs). We will develop a process that makes these nano-sized therapeutics attachable to a biomaterial, like Velcro®, for tissue repair and regeneration. Additionally, our industry partner will modify their workflow to make the attachable EVs widely available and easy to use for downstream consumers, including those that are advancing regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This translational prospective cohort study of patients with multiple tumours arising on a background of germline VHL mutation aims to comprehensively characterise and understand the molecular events associated with growth and progression of clear cell renal cancer and other VHL associated cancers. We will employ multiparametric tumour profiling to assess how the molecular landscape, the tumour microenvironment and metabolic reprogramming contribute to differences in tumour behaviour. Outputs from this research have the potential to address key question in evolutionary cancer biology: the concept of evolutionary contingency; and in parallel, to identify the triggers for tumour growth and progression, and potentially revealing therapeutic vulnerabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Human cells regulate the functions of proteins by decorating them with sugar molecules, a process known as glycosylation. Our project aims to understand how glycosylation controls multiprotein complexes that drive important cell biological processes. This work may reveal new therapeutic opportunities to treat diseases in which glycosylation is dysregulated, including cancer, diabetes and neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative IPUMS CPS is essential data infrastructure for research on population health and child and family well-being in the United States. IPUMS CPS streamlines access to the Current Population Survey (CPS)—the nation’s primary source of timely data on monthly labor force statistics and the economic and social well-being of its people—by harmonizing, documenting, linking, and freely disseminating CPS data through a powerful data access platform. IPUMS CPS dramatically reduces the cost and increases the rigor and reproducibility of the research on population dynamics and population health with transformative implications for public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is the single greatest risk factor for the development of cancer, but how biological changes that occur during aging increase the incidence of cancer in older adults is largely unknown. This proposal examines how changes in protein homeostasis within aging blood-forming stem cells create a permissive environment for the emergence of clonal hematopoiesis and acute myeloid leukemia in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intracellular pH (pHi) dynamics are a critical regulator of numerous cell behaviors, including cell migration, cell adhesion remodeling, and cell fate specification, yet the role of pHi dynamics during embryonic development in vivo remains largely unknown. The objective of this proposal is to address this gap by determining the function of pHi dynamics in the development of cranial neural crest, a highly conserved multipotent embryonic cell population, using zebrafish as a model. My findings have promise to reveal new insight on the cellular and molecular factors controlling craniofacial development, with important implications for human congenital diseases and tissue repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Recent studies highlight significant promise for multi-parametric MRI (MP-MRI) and Prostate Health Index (PHI) in biopsy-naïve men to help ~25% of men avoid unnecessary prostate biopsies (PBs) while missing few clinically significant prostate cancers (csPCas). However, there is a need to increase the number of men who can safely avoid PB and expand it to Black and Hispanic men. Hence, we will 1) recruit Black and Hispanic biopsy-naïve men with PSA from 4-10ng/ml into a comparative effectiveness study to identify strategies using PHI & MP-MRI alone, in series, and in parallel to develop race-specific biopsy strategies with PHI & MP-MRI, and 3) identify the most accurate and cost-effective biopsy strategy to detect csPCa and minimize unnecessary PBs.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advancements in multimodal therapy for oral cavity and oropharyngeal (OC/OPC) cancers have improved survival outcomes beyond 5 years. However, most survivors will experience moderate-severe orodental sequelae that are inadequately monitored or managed given structural and informatics challenges precluding accurate orodental data collection. The proposed research aims to address implementation barriers to longitudinal patient- and provider-generated electronic data capture by developing practice-changing ontological systems and advanced computational models for treatment planning and assessment of outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  CMV has a high global prevalence and is the leading cause of transplant related mortality. The proposed research will combine tools from DNA and protein based synthetic structural biology to construct (i) a biosensor that will allow transplant patients to self-screen for CMV at home, and (ii) a protein switch that will use CMV’s genetic signature to kill virally infected cells. This is the first attempt at combining technologies from two separate fields that have evolved independently, and the outcome of this project will pave the way for the construction of biomolecular switches using this hybrid approach for applications beyond the reach of each individually.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: More than 30,000 veterans are hospitalized for stroke each year, and in the critical first months of recovery, at least half are disabled by abnormal 3-D spatial function (spatial neglect). Their self-care, mobility, and ability to return home are severely limited. Worse, many of these veterans are never diagnosed, counseled about the problem, or prescribed spatial rehabilitation. Here, we attempt to speed up spatial neglect diagnosis, using the brain imaging that is always part of the first hours of stroke care. We will compare 4 methods to identify the special brain imaging features present in people with spatial neglect who respond to early rehabilitation, and who recover best at 3 and 6 months after stroke. Once we complete this study, the next step will be to confirm our findings in a larger project, to ensure clinical brain imaging can be used for treatment assignment in veterans across gender, race, and other characteristics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is expected to advance the capability to engineer organisms for biomedical uses. Specifically, the outcomes of this project include design principles for engineering regulators from different protein families, an extensive set of genetic sensors for detecting a broad range of signals, and novel genetic circuits that address uprising problems in biomedical fields. The project is relevant to NIH’s mission because it uses a novel multidisciplinary approach to enhance the health of the nation by creating tools that facilitate both medical-related discoveries and the implementation of new strategies for biomedical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sensorineural hearing loss often involves the damage and retraction of auditory nerve fibers from the sensory epithelium within the cochlea. Regeneration of these auditory nerve fibers and reinnervation of the appropriate cell targets is limited in humans and other mammals. This study uses a zebrafish model to determine molecular cues and cellular behavior that may promote functional nerve regeneration to restore physiologic hearing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This innovative proposal will study the complex relationship between stress, endocannabinoid signaling, and cocaine-seeking behavior by exploring projection-specific neuroadaptations within a translational behavioral model. The results of these multi-faceted experiments will expand our understanding of the mechanisms underlying the individual or combined effects of stress and cocaine use and could provide insight into mechanisms that enhance drug seeking behavior. Together, the proposed experiments will reveal new mechanistic understanding of stress and cocaine interactions for the purpose of developing better treatment for cocaine use disorder and other substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to improve the guideline-concordant breast cancer (BC) screening among Latinas living in Chicago, by testing a new empowerment (empower) approach - wherein non-adherent Latinas are empowered to become informal breast health leaders in their community and are navigated to affordable, accessible care. We will examine if, relative to traditional approaches, the empower approach leads to greater BC screening among non-adherent Latinas and women in their social networks. We will also explore and identify the “active ingredients” that lead to greater BC screening in the empower approach - including greater knowledge, motivation to be a healthy role model, volunteerism in community BC initiatives, potential to “bridge” network members with formal change agents (e.g., community health workers, navigators), acceptability to promote BC, feasibility to promote BC, and BC promotion to network members.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Kaposi sarcoma herpesvirus (KSHV) infection can cause Kaposi’s sarcoma (KS), a major malignancy leads to mortality and morbidity in people living with HIV/AIDS. Saliva from people with HIV infection contains nanoparticle-like extracellular vesicles that increase KSHV infection. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Behavior often takes place in situations of motivational conflict, where opposing goals (i.e., consuming food and avoiding threats) occur simultaneously, requiring the appetitive and aversive elements to be weighed and integrated to guide choices. This proposal will use novel viral and imaging tools to dissect the role of dopamine and GABA neurons in the ventral tegmental area, a brain region critical for motivated behavior, in valence-based learning and decision making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative It is estimated that 10-25% of human embryos have the wrong number of chromosomes, resulting in a high incidence of miscarriages and birth defects. Most of these abnormalities are the result of mistakes generated when female reproductive cells (oocytes) divide, yet surprisingly little is known about the mechanisms that underlie the vulnerability of oocytes to these errors. This project seeks to gain insight into this important question, focusing on the assembly and stabilization of a structure called the spindle that mediates the segregation of chromosomes during cell division.

PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of the K12 Career Development Program at City of Hope is to provide a structured, multidisciplinary approach to training junior faculty to become independent investigators capable of translating advances in molecular oncology to the bedside and back. K12 Scholars engage in a multidisciplinary curriculum with didactic, laboratory, and clinical experience components in basic, translational, and clinical research in cancer- related fields. Scholars are guaranteed protected time for mentored translational research, and each is mentored by a clinician-scientist and a laboratory researcher.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Snord116 is a small nucleolar RNA that is genetically linked to appetite control. In this project, I will determine the molecular function of Snord116 in appetite-regulating centers of the brain and investigate how Snord116 loss affects the activity of neurons in these regions. Doing so is expected to contribute novel insights to the molecular basis of appetite control in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intentionally incorporating professional skills development into biomedical research training is essential to national goals of developing a diverse and adaptable scientific workforce, but advances in training have been limited by a lack of central mechanisms and incentives to share effective practices, leading to inefficiencies where institutions “recreate the wheel” or leave trainees without evidence-based professional skills training at their institutions. This project will support dissemination of effective educational approaches, provide training and mentoring for faculty and staff to implement those models, and develop assessment protocols and training. By training and mentoring faculty to enhance professional skills training at their institutions, we will impact research trainees across the country, enhancing training to meet the nation's workforce needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Meiotic errors are remarkably common in oocytes and give rise of chromosomal abnormalities in eggs and embryos, a leading cause of miscarriages, infertility, and genetic disorders. Spindle-bound actin filaments have recently emerged as a new mechanism that safeguards the accuracy of oocyte meiosis. The goal of this research to obtain molecular understanding of spindle actin filament assembly and function at the chromosome-microtubule interface in mammalian oocytes and embryos.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative How gene expression is regulated can inform the development of complex biological systems and help design treatment strategies for diseases by manipulating cell states; however, to accurately infer gene regulatory net- works, we urgently need to develop robust computational methods that incorporate rich transcriptomics and epigenomics data measured in single cells. This research program will develop computational methods for in- ferring and analyzing gene regulatory networks using multi-sample single-cell multiomics and spatial genomics data, use spatial trajectories from spatial transcriptomics data to characterize spatio-temporal gene regulation, and build network control strategies to manipulate networks to desired states (such as cellular healthy states). This research is expected to signiﬁcantly reduce the wasted resources in downstream validation experiments and reduce the cost in disease treatment.
