IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a need for developing small molecule tools that can both control protein function and be used for imaging in intact animals or patients. Our approach is to genetically alter cells to produce proteins of interest, such as chimeric antigen receptors (CARs), fused to a small bacterial enzyme called E. coli dihydrofolate reductase (eDHFR). eDHFR binds very tightly to the clinically-used antibiotic trimethoprim (TMP) and eDHFR-expressing cells will take up and bind TMP. We have engineered two derivatives of TMP. The first is coupled to a radioactive isotope that allows quantitative imaging of eDHFR and eDHFR expressing cells in animals using positron- emission tomography. The second is the focus of this research project, a version of TMP that is tethered to another small molecule, pomalidomide (POM). These TMP-POM molecules guide eDHFR-fusion proteins to the protein degradation machinery (e.g. the proteosome) of the cell causing destruction of the fusion protein. We will apply these molecules to show their ability to regulate the expression of diverse fusion partner proteins, to show their mechanism of action, and to improve the therapeutic window of CAR T-cells. This project sets a new precedent for small protein tags which confer dual in vivo imaging and regulation capabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with similar degrees of sensorineural hearing loss, as defined by the audiogram, often have varying levels of difficulty understanding speech in noisy environments. To assess the relationship between dysfunction in the auditory periphery and perception, the proposed project uses coordinated non-invasive biomarkers sensitive to multiple sites of cochlear dysfunction in both humans and chinchillas with sensorineural hearing loss to estimate profiles of peripheral pathology and predict hearing outcomes in background noise. Results from this cross- species study will provide valuable insight into the dysfunctions that underlie common auditory complaints and improve personalization of treatments for sensorineural hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use disorder (AUD) and its outcomes are a leading cause of death and disability in the United States, but the neurobiological changes underlying the pathogenesis of AUD are unknown. This proposal aims to investigate the long non-coding RNA Gas5 as a regulator of glucocorticoid-dependent molecular and behavioral phenotypes of alcohol dependence. This research will uncover a novel facet of AUD neurobiology that may lead to more effective therapeutics for AUD and other human conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to establish a Hemophilia A Analytical Cohort Research Program (HARP) to support the development of an Intergenerational Precision Medicine Program for the study of factor VIII (FVIII) immunogenicity in severe hemophilia A. The three major aims of HARP are to form a new longitudinal antenatal/neonatal/pediatric severe hemophilia A cohort to study the development of FVIII inhibitors, to enable the development of the HARP Shareable Resource comprised of well annotated data and biological samples, and to perform hypothesis-testing research in each of the four scientific emphasis areas. The HARP data and biospecimen resources collected over the course of the program will advance our knowledge of the pathophysiology of inhibitor development and be accessible to community researchers through a portal, F8portal.org.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to first confirm statins protective effects on the radiographic knee (OA) progression in a subset of Osteoarthritis Initiative (OAI) participants with non-traumatic generalized osteoarthritis (OA) with Heberden's nodes (i.e., HN+ GOA) and no/minimal subchondral bone marrow lesions (BMLs), as the “potential responders” using advanced MRI measures of cartilage structural damage and serum/urine cartilage degradation biomarkers. Second, the mediatory role of subchondral bone morphometry and subchondral BMLs will be assessed for the protective effect statin on radiographic knee OA outcome. We will further explore subchondral bone and vascular structures and analyze the osteogenesis, angiogenesis, and accumulation of senescent cells (SnCs) in subchondral bone in early dyslipidemia-associated non-traumatic OA mice models to evaluate the mechanism underlying the therapeutic effect of statins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - NADPH is implicated in various diseases, including cancer and neurodegenerative disorders. NADK2 deficiency depletes the mitochondrial pool of NADPH and results in severe neurological and developmental symptoms in patients, however the metabolic consequences of NADK2 deficiency are not known. Here we will identify the vital functions of NADK2 and mitochondrial NADPH in cell metabolism, cell growth and proliferation, paving way for future therapeutic interventions for proliferative diseases and for patients with NADK2 mutations.

PHR: We propose a new, clinically interpretable, personalized, and generalizable disease index, and a web-tool for efficient quantification of national-level association and causal estimation of longitudinal treatment effects for assessing multi-comorbidities (periodontal disease and Type-2 diabetes), factoring in the intersection of sex/gender influences. Longer-term impact on public health is expected to be far-reaching, bridging the gap between epidemiologists, and health practitioners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Mapping of connections, neurons and nuclei in the human brainstem will enable new and highly specific types of analyses of neuroimaging data. In particular, the ability to probe cellular and connectional properties of specific brainstem nuclei may provide significant advances in disorders such as traumatic brain injury, Alzheimer’s disease, and an array of other neurologic conditions. Finally, the 3D-PSOCT we propose to develop is a potentially transformative tool as it allows direct imaging of axonal orientation with micrometer-scale resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of cancer-related death in the United States. Chemotherapy is used in advanced stage colorectal cancers yet the resistance mechanisms are not fully known. This project is aimed at understanding the role of immune system in regulating chemotherapy response in colon cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parent-engagement strategies, while effective in reducing teen motor vehicle collisions (MVCs), have not been implemented and tested among high-risk teen drivers such as those with a traffic violation. Through established collaborations with rural and urban juvenile traffic courts in Ohio, this study will test, in a hybrid randomized controlled trial, the implementation, effectiveness, and cost-effectiveness of a parent- engagement intervention tailored to the needs of teen drivers with a traffic violation. The findings will have an impact on juvenile traffic courts’ practices and policies aimed to improve teen driving safety by reducing MVCs and MVC-related injuries and deaths, which aligns with NICHD’s ongoing research priority.
